sloka: cinmayasyādvitīyasya niṣkalasyāśarīriṇaḥ | upāsakānāṃ kāryārthe brahmaṇo rūpakalpanā ||
translation: Of the indivisible, bodiless one that is consciousness and unique, the form envisioning is the duty of the devotees for some particular purpose.

sloka: devebhyaḥ svāhākāra ā kāṣṭhāt
translation: From the divine beings, (coming) from a tree, (is the exclamation) svāhā.

sloka: tasmādapaḥ sambharati tasmāddhiraṇyaṃ sambharati taddyāvāpṛthivyo rasena samardhayati tasmādūṣāntsambharati tasmādākhukarīṣaṃ sambharati
translation: Therefore, it nourishes the waters from there, and similarly enriches the earth with its essence; furthermore, it causes the extremities to be nourished. Thus, it is also responsible for nourishing the plants that grow from the earth.

sloka: kṛttikāsu rohiṇyāṃ mṛgaśirasi phalgunīṣu viśākhayoruttarayoḥ proṣṭhapadayoḥ ||
translation: At the front of Rohini and at the heads of Mriga, Phalguni, Uttara's later part, and Visakha, respectively.

sloka: kṛttikāsu brāhmaṇa ādadhīta mukhyo brahmavarcasī bhavati gṛhāṃstasyāgnirdāhuko bhavati ||
translation: In the Krttikas (a group of stars), if a brahmin studies (this) primary knowledge of the Brahman, he becomes worthy of veneration; his home becomes a place for fire offerings.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are spring, summer, and the rains; these two, autumn and winter, they call the fathers.

sloka: rātriṃ jāgaraṇadhāraṇe śakalairvā
translation: During the night, or in the form of staying awake, by everyone, perhaps?

sloka: śamīgarbhādagniṃ manthati | eṣā vā agneryajñiyā tanūḥ |
translation: The firewood's core is churned. This, indeed, is the physical form of the sacrificial fire.

sloka: sa bhūrbhuva ityetaistribhirakṣarairgārhapatyamādadhāti dve pariśinaṣṭyayātayāmatāyai
translation: He, with these three syllables "bhūrbhuva," endows the sacred domestic fire while nurturing it with great care, causing two entities to approach and move away.

sloka: yo aśvatthaḥ śamīgarbha āruroha tvesacā | taṃ tvāharāmi brahmaṇā yajñiyaiḥ ketubhiḥ saheti pūrṇāhutyantamagnyādheyaṃ
translation: The ashvattha tree that has sprung from the seed of a shami tree, I now offer it with oblations performed in full through the sacred formulas.

sloka: punarādheyamādhānā'pratijñātasya rājyayaśaskāmasya vā trirātrāvaramagnīnutsṛjya sadyo vā punarvasvoḥ varṣāsu madhyandine vā kuśairādhānam vrīhyapūpamarkapalāśayoḥ pakvaṃ gārhapatyasthāne nidadhātyevamāhamanīyasya yāvaṃ sadyaścet
translation: Again, the future passive participle of preparing oneself for the rule or kingdom, not having previously promised, should he abandon the fires after three nights and days, or immediately, in the middle of the rains, should he establish the ripened sacrifice of barley and rice on sacred grass - this is what I will do for one who is deserving.

sloka: nānāhitāgnirnāyajvā vipro nāpyasahasradaḥ |
translation: "Are not some fires beneficial, o learned one, and will a thousandstreams not be able to satisfy?"

sloka: ayajño vā eṣaḥ | yo'patnīkaḥ |
translation: "Indeed, this one is un Religious or has not performed religious rites, or one who neglects his wife ."

sloka: etadvai jarāmaryaṃ satraṃ yadagnihotraṃ jarayā vā hyevāsmānmucyate mṛtyunā vā payasā nityahomaḥ
translation: This indeed is the sacrificial ritual, called Agnihotra, that liberates us from decay, either through the natural aging process or through death, by means of the constant oblation of a mixture of milk and ghee.

sloka: yavāgūrodano dadhi samigrāmakāmānnādyakāmendriyakāmatejaskāmānāṃ
translation: The tears of the one who has just finished eating yavagu (a type of rice dish) are aimed at (i.e., will fall on) the pot of curd.

sloka: dhūmāyantyām grāma kāmasya juhuyāt | jvalantyām brahma varcasa kāmasya | aṅgāreṣu paśu kāmasya |
translation: In the settlement's closing moments, should (he) offer oblations to the smoke; desiring the Brahman's resplendence, should (he) attend to it in living beings.

sloka: jātaṃ vātsapreṇābhimṛśyottareṇa yajuṣopastha ādhāyottarābhyāmābhimantraṇaṃ mūrdhanyavaghrāṇaṃ dakṣiṇe karṇe jāpaḥ sarṣapānphalīkaraṇamiśrānañjalinottaraistristripratisvāhākāraṃ hutvā saṃśāsti praviṣṭe praviṣṭa eva tūṣṇīmagnāvāvapateti
translation: Having been born, you should touch (the newborn) with the upper part of a cow's tail, after reciting the yajuṣ mantras over it. Placing it on the infant's head, make him/her silent by chanting the japa mantra in the right ear. After performing these rituals, become still and silently observe the entry of the new soul into this world.

sloka: athaināmuttarayā dakṣiṇe haste gṛhītvāgnimabhyānīyāpareṇāgnimudagagraṃ kaṭamāstīrya tasminnupaviśata uttaro varaḥ agnerupasamādhānādyājyabhāgānte'thaināmādito dvābhyāmabhimantrayeta
translation: Having taken the firewood in the right hand, having made the southern portion (of the altar) and placed thereon the turf with its top to the east, having kindled the fire, and when the final oblations have been offered, then should he cause the recitation of the Savitri formula twice with the words "svaha" and "idam".

sloka: sāyaṃsāyaṃ gṛhapatirno agniḥ prātaḥprātaḥ saumanasasya dātā | vasorvasorvasudāna edhi vayaṃ tvendhānāstanvaṃ puṣema || prātaḥprātargṛhapatirno agniḥ sāyaṃsāyaṃ saumanasasya dātā | vasorvasorvasudāna edhīndhānāstvā śataṃhimā ṛdhema ||
translation: At dawn, the householder, offering oblations to the fire, becomes the giver of wealth. We both, tending our respective duties, should invigorate this shared prosperity. In the evening, once again the householder, as the benefactor of serenity, attends to the fire. Thus, let us two, dedicated and ardent in our tasks, foster a hundredfold increase.

sloka: sa yatsāyamastamite dve'āhutī juhoti | tadetābhyāṃ pūrvābhyāṃ padbhyāmetasminmṛtyau pratitiṣṭhattyatha yatprātaranudite dve'āhutī juhoti tadetābhyāmaparābhyāṃ padbhyāmetasminmṛtyau pratitiṣṭhati sa'enameṣa'udyannevā''dāyodeti tadetaṃ mṛtyumatimucyate
translation: He who, in the morning and in the evening, offers the two oblations, does so with these (preceding) two steps at this death. And similarly, he who performs the two oblations in the morning and in the afternoon, stands firm at this death. This is called the awakening; through it, one is liberated from the bondage of this death.

sloka: tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ pradūyetaiv~ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante ya etadevaṃ vidvānagnihotraṃ juhoti ||
translation: The one who knows this (the sacred knowledge) entirely burns away the fuel of attachment in the fire of discrimination, and all sinful tendencies also get burned away. Such a person performs the agnihotra sacrifice.

sloka: vasanti prāṇino yatra |
translation: Where living beings dwell/reside.

sloka: karṇaśrave'nile rātrau divā pāṃsusamūhane | etau varṣāsvanadhyāyāvadhyāyajñāḥ pracakṣate
translation: In the nighttime at dawn, during the gathering of dust, these two—the recitation and study—are indicated as those that are to be performed in the rainy season.

sloka: vidyutstanitavarṣeṣu maholkānāṃ ca saṃplave | ākālikam anadhyām eteṣu manurabravīt etāṃstvabhyuditānvidyādyadā prāduṣkṛtāgniṣu | tadā vidyādanadhyāyam anṛtau cābhradarśane
translation: "In the showers of lightning and meteors, Manu declared these long-established sciences to be studied without interruption. He said that they should be constantly cultivated, even when fires are extinguished during eclipses, and in the absence of rainfall and clear skies."

sloka: nirghāte bhūmicalane jyotiṣāṃ copasarjane | etānākālikānvidyādanadhyāyānṛtāvapi prāduṣkṛteṣvagniṣu tu vidyutstanitaniḥsvane | sajyotiḥ syādanadhyāyaḥ śeṣe rātrau yathā divā
translation: In the activities of sweeping the ground and tending to luminaries, even when the stars appear in the dual firmament, a teacher versed in periphrastic knowledge will ignite sparks in fires neglected during the daytime. Just as light is present during the day, so too should it be at the end of the night.

sloka: nīhāre bāṇaśabde ca saṃdhyayoreva cobhayoḥ | amāvāsyācaturdaśyoḥ paurṇamāsyaṣṭakāsu ca amāvāsyā guruṃ hanti śiṣyaṃ hanti caturdaśī | brahmāṣṭakapaurṇamāsyau tasmāttāḥ parivarjayet
translation: In the locative of "nīha" and "śabda," as well as in both "sandhyas," at twilight, you both have recited perfectly. In the present optative, should you wish to recite during new moon's fourteenth phase and the eighth day of the bright fortnight, beware! You will strike down (the asterism) Jupiter during new moon (amāvāsyā) and the fourteenth phase (daśī). Therefore, one should refrain from reciting during both new moon and full moon (brahma-paurṇamāsau).

sloka: pāṃsuvarṣe diśāṃ dāhe gomāyuvirute tathā | śvakharoṣṭre ca ruvati paṅktau ca na paṭheddvijaḥ
translation: In the rainfall and in the scorching of the directions, on cows and in pus produced from wounds, a twice-born does not recite (the sacred texts) on the ground or on the bank of a river.

sloka: pratigṛhya dvijo vidvānekoddiṣṭasya ketanam | tryahaṃ na kīrtayedbrahma rājño rāhośca sūtake yāvadekānudiṣṭasya gandho lepaśca tiṣṭhati | viprasya viduṣo dehe tāvadbrahma na kīrtayet prāṇi vā yadi vāprāṇi yatkiṃ cicchrāddhikaṃ bhavet | tadālabhyāpyanadhyāyaḥ pāṇyāsyo hi dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ
translation: Accepting the teachings of a twice-born scholar, one should not publicly proclaim the Brahmana's selection in the king's or robber's presence. As long as the fragrance and mark of the chosen one remain, so too should the knowledge of the Brahman within the scholar's body. If an animal or even breath is offered more than what is prescribed, it becomes a sinful act. Only when it is properly studied does the twice-born become worthy of such offerings.

sloka: dvāveva varjayennityaṃ anadhyāyau prayatnataḥ | svādhyāyabhūmiṃ cāśuddhaṃ ātmānaṃ cāśuciṃ dvijaḥ
translation: A twice-born should carefully cause the avoidance of just two subjects in daily study , namely impure self and impure scriptural text , with dedicated effort .

sloka: nādhīyītāśvaṃ ārūḍho na vṛkṣaṃ na ca hastinam | na nāvaṃ na kharaṃ noṣṭraṃ neriṇastho na yānagaḥ śayānaḥ prauḍhapādaśca kṛtvā caivāvasakthikām | nādhīyītāmiṣaṃ jagdhvā sūtakānnādyaṃ eva ca
translation: Should not one mount a horse, climb a tree, ride an elephant, sail in a boat, or ride a donkey, nor should one lie down on the ground with thickly grown legs, but should get up and make an effort; nor should one eat meat, drink alcohol, or indulge in other such acts.

sloka: corairupadrute grāme saṃbhrame cāgnikārite | ākālikaṃ anadhyāyaṃ vidyātsarvādbhuteṣu ca
translation: In the village, due to confusion caused by fire, and in the sudden occurrence of a calamity, one should abandon (the study of) the entirety of learning that is not to be studied at once.

sloka: upākarmaṇi cotsarge trirātraṃ kṣepaṇaṃ smṛtam | aṣṭakāsu tvahorātraṃ ṛtvantāsu ca rātriṣu
translation: During the three-day festival of Upakarma, picking (of specified items) is remembered; in contrast, for the eight days and the nights of the change of seasons, it's placing (of those items).

sloka: na vivāde na kalahe na senāyāṃ na saṃgare | na bhuktamātre nājīrṇe na vamitvā na śuktake atithiṃ cānanujñāpya mārute vāti vā bhṛśam | rudhire ca srute gātrācchastreṇa ca parikṣate
translation: In no dispute, battle, army, assembly, when food has merely been tasted or is leftover, nor in pretense or boasting, should a host not welcome a guest; the wind blows forcefully, and one is examined by bloodshed, hearing, and physical contact.

sloka: sāmadhvanāvṛgyajuṣī nādhīyīta kadā cana | vedasyādhītya vāpyantaṃ āraṇyakaṃ adhītya ca
translation: "In no circumstances should the two, 'sāma-dhvana' and 'ṛk-yajuṣī' ever be not studied; whether or not one has studied the Vedas, they should also study the āraṇyaka."

sloka: vibhāvasubharadrājau parjanyairāvatau tathā | viśvācīsenajitsaṃjñau kārttike cādhikāriṇāḥ ||
translation: In the rainy season, are you the ones, Vasubharat and Airavata, endowed with abundant splendor, known as Viśvācī and Senajit, who excel in Kārttike?

sloka: śeṣaḥ prathamato jāto vāsukistadanantaram| airāvatastakṣakaśca karkoṭakadhanañjayau||
translation: The serpent named Shesha was born first, followed by Vasuki, then Airavata and Takshaka, and finally the two (Karkotaka and Dhananjaya).

sloka: daśa krodhavaśā rāma vijajñe api ātmasaṃbhavāḥ | mṛgīm ca mṛgamaṃdām ca harīm bhadramadām api ||
translation: To Rama, he revealed his true nature, born of ten furies; even the doe and the shining one, as well as the auspicious one, he subdued.

sloka: tato jajñe mahākāyaścaturdanto mahāgajaḥ| kapilā kāmavṛkṣaśca kaustubhaścāpsarogaṇaḥ|
translation: Then emerged the immense one, the four-tusked elephant known as Mahagaja, along with the desire-fulfilling tree Kapila, the Kaustubha gem, and the retinue of Apsaras.

sloka: pitṛṇāṃ dharmarājaṃ taṃ yamaṃ rājye'bhyaṣecayat | airāvataṃ gajendrāṇām aśeṣāṇāṃ patiṃ dadau ||
translation: The king of men, Yama, was consecrated as the future ruler by the forefathers, and he gave Airavata to all the elephant lords.

sloka: śeṣantu nāgarājānaṃ mṛgāṇāṃ siṃhamīśvaram | vanaspatīnāṃ rājānaṃ plakṣamevābhyaṣecayat ||
translation: Let the snake king be concluded, and Lord Lion be consecrated as the king of animals. Likewise, let Plaksha be enthroned as the king of trees.

sloka: yo māmajamanādiṃ ca vetti lokamaheśvaram | asaṃmūḍhaḥ sa martyeṣu sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate ||
translation: The one who truly knows me as the origin of all, including myself, and the lord of the world, becomes without confusion in the mortal realm and is freed from all sins.

sloka: maharṣayaḥ sapta pūrve catvāro manavastathā | madbhāvā mānasā jātā yeṣāṃ loka imāḥ prajāḥ ||
translation: The seven ancient sages and four human Manus, who were born of my mind, they are the ones from whom these creatures in this world have originated.

sloka: etāṃ vibhūtiṃ yogaṃ ca mama yo vetti tattvataḥ | so'vikampena yogena yujyate nātra saṃśayaḥ ||
translation: The one who truly understands this divine power and yoga of mine, he unites with it effortlessly; there is no doubt about this.

sloka: arjuna uvāca
translation: Arjuna spoke,

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam ||
translation: I, the imperishable, am the creator of the four-varnas (social classes) according to their qualities and actions. Know me to be the doer of this and also not the doer.

sloka: eṣāmutpattyādiryathā yadā bhagavān puruṣarūpeṇa sṛṣṭiṃ kṛtavān tadāsyaśarīrāt catvāro varṇā utpannāḥ mukhato brāhmaṇāḥ bāhutaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ūruto vaiśyāḥ pādataḥ śūdrā jātāḥ
translation: When the lord, in the form of Purusha, created the universe, then from his body emerged four varnas (social classes) in order:

sloka: yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | yasmāttrayo'pyāśramiṇo jñānenānnena cānvaham | gṛhasthenaiva dhāryante tasmājjyeṣṭhāśramo gṛhī |
translation: Just as all beings exist relying on the wind, similarly all asramas (stages of life) exist relying on the householder. Indeed, the knowledge of the three asramis (those who inhabit the first three asramas) is upheld by the householder alone. Therefore, the foremost asrama is that of the grihasta (householder).

sloka: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo'dhyemi yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitrya~rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajñavidyāmetadbhagavo'dhyemi
translation: I meditate on the Ridgeveda, praised be you, and Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvana, the fourth; the historical account and Puranas are the fifth; the treasure of sacred tradition in speech , knowledge of devas, brahma, and elements , kshatra-vidya, nakshatra-vidya, sarpadeva-jna-vidya, all these I meditate upon.

sloka: ahaṃ tṛtīya ityatristasmādatriḥ sa kīrtyate ||
translation: I am called the third one, named Tritiya; he is known by the name Atri from me.

sloka: atrivaṃśasamutpanno brahmayoniḥ sanātanaḥ| prācīnabahirbhagavāṃstasmātprācetaso daśa||
translation: Born from the eternal part of the lineage of Atri, and located on the outside, [he is] the supreme being. Therefore, he has the ten qualities of the enlightened one.

sloka: daśānāṃ tanayastveko dakṣo nāma prajāpatiḥ| tasya dve nāmanī loke dakṣaḥ ka iti cocyate||
translation: Of the ten's offspring, a single being named Daksha is skilled; of him, two names are known in the world - who is called Daksha?

sloka: vāgevātrirvācā hyannamadyate'ttirha vai nāmaitadyadatririti | sarvasyāttā bhavati sarvamasyānnambhavati | ya evaṃ veda |
translation: In speech, the threefold *vāc* (representing Rig, Yajur, and Sama Vedas) is manifest in the designations such as "anna" (food) and "mati" (thought), etc. The self of all becomes everything, and everything turns into the self of that. One who knows this, he/they know it in action.

sloka: svāminaḥ sevanaṃ dṛṣṭvā śivasya ca parātmanaḥ || sādhvi dharmaṃ ca te dṛṣṭvā sthitāsmi tava sannidhau ||
translation: Having seen the service to Lord Shiva and his own self, I stand in your presence, O righteous one, after having observed your adherence to dharma and yours alone.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā nātiprabhaṃ somaṃ tathā sūryaṃ ca pārthiva| prakāśamakarodatristapasā svena saṃyuge| jagadvitimiraṃ cāpi pradīptamakarottadā||
translation: On witnessing the brilliant moon and sun, O king, Atri, in his own battle, made them shine intensely; you two also dispelled the cosmic darkness and caused it to become illuminated.

sloka: sarvaṃ hīdaṃ prāṇenā''vṛtam iti | so'yamākāśaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdhastadyathā'yamākāśaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdha | evaṃ sarvāṇi bhūtāni āpipīlikābhyaḥ prāṇena bṛhatyā viṣṭabdhānītyevaṃ vidyāt iti ||
translation: Everything in this world is enveloped by the vital force called prana, so too is space vast and expansive because of that same prana. Likewise, know all beings from the smallest to largest are pervaded by that same vital force. This is the knowledge one should have.

sloka: āyuḥ prāṇaḥ prāṇo vā āyuḥ prāṇa evācāmṛtam | yāvaddhyasmiñcharīre prāṇo vasati tāvadāyuḥ |
translation: "Is life the same as breath, or is breath a means to immortality ? As long as the breath resides in this body, one has life."

sloka: prāṇena sṛṣṭāvantarikṣaṃ ca vāyuśca | antarikṣaṃ vā anucaranti antarikṣamanuśṛṇvanti | vāyurasmai puṇyaṃ gandhamāvahati | evametau prāṇaṃ pitaraṃ paricarato'ntarikṣaṃ ca vāyuśca |
translation: "O life-force, just as the atmosphere and wind travel in and listen to the sky, so too do they carry sacred scents for it. Thus, the sky and wind serve the life-force in this way."

sloka: taṃ devāḥ prāṇayanta sa praṇītaḥ prātāyata prātāyītī~ tatprātarabhavatsamāgāditī~ tatsāyamabhavadahareva prāṇo rātrirapānaḥ iti |
translation: The gods then began to bring him back to life at dawn. That's when he fully revived at daybreak, and his breath, day, and night once again became established right then.

sloka: vāgagniścakṣurasāvādityaścandramā mano diśaḥ śrotraṃ sa eṣa prahitāṃ saṃyogo'dhyātmamimā devatā ada u āviradhidaivatamityetattaduktaṃ bhavati iti |
translation: This is the union of speech as Agni, the sharp-edged sun as Sāva, Āditya as the moon, and mind as Man; the directions as hearing – all this, called the inner divinity (adhyātmam), has been declared.

sloka: pūrvajanma kṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vyādhi rūpeṇa bādhate | tata śāṃtiroṣadhedāneṃ mantra japa homa surāracaneṃ ||
translation: Previous birth's karma manifests as disease. To pacify it, O serene one, chant mantras, perform homas and fire rituals.

sloka: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvettu mṛtena pramṛtena vā | satyānṛtābhyāṃ api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet
translation: May they always live nourished by the true and the immortal, or by the false and the mortal. Never should one live through deceitful livelihood. The truly pure truth is to be known as immortal. The deceitful trade is designated as mortal. By these very means does one live. Service is named mundane livelihood; thus, one should avoid it.

sloka: ato'nyatamayā vṛttyā jīvaṃstu snātako dvijaḥ | svargāyuṣyayaśasyāni vratāṇīmāni dhārayet
translation: Thus, a twice-born who has completed his purification ritual should uphold these two observances of increasing one's lifespan and following vows in this way , so the scripture says . Let him cause them to be held .

sloka: vedam evābhyasennityaṃ yathākām atandritaḥ | taṃ hyasyāhuḥ paraṃ dharmam upadharmo'nya ucyate
translation: One should recite the Vedas continually and tirelessly, as he desires; they declare that this is his supreme duty, while everything else is described as a transgression.

sloka: klptakeśanakhaśmaśrurdāntaḥ śuklāmbaraḥ śuciḥ | svādhyāye caiva yuktaḥ syānnityaṃ ātmahiteṣu ca
translation: Endowed with well-combed hair and clean at the tips, wearing white garments and pure, engaged in regular study, should one always be for one's own benefit.

sloka: sarvānparityajedarthānsvādhyāyasya virodhinaḥ | yathā tathādhyāpayaṃstu sā hyasya kṛtakṛtyatā
translation: He should give up all conflicting matters of study; in this way, one can teach appropriately. This is indeed his obligatory duty.

sloka: buddhivṛddhikarāṇyāśu dhanyāni ca hitāni ca | nityaṃ śāstrāṇyavekṣeta nigamāṃścaiva vaidikān | yathā yathā hi puruṣaḥ śāstraṃ samadhigacchati | tathā tathā vijānāti vijñānaṃ cāsya rocate
translation: Indeed, he should regularly examine the scriptures and Vedic treatises; as a person acquires knowledge from scriptures, he understands and finds delight in that understanding, each according to its own merits.

sloka: vedābhyāsena satataṃ śaucena tapasaiva ca | adroheṇa ca bhūtānāṃ jātiṃ smarati paurvikīm paurvikīṃ saṃsmaranjātiṃ brahmaivābhyasyate punaḥ | brahmābhyāsena cājasraṃ anantaṃ sukhaṃ aśnute
translation: By constantly practicing the Vedas, purity, and austerity, oh man, you will remember the inherent nature of all beings. By repeatedly practicing brahmavidyā, one experiences infinite joy.

sloka: ṛṣiyajñaṃ devayajñaṃ bhūtayajñaṃ ca sarvadā | nṛyajñaṃ pitṛyajñaṃ ca yathāśakti na hāpayet
translation: One should always perform the ṛṣiyajña, devayajña, bhūtayajña, and offer naively as much as possible to nṛyajña and pitṛyajña.

sloka: etāneke mahāyajñānyajñaśāstravido janāḥ | anīhamānāḥ satataṃ indriyeṣveva juhvati vācyeke juhvati prāṇaṃ prāṇe vācaṃ ca sarvadā | vāci prāṇe ca paśyanto yajñanirvṛttiṃ akṣayām
translation: These scholars of the major sacrifices' scriptures know well and constantly offer their senses, in some cases they dedicate their speech and vital breath, while always being mindful of the unending fulfillment achieved through sacrifice.

sloka: jñānenaivāpare viprā yajantyetairmakhaiḥ sadā | jñānamūlāṃ kriyāṃ eṣāṃ paśyanto jñānacakṣuṣā
translation: With sacred knowledge alone, O brahmins, do you all constantly worship with these false rituals. They see the root of actions, these seers, with the eye of wisdom.

sloka: agnihotraṃ ca juhuyādādyante dyuniśoḥ sadā | darśena cārdhamāsānte paurṇāmāsena caiva hi
translation: And let a sacrifice to Agni be offered at the beginning and end of day, as well as during the half-monthly darśa and full moon rituals.

sloka: sāvitrāñ śāntihomāṃśca kuryātparvasu nityaśaḥ | pitṝṃścaivāṣṭakāsvarcennityaṃ anvaṣṭakāsu ca
translation: Perform the Savitra and peace chants daily in specific times, and also regularly pay respects to the ancestors during the eight nights.

sloka: rājato dhanam anvicchetsaṃsīdansnātakaḥ kṣudhā | yājyāntevāsinorvāpi na tvanyata iti sthitiḥ
translation: A person should seek wealth only from a royal source, being one who has undergone the samsiddha-snana (a religious ablution) and is free from hunger. The state of being settled near the fire altar or the dwelling of the officiating priest, whether as a yajyaa or not, is not considered separate (from this).

sloka: na sīdetsnātako vipraḥ kṣudhā śaktaḥ kathaṃ cana | na jīrṇamalavadvāsā bhavecca vibhave sati
translation: A bathed and purified priest cannot be overcome by hunger, how then can he be, when he is not destitute? And how could one, whose clothes are not tattered and worn out, ever become so, when he has the means?

sloka: daśa sūṇāsahasrāṇi yo vāhayati saunikaḥ | tena tulyaḥ smṛto rājā ghorastasya pratigrahaḥ yo rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇāti lubdhasyocchāstravartinaḥ | sa paryāyeṇa yātīmānnarakānekaviṃśatim etadvidanto vidvāṃso brāhmaṇā brahmavādinaḥ | na rājñaḥ pratigṛhṇanti pretya śreyo'bhikāṅkṣiṇaḥ
translation: The ruler who can draw ten thousand chariots is considered equal in prowess to Saunika, the one who accepts the tribute of such a king is as greedy and unlearned in scriptures as one who would not receive the tribute after the king's death for the sake of greater good. The scholars well-versed in Vedas know this.

sloka: vayasaḥ karmaṇo'rthasya śrutasyābhijanasya ca | veṣavāgbuddhisārūpyaṃ ācaranvicarediha śrutismṛtyuditaṃ samyaṅnibaddhaṃ sveṣu karmasu | dharmamūlaṃ niṣeveta sadācāraṃ atandritaḥ ācārāllabhate hyāyurācārādīpsitāḥ prajāḥ | ācārāddhanaṃ akṣayyaṃ ācāro hantyalakṣaṇam
translation: Inquire into the purpose of actions, lineage, and hearing; strive to follow the example set by those who have realized the identity of speech, intellect, and conduct. Properly adhere to the established codes of conduct in your own actions, being always steadfast. For, one gains long life, cherished offspring, and unending wealth through conduct; and it is conduct that defines what is worthy and unworthy.

sloka: sarvalakṣaṇahīno'pi yaḥ sadācāravānnaraḥ | śraddadhāno'nasūyaśca śataṃ varṣāṇi jīvati durācāro hi puruṣo loke bhavati ninditaḥ | duḥkhabhāgī ca satataṃ vyādhito'lpāyureva ca
translation: Even if one is devoid of all distinguishing marks, but behaves righteously and is a man of character, they live for a hundred years, dispelling doubts, free from envy. However, a man who is immoral in this world is reviled and subject to constant suffering, always sickly, and short-lived.

sloka: na pāṇipādacapalo na netracapalo'nṛjuḥ | na syādvākcapalaścaiva na paradrohakarmadhīḥ yenāsya pitaro yātā yena yātāḥ pitāmahāḥ | tena yāyātsatāṃ mārgaṃ tena gacchanna riṣyati vairiṇaṃ nopaseveta sahāyaṃ caiva vairiṇaḥ | adhārmikaṃ taskaraṃ ca parasyaiva ca yoṣitam | na hīdṛśaṃ anāyuṣyaṃ loke kiṃ cana vidyate | yādṛśaṃ puruṣasyeha paradāropasevanam |
translation: One who is not unsteady in hands and feet, not a deceiver with eyes and words, not given to violent or harmful actions, nor engages in calumny against others; the one whose ancestors have departed by that path, and so too have his great-grandfathers. Let him follow that path, for he will be ushered thereon. He should not associate with or serve a wicked thief or another's wife. Such conduct does not exist elsewhere in the world. How can one engage in such misconduct with another person?

sloka: maṅgalācārayuktānāṃ nityaṃ ca prayatātmanām | japatāṃ juhvatāṃ caiva vinipāto na vidyate
translation: For those devoted to auspicious conduct and always self-engrossed, as well as those who engage in recitation and offering rituals, there is never a downfall.

sloka: dṛḍhakārī mṛdurdāntaḥ krūrācārairasaṃvasan | ahiṃsro damadānābhyāṃ jayetsvargaṃ tathāvrataḥ
translation: Endowed with steadfastness and mildness, one who avoids the company of cruel behavior, who is harmless and practices self-control and charity, shall win the heavenly abode.

sloka: anena vipro vṛttena vartayanvedaśāstravit | vyapetakalmaṣo nityaṃ brahmaloke mahīyate
translation: By this conduct, the brahmin, well-versed in Vedic scriptures and rid of all blemishes, consistently attains greatness in the abode of Brahma.

sloka: sākṣāt mokṣasādhanāni imāni ātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyo mantavyo nididhyāsitavyaḥ | bṛhadāraṇyakopaniṣat
translation: These means to liberation should be directly seen, heard, contemplated, and assiduously meditated upon; they are to be considered and understood in the Brhadaranyaka Upanishad.

sloka: kaṇādena tu saṃproktaṃ śāstraṃ vaiśeṣikaṃ mahat | gautamena tathā nyāyaṃ sāṃkhyaṃ tu kapilena vai ||
translation: Kaṇāda, hear now of the distinguished vaiśeṣika śāstra proclaimed [by me]. Also, Gautama has explained nyāya, and Kapila has [explained] sāṃkhya.

sloka: prajāvatā vacasā vahnirāsā ca huve ni ca satsīha devaiḥ | veṣi hotramuta potraṃ yajatra bodhi prayantarjanitarvasūnām ||
translation: With progeny-related speech, the fire god, along with his wife, adorns the role of priest at sacrifices for the Devas, urging on as the protector of offspring.

sloka: yo adhvareṣu śaṃtama ṛtāvā hotā tamū namobhirā kṛṇudhvam | agniryadvermartāya devānsa cā bodhāti manasā yajāti ||
translation: The one who is the foremost among those performing sacrifices, you all should honor him with reverences. For, he indeed awakens the gods in the mind of the performer during the fire-ritual known as 'Agni Marta'.

sloka: abhi tvā gotamā girā jātavedo vicarṣaṇe dayumnairabhi para ṇonumaḥ jātavedase sunavā masomamarātīyato ni dahāti vedaḥ sa naḥ parṣadati durgāṇi viśvā nāveva sindhuṃ duritātyagniḥ agnirasmi janmanā jātavedā ghartaṃ me cakṣuramṛtaṃ ma āsana arkastridhātū rajaso vimānoajasro gharmo havirasmi nāma
translation: Approaching you, oh Gotama, with kind words, Jatavedas, I urge you to recite the Vedic hymns, to ignite the fire that illuminates and dispels all unrighteousness for us. You are the fire born of creation, Jatavedas, my eye, immortal and shining, source of heat. You are the sun, the threefold light, the life force in all beings, the oblation; I know you by name.

sloka: hotāraṃ viśvavedasaṃ saṃ hi tvā viśa indhate | sa ā vaha puruhūta pracetaso 'gne devā~ iha dravat ||
translation: The Hotr of the universal Veda, indeed, for you Indra, does Agni invoke the brilliant and inspired gods here; they rush to this place.

sloka: jarābodha tadviviḍḍhi viśeviśe yajñiyāya stomaṃ rudrāya dṛśikam
translation: "O cognizer of the impermanence, make an offering through the ritual hymn to Rudra, who is to be honored with the oblation."

sloka: tvamagnerudro asuro maho divastvaṃ śardho mārutaṃ pṛkṣa īśiṣe
translation: You, Agni's enemy, are the mighty asura, occupying the divine realm. What a great share of the wind you have been given!

sloka: sa eva puruṣaḥ prajāpatirabhavat sa yaḥ sa puruṣaḥ prajāpatirabhavat ayameva saḥ yo'yamagniścīyate kāṇḍikā
translation: It was indeed that very Purusha who became the Prajapati, and it is he again who is now becoming manifest as this very Agni, named Kandika.

sloka: tataḥ yaḥ jātagarbhaḥ saḥ agniḥ asṛjyata tasmāt sarvasya sthūlaprapañcasya agram ādau sṛṣṭatvāt agnirityucyate tam agrim idānīntanā agnināmnā vyavahāraṃ kurvanti kāṇḍikā
translation: From that emerged the fire, known as Agni, who was born from the womb and was the first to create the gross physical world. They now conduct their interactions using the name "Agni" for this fire, as referred to in the Kāṇḍikā text.

sloka: vāyuranilamamṛtamathedaṃ bhasmāntam śarīram | oṃ krato smara kṛtam smara krato smara kṛtam smara ||
translation: "O Vāyu, as the imperishable animating force, have you not saturated this perishable body with the divine essence of immortality? O Krato, remember, I entreat you, the deeds done."

sloka: agne naya supathā rāye asmānviśvāni deva vayunāni vidvān | yuyodhyasmajjuhurāṇameno bhūyiṣṭhāṃ te nama uktiṃ vidhema ||
translation: "Agni, leader, guide us along the right path, as we seek success. You know all the worlds, O gods. May we overcome obstacles and gain the highest good. To you, our obeisance."

sloka: te'gnimabruvan jātaveda etadvijānīhi kimetadyakṣamiti tatheti ||
translation: They, addressing the fire-god Agni, asked: "Reveal what this mysterious thing is." He responded: "I will tell you." (Referring to the offering being made to the fire)

sloka: tadabhyadravattamabhyavadat ko'sītyagnirvā ahamasmītyabravījjātavedā vā ahamasmīti ||
translation: To that (tat) he approached and said, "Who are you?" In response, Agni said, "It is I," while the other, becoming manifest, declared, "I am the Vedas."

sloka: tasmiṃstvayi kiṃ vīryamityapīdaṃ sarvaṃ daheyaṃ yadidaṃ pṛthivyāmiti ||
translation: In you, what excellence (or strength) is this? Everything here on earth must be offered. Such is my determination.

sloka: tasmai tṛṇaṃ nidadhāvetaddaheti tadupapreyāya sarvajavena tanna śaśāka dagdhum | sa tata evanivavṛte naitadaśakaṃ vijñātuṃ yadetadyakṣamiti ||
translation: To him, they should lay the grass; "Burn this!" they say, as an appropriate offering. But even he, that powerful being, could not be consumed by it. Thus, he enveloped (the fire) there itself, unable to comprehend that it was only a mere ten fingers' (width).

sloka: pra te bravīmi tadu me nibodha svargyamagniṃ naciketaḥ prajānan | anantalokāptimatho pratiṣṭhāṃ viddhi tvametaṃ nihitaṃ guhāyām || ||
translation: To you, I speak of this that you should understand, Naciketa. The fire that leads to the heavenly world , learn that is established through the limitless progeny . Indeed, it is set in the hidden .

sloka: lokādimagniṃ tamuvāca tasmai yā iṣṭakā yāvatīrvā yathā vā | sa cāpi tatpratyavadadyathoktaṃ athāsya mṛtyuḥ punarevāha tuṣṭaḥ ||
translation: The foremost in the world, addressing that agni, spoke to him: "Whatever offerings you desire, as many as they may be, presented in whatever way" - he responded to this; his death satisfied, it came again.

sloka: sa etaṃ devayānaṃ panthānamāpadyāgnilokamāgacchatisa vāyulokaṃ sa ādityalokaṃ
translation: He approaches this path, the divine way, named "Agni's realm," and she, the air and the sun.

sloka: yasyāgnihotramadarśamapaurṇamāsamacāturmāsyamanāgrayaṇamatithivarjitaṃ ca ahutamavaiśvadevamavidhinā hutamāsasaptamāṃ stasya lokānhinasti
translation: Of whom the new and full moon fire sacrifices, the beginning of each season's sacrifice, and the fortnightly sacrifices, excluding the animal sacrifice, conducted as per injunction, are absent, their worlds cease to exist.

sloka: agnimīl̤e purohitaṃ yajñasya devamṛtvijam | hotāraṃ ratnadhātamam ||
translation: The fire-god, as the priest of the sacrifice, the divine one honored with ritual offerings, the most excellent sacrificer, and the bestower of riches.

sloka: śākalyaseya śataṃ śiṣyā naiṣṭhikabrahmacāriṇaḥ pañca teṣāṃ gṛhasthāste dharmaniṣṭhāśca kuṭumbinaḥ śiśiro vāṣkalo sāṃkhyo vātsyaścaivāśvalāyanaḥ pañcaite śākalāḥ śiṣyāḥ śākhābhedapravarttakāḥ
translation: The five disciples of Śākalyaseya will, in the future, become a hundred devoted students, steadfast in their respective duties as householders and heads of families. They are Śiśira, Vātsya, and the one known as Āśvalāyana, who initiated the branch divisions. These five disciples of Śākalyaseya will become leaders of those branches.

sloka: ādityānīmāni śuklāni yajūṃṣi vājasaneyena yājñavalkyenākhyāyante
translation: These bright yajus hymns, referred to as the Vājasaneya and Yājñavalkya, are being recited by Āditya.

sloka: tallakṣaṇamāha jaiminiḥ gīteṣusāmākhyā iti gīyamāneṣu mantreṣu sāmasaṃjñetyarthaḥ iti
translation: Jaimini, having described the characteristic, states that in the hymns being sung, it is known as "sama" (a type of Vedic hymn). This is the meaning.

sloka: sā cāmaśceti tatsāmnaḥ sāmatvam |
translation: She, along with āma, embodies equality.

sloka: sahastravartmā sāmavedaḥ
translation: The path of the Sama Veda.

sloka: ‘karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: "The Brāhmaṇa's actions are instigators (of spiritual growth)."

sloka: araṇye'dhīyūrān
translation: The two having taken up the protection in the wilderness.

sloka: kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti || mṛtyave tvā dadāmīti ||
translation: To whom should I give myself, or to death should I give you?

sloka: svāntaḥprāṇākṣivāṇīprabhṛti ca viṣayābhāsakaṃ yasya yogād yanna prāpnoti caitadviditaṃ yadbhavennātmarūpam| indrādyā devamukhyā api kila na viduryasya śaktiṃ nigūḍhāṃ tadbuddhaṃ yena so'sau bhavati naravaro'nantasaukhyapratiṣṭhaḥ ||
translation: The one whose inner self has experienced the perfect control over the life-force and has seen the manifestation of objects, who has not attained this understanding through yoga, is understood to be the true form of oneself. Even great beings like Indra and other leading deities are said to have not fathomed the hidden power of that enlightened one, who becomes the source of limitless happiness for humans.

sloka: vaiśvānaraḥ praviśati atithirbrāhmaṇo gṛhān | tasyaitā~ śāntiṃ kurvanti hara vaivasvatodakam ||
translation: The all-pervading fire (Agni) enters as a guest into the Brahmin's home. They make him peaceful by offering him the oblation of water from Vaivasvat's (the sun's) portion.

sloka: ki~svidyamasya kartavyaṃ yanmayā'dya kariṣyati ||
translation: What is the task to be done, which I should accomplish today?

sloka: tamabravītprīyamāṇo mahātmā varaṃ tavehādya dadāmi bhūyaḥ | tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa ||
translation: The exalted one, pleased, said to him, "I give you an additional boon today. You will become famous by my name. Take this form that has many aspects. Embrace it."

sloka: yeyaṃ prete vicikitsā manuṣye astītyeke nāyamastīti caike | etadvidyāmanuśiṣṭastvayā'haṃ varāṇāmeṣa varastṛtīyaḥ ||
translation: Of the two opinions about a deceased person - "she exists" and "she does not exist" - he who has studied this discipline of knowledge knows the truth; I, having studied it, am the third choice among the desirable options.

sloka: yasminnidaṃ vicikitsanti mṛtyo yatsāmparāye mahati brūhi nastat | yo'yaṃ varo gūḍhamanupraviṣṭo nānyaṃ tasmānnaciketā vṛṇīte ||
translation: In which is this being doubted ; as death approaches this great crisis , tell us that . Who is this excellence , secretly entered ? Therefore , let Naciketā not choose any other .

sloka: naiva vācā na manasā prāptuṃ śakyo na cakṣuṣā | astīti bruvato'nyatra kathaṃ tadupalabhyate ||
translation: It cannot be grasped through speech, mind, or sight, they say. But how is it accessible elsewhere?

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū | brahmajajñaṃ devamīḍyaṃ viditvā nicāyya mā~ śāntimatyantameti ||
translation: Having fully understood the deity Brahmajajña, who is to be known as īḍya, and after reflecting on the three actions that Triṇāciketa performs with the help of the three fires, one transcends birth and death; thus, do not disturb my peace.

sloka: triṇāciketastrayametadviditvā ya evaṃ vidvā~ ścinute nāciketam | sa mṛtyupāśānpurataḥ praṇodya śokātigo modate svargaloke ||
translation: Having understood the three-footed fire, if one truly knows and recites 'Atharvaveda, Nahkayaniya section, Naciketopakhyana' (i.e., the story of Naciketa), they will rejoice in the heavenly world, freed from the proximity of death and sorrow.

sloka: nehetārthānprasaṅgena na viruddhena karmaṇā | na vidyamāneṣvartheṣu nārtyāṃ api yatastataḥ indriyārtheṣu sarveṣu na prasajyeta kāmataḥ | atiprasaktiṃ caiteṣāṃ manasā saṃnivartayet
translation: Let not one, endowed with reason, engage in actions conflicting with or opposed to the pursuit of these goals. Nor should he become overwhelmed by desire when engaging with the senses in various activities. He should, instead, exercise restraint over his own mind and prevent it from becoming excessively attached (to such pursuits).

sloka: pratigrahasamartho'pi prasaṅgaṃ tatra varjayet | pratigraheṇa hyasyāśu brāhmaṃ tejaḥ praśāmyati naitādṛśaḥ paro dharmo nṛṇāṃ saddharmamicchatām nyāso daṇḍasya bhūteṣu manovākkāyajasya yaḥ
translation: Although capable of accepting gifts, he should refrain from unnecessary involvement there. Such acceptance quickly diminishes the Brahmin's spiritual power and is not in line with the righteous path for people pursuing the highest virtue. The assignment of punishment to beings, resulting from their actions through mind, speech, and body, is what he is.

sloka: parasya daṇḍaṃ nodyacchetkruddho nainaṃ nipātayet | anyatra putrācchiṣyādvā śiṣṭyarthaṃ tāḍayettu tau brāhmaṇāyāvaguryaiva dvijātirvadhakāmyayā | śataṃ varṣāṇi tāmisre narake parivartate tāḍayitvā tṛṇenāpi saṃrambhānmatipūrvakam | ekaviṃśatīṃ ājātīḥ pāpayoniṣu jāyate
translation: The brāhmaṇa, seeking to carry out the punishment, shouldn't wield the rod of another in anger or throw it. Instead, he should cause a son to learn for the sake of discipline, or gently chastise others outside. If he punishes with a rod even slightly, he will revolve in a foul hell for a hundred years. After striking and killing two hundred sixteen creatures born from sinful wombs, he becomes subject to being struck himself.

sloka: ayudhyamānasyotpādya brāhmaṇasyāsṛgaṅgataḥ | duḥkhaṃ sumahadāpnoti pretyāprājñatayā naraḥ śoṇitaṃ yāvataḥ pāṃsūnsaṃgṛhṇāti mahītalāt | tāvato'bdānamutrānyaiḥ śoṇitotpādako'dyate na kadā ciddvije tasmādvidvānavaguredapi | na tāḍayettṛṇenāpi na gātrātsrāvayedasṛk
translation: While preparing the sacrificial fire for a Brahmin who is engaged in duties, a person does not experience great suffering after death due to ignorance. The person only picks up as much soil as contained in a pāṃsūna (a handful) until his/her death, and an equivalent amount of sinful reactions are generated. However, one should never strike with grass or cause bodily effusion, even in the case of a knower of this truth, what to speak of others.

sloka: satyadharmāryavṛtteṣu śauce caivārametsadā | śiṣyāṃśca śiṣyāddharmeṇa vāgbāhūdarasaṃyataḥ parityajedarthakāmau yau syātāṃ dharmavarjitau | dharmaṃ cāpyasukhodarkaṃ lokasaṃkruṣṭaṃ eva ca
translation: In the pursuit of truth and righteousness, if someone becomes pure in conduct, composed in speech, arms, and stomach, and discards material desires, even if they forsake righteousness itself, which is delightful, distressing to the world, and associated with happiness.

sloka: na sīdannapi dharmeṇa mano'dharme niveśayet | adhārmikānāṃ pāpānāṃ āśu paśyanviparyayam
translation: Even if the mind is not settling in its duty, it should not be made to settle in spiritual pursuits against its will. Quickly perceiving the reversal of values among the immoral, one should recognize their sins.

sloka: bhadraṃ bhadraṃ iti brūyādbhadraṃ ityeva vā vadet | śuṣkavairaṃ vivādaṃ ca na kuryātkena citsaha
translation: Speak auspiciousness, speak it indeed; or even simply express it. One should not engage in a petty feud. What for? Together with awareness.

sloka: yadyatparavaśaṃ karma tattadyatnena varjayet | yadyadātmavaśaṃ tu syāttattatseveta yatnataḥ yatkarma kurvato'sya syātparitoṣo'ntarātmanaḥ | tatprayatnena kurvīta viparītaṃ tu varjayet
translation: Perform the actions that you cannot avoid with deliberate effort, and abandon those that can be avoided. Seek to serve one's own self in all ways possible; this brings inner satisfaction. Do what needs to be done with diligence, and reject what should not be done with caution.

sloka: śraddhayeṣṭaṃ ca pūrtaṃ ca nityaṃ kuryādatandritaḥ | śraddhākṛte hyakṣaye te bhavataḥ svāgatairdhanaiḥ dānadharmaṃ niṣeveta nityaṃ aiṣṭikapaurtikam | parituṣṭena bhāvena pātraṃ āsādya śaktitaḥ
translation: The one who is devoted should always make an effort to fulfill and complete (his) duties with steadfastness. For, the fortune amassed from such dutiful actions leads to the growth of faith. With a content heart, one should always partake in charity, following the scriptural path of both Aishṭika and Paurtika. Having approached the worthy recipient, one should establish (the charity) with power and ability.

sloka: yatkiṃ cidapi dātavyaṃ yācitenānasūyayā | utpatsyate hi tatpātraṃ yattārayati sarvataḥ sarveṣāṃ eva dānānāṃ brahmadānaṃ viśiṣyate | vāryannagomahīvāsas tilakāñcanasarpiṣām
translation: Whatever needs to be given, whether it is something or nothing, when requested without arrogance, its recipient is indeed the one who accepts it wholeheartedly from all sides. Among all gifts, the gift of knowledge is considered the most excellent; likewise, a person who is pure, wearing white clothes and adorned with sacred marks made of sandalwood and gold is superior.

sloka: yena yena tu bhāvena yadyaddānaṃ prayacchati | tattattenaiva bhāvena prāpnoti pratipūjitaḥ yo'rcitaṃ pratigṛhṇāti dadātyarcitaṃ eva vā | tāvubhau gacchataḥ svargaṃ narakaṃ tu viparyaye
translation: By whatever mental state one gives away something, by that same state he attains respect and acceptance. He who accepts what has been ritually offered or gives with respect, will reach the abode of heaven or hell based on whether his action is done rightly or wrongly.

sloka: yajño'nṛtena kṣarati tapaḥ kṣarati vismayāt | āyurviprāpavādena dānaṃ ca parikīrtanāt
translation: The yajña (sacrifice) flourishes through proper conduct, and austerity does so through wonder. Longevity and priesthood are enhanced by praiseworthy giving.

sloka: dharmarājaḥ pitṛpatiḥ samavartī paretarāṭ kṛtānto yamunābhrātā śamano yamarāḍ yamaḥ kālo daṇḍadharaḥ śrādhdadevo vaivasvatontakaḥ
translation: The upholder of dharma, the lord of ancestors, associated with the Yamunā brother, the tamer of the wild, the one who has completed his duties, the god Shraddhadeva, and Vaivasvatontaka are all names of Yama, the deity of death who carries the staff as the controller of time.

sloka: yacchati upa ramayati jivitam sarvam bhuta graman iti yamaha
translation: The one who grants life and makes all beings delight is known as Yama.

sloka: yathā candraśca rohiṇyāmurmilāyāṃ dhaneśvaraḥ|| yatra rājā vaivasvato yatrāvarodhanaṃ divaḥ yatrāmūryahvatīrāpastatra māmamṛtaṃ kṛdhīndrāyendo pari srava
translation:
Just as the moon blends with Rohini and the lord of riches shines,
Where the king Vaivasvata is, where the dividing line of day and night is,
Where the dawn and sunset occur, there make me immortal, O Indra, along with your flow.

sloka: naciketamupākhyānaṃ mṛtyuproktaṃ sanātanam
translation: The timeless narrative known as "Naciketa" has been spoken about by Death.

sloka: ati drava sārameyau śvānau caturakṣau śabalau sādhunā pathā athā pitṝntsuvidatrānupehi yamena ye sadhamādaṃ madanti
translation: With a sincere heart, make the swift-running pair of dogs (who are) strongly built follow the path with righteousness, and let them enjoy the offered share that comes from the two (offerings) with the help of Yamaha.

sloka: dharati lokān dhriyate puṇyātmabhiriti vā |
translation: The earth supports the worlds and is itself supported by the virtuous through their actions, or perhaps in another way.

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ |
translation: The highest duty is proper conduct.

sloka: maitraṃ prasādhanaṃ snānaṃ dantadhāvanaṃ añjanam | pūrvāhṇa eva kurvīta devatānāṃ ca pūjanam dūrādāvasathānmūtraṃ dūrātpādāvasecanam | ucchiṣṭānnaniṣekaṃ ca dūrādeva samācaret udvartanaṃ apasnānaṃ viṇmūtre raktaṃ eva ca | śleśmaniṣṭhyūtavāntāni nādhitiṣṭhettu kāmataḥ
translation: In the morning, one should make an offering, bathe, clean the teeth, and apply collyrium. Worship the gods in a distant place, and urinate and defecate there as well. Perform the rites of sipping water and cleaning the mouth, and eat food that is not offered to the gods. Massage the body with oil, and bathe in water that is colored red (with turmeric or saffron). Avoid being lazy about applying ointments and other treatments for good health.

sloka: nānnaṃ adyādekavāsā na nagnaḥ snānaṃ ācaret | na mūtraṃ pathi kurvīta na bhasmani na govraje nāpsu mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ vā ṣṭhīvanaṃ vā samutsṛjet | amedhyaliptaṃ anyadvā lohitaṃ vā viṣāṇi vā
translation: Let none wear only one cloth today, nor go naked; let him not perform ablutions, nor relieve himself on a path or in ash, a cattle pen, or in water, nor emit feces or urine or flatulence. Let nothing anointed with impure substances, reddish or emitting fumes be used.

sloka: na pādau dhāvayetkāṃsye kadā cidapi bhājane | na bhinnabhāṇḍe bhuñjīta na bhāvapratidūṣite upānahau ca vāsaśca dhṛtaṃ anyairna dhārayet | upavītaṃ alaṅkāraṃ srajaṃ karakaṃ eva ca
translation: Never should one swiftly step on a pair of shoes, at any time or place; nor eat from a broken pot; never wear garments that have been contaminated or are used by others. Always wear the sacred thread, an upper cloth, and keep the tuft of hair neatly tied, as these are the essential marks of a dignified person.

sloka: na saṃhatābhyāṃ pāṇibhyāṃ kaṇḍūyedātmanaḥ śiraḥ | na spṛśeccaitaducchiṣṭo na ca snāyādvinā tataḥ nadīṣu devakhāteṣu taḍāgeṣu saraḥsu ca | snānaṃ samācarennityaṃ gartaprasravaṇeṣu ca
translation: Let him not scratch his own head with joined hands, nor touch this impure one. Let him not bathe in rivers and ponds other than those consecrated, but rather perform his ablutions daily in a secluded spot or a pit dug for the purpose.

sloka: adhastānnopadadhyācca na cainaṃ abhilaṅghayet | na cainaṃ pādataḥ kuryānna prāṇābādhaṃ ācaret na vārayedgāṃ dhayantīṃ na cācakṣīta kasya cit || gavāṃ ca yānaṃ pṛṣṭhena sarvathaiva vigarhitam
translation: "Let him not be made to lie down or taught below, nor let anyone touch him. Let him not cause any hindrance to his breath or prevent the milking cow. Let him not look at or reveal this one being cared for by someone. What wise man would allow such actions towards this being's transportation on the back of a cow?"

sloka: hīnāṅgānatiriktāṅgānvidyāhīnānvayo'dhikān | rūpadraviṇahīnāṃśca jātihīnāṃśca nākṣipet abhivādayedvṛddhāṃśca dadyāccaivāsanaṃ svakam | kṛtāñjalirupāsīta gacchataḥ pṛṣṭhato'nviyāt
translation: Don't cast aside, cause to approach, or offer respect to those who are deprived of physical strength, knowledge, proper conduct, wealth, or lineage. Instead, show them respect and provide them with their necessary seat. One should go, having first paid obeisance, and then follow behind, leaving (them) in front (while departing).

sloka: ṛtvikpurohitācāryairmātulātithisaṃśritaiḥ | bālavṛddhāturairvaidyairjñātisaṃbandhibāndhavaiḥ ākāśeśāstu vijñeyā bālavṛddhakṛśāturāḥ | bhrātā jyeṣṭhaḥ samaḥ pitrā bhāryā putraḥ svakā tanuḥ chāyā svo dāsavargaśca duhitā kṛpaṇaṃ param | tasmādetairadhikṣiptaḥ sahetāsaṃjvaraḥ sadā
translation: By the priests, teachers, elderly relatives, and family friends who are here as guests, as well as by physicians of all ages, you should always be known in the sky as "the one who possesses balance." You are the elder brother, equal to the father, wife, son, personal self, shadow, servants, and also the daughter. Therefore, with these (thoughts), always afflicted, you should be directed.

sloka: ācāryaṃ ca pravaktāraṃ pitaraṃ mātaraṃ gurum | na hiṃsyādbrāhmaṇāngāśca sarvāṃścaiva tapasvinaḥ na kurvīta vṛthāceṣṭāṃ na vāryañjalinā pibet | notsaṅge bhakṣayedbhakṣyānna jātu syātkutūhalī |
translation: Respect the teacher, the one who introduced this to you, the father, the mother, and the spiritual guide. Never should you harm the brahmins or ascetics, nor do anything useless. Do not drink water with your hands folded in a gesture of respect without offering it to others. Never eat food alone; share it with others. Never become overly eager or curious.

sloka: nākṣairdīvyetkadā cittu svayaṃ nopānahau haret | śayanastho na bhuñjīta na pāṇisthaṃ na cāsane | ārdrapādastu bhuñjīta nārdrapādastu saṃviśet | ārdrapādastu bhuñjāno dīrghaṃ āyuravāpnuyāt |
translation: Let him never be illuminated by stars, when will he ever shine on his own? Let him not take up women, let him lie down and not eat while seated. Let him eat only when his feet are wet, and let him enter the waters only with wet feet. Let him, eating while his feet are wet, attain long life.

sloka: na snānaṃ ācaredbhuktvā nāturo na mahāniśi | na vāsobhiḥ sahājasraṃ nāvijñāte jalāśaye mattakruddhāturāṇāṃ ca na bhuñjīta kadā cana | keśakīṭāvapannaṃ ca padā spṛṣṭaṃ ca kāmataḥ
translation: Never should one who seeks purification conduct a ritual bath after being afflicted, nor partake in grand feasts at night with company or indulge in eating meat from any animal drowned in water or killed in rage, and never should one deliberately touch a dog or a bird.

sloka: nekṣetodyantaṃ ādityaṃ nāstaṃ yāntaṃ kadā cana | nopasṛṣṭaṃ na vāristhaṃ na madhyaṃ nabhaso gatam na laṅghayedvatsatantrīṃ na pradhāvecca varṣati | na codake nirīkṣeta svarūpaṃ iti dhāraṇā
translation: Never can the sun's movement in its course, ending or beginning, be seen at any time. Neither has it ever swerved aside, nor been surpassed, nor touched the middle of the sky. It doesn't cause rainfall, nor does it look at its own form in water. Such is the belief.

sloka: nādharmike vasedgrāme na vyādhibahule bhṛśam | naikaḥ prapadyetādhvānaṃ na ciraṃ parvate vaset bālātapaḥ pretadhūmo varjyaṃ bhinnaṃ tathāsanam | na chindyānnakharomāṇi dantairnotpāṭayennakhān
translation: In an irreligious settlement, one should not dwell excessively amidst diseases; nor should a single person take to the road for long; nor should one reside on a mountain for too long in the heat of summer. Smoke, the product of fire, is to be avoided, as are the breaking of sandals and cutting of nails with teeth or hands.

sloka: na mṛlloṣṭhaṃ ca mṛdnīyānna chindyātkarajaistṛṇam | na karma niṣphalaṃ kuryānnāyatyāṃ asukhodayam advāreṇa ca nātīyādgrāmaṃ vā veśma vāvṛtam | rātrau ca vṛkṣamūlāni dūrataḥ parivarjayet
translation: One should not lightly touch the earth or cause it to be cut with a plow; one should not make straw or pointless actions. One should not, in the late afternoon, step over nor too closely approach a village, house, or enclosed space. At night, one should keep away from tree roots, even distant ones.

sloka: acakṣurviṣayaṃ durgaṃ na prapadyeta karhi cit | na viṇmūtraṃ udīkṣeta na bāhubhyāṃ nadīṃ taret adhitiṣṭhenna keśāṃstu na bhasmāsthikapālikāḥ | na kārpāsāsthi na tuṣāndīrghaṃ āyurjijīviṣuḥ
translation: Never should one seek to behold a forbidden object, nor gaze at another's urine, nor cross a river using arms. One should never set foot on another's hair or hold even a particle of ash or bone from another's funeral pyre. Nor should one desire a long life consuming the five sense objects.

sloka: keśagrahānprahārāṃśca śirasyetānvivarjayet | śiraḥsnātaśca tailena nāṅgaṃ kiṃ cidapi spṛśet devatānāṃ guro rājñaḥ snātakācāryayostathā | nākrāmetkāmataśchāyāṃ babhruṇo dīkṣitasya ca
translation: Let the officiant, having bathed and anointed with oil his locks and these (objects to be offered), avoid striking their (the offerings') tops; let him not touch any part of his body before worshiping the deities, the teacher, the king, and the initiated. Nor should he move about recklessly in the shadow of the sacrificial fire or of a brown-skinned person consecrated for a sacrifice.

sloka: kṣatriyaṃ caiva sarpaṃ ca brāhmaṇaṃ ca bahuśrutam | nāvamanyeta vai bhūṣṇuḥ kṛśānapi kadā cana nātmānaṃ avamanyeta purvābhirasamṛddhibhiḥ | ā mṛtyoḥ śriyaṃ anvicchennaināṃ manyeta durlabhām
translation: Treat a ruler, a serpent, and a learned brahmin as worthy of respect. Adual, never underestimate oneself, even if physically weak. Even the past-rich ancestors should not belittle this prosperity. Seek after fortune **as** something hard to obtain, approaching death.

sloka: dharmaṃ śanaiḥ saṃcinuyādvalmīkaṃ iva puttikāḥ | paralokasahāyārthaṃ sarvabhūtānyapīḍayan dṛḍhakārī mṛdurdāntaḥ krūrācārairasaṃvasan | ahiṃsro damadānābhyāṃ jayetsvargaṃ tathāvrataḥ
translation: Let him establish the dharma gradually, like a plant growing slowly. Like nurturing friends for future benefit, he should treat all beings without causing them distress, firm in his conduct, gentle and restrained, avoiding cruel behavior. Through non-violence and self-control, he shall win heaven.

sloka: maṅgalācārayuktaḥ syātprayatātmā jitendriyaḥ | japecca juhuyāccaiva nityaṃ agniṃ atandritaḥ vedābhyāsena satataṃ śaucena tapasaiva ca | adroheṇa ca bhūtānāṃ jātiṃ smarati paurvikīm paurvikīṃ saṃsmaranjātiṃ brahmaivābhyasyate punaḥ | brahmābhyāsena cājasraṃ anantaṃ sukhaṃ aśnute
translation: Let one be combined with auspicious conduct, be resolved in his mind, and have mastery over his senses. Let him recite and offer oblations to the fire continuously, being ever steadfast in the practice of daily studying the scriptures, cleanliness, and austerities. Ever mindful of the primary creation of all beings, he constantly deepens his meditation on it. Through ceaseless practice of understanding Brahman, he partakes in boundless bliss.

sloka: anena vipro vṛttena vartayanvedaśāstravit | vyapetakalmaṣo nityaṃ brahmaloke mahīyate
translation: With this conduct, the brahmin, well-versed in the Vedic scriptures and free from defects, consistently attains greatness in the world of Brahma.

sloka: ye vai brāhmaṇāḥ śuśruvāṃso'nūcānāste viprāstānevaitadabhyāha
translation: "Indeed, O brahmins who have listened before, if you (singular) will be taught by them (dual) in this way."

sloka: agnyādheyaṃ pākayajñānagniṣṭomādikānmakhān | yaḥ karoti vṛto yasya sa tasya rtvigihocyate ||
translation: The one who performs the agnyadheya and other fire rituals such as pakayajnas, agnistomas, and so on, is considered the priest of that person whose (rituals) are protected.

sloka: iha hi dravyaṃ pañcamahābhūtātmakam |
translation: Indeed, here the substance is made up of the fifth element.

sloka: ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī |
translation: From space arises air, from air arises fire, from fire arises water, and from water arises earth.

sloka: tatra gandhavatī pṛthivī | sā dvividhā nityā'nityā ca | nityā paramāṇurūpā | anityā kāryarūpā | punastrividhā śarīrendriyaviṣayabhedāt |
translation: There, the earth is fragrant in two ways: one is eternally consisting of atoms, and the other is transient and forms of actions. Furthermore, it is threefold according to the distinction between body, senses, and objects of sense, due to its nature.

sloka: madhukaiṭabhayormedaḥ saṃyogānmedinī smṛtā | dhāraṇācca dharā proktā pṛthvī vistārayogataḥ || mahī cāpi mahīyas |
translation: The union of madhu and kaitabha, remembered as medini, is known as dharana, and the holding (or maintenance) of it is called dharā, derived from the action of spreading out the earth. Similarly, mahi is distinguished by its greatness.

sloka: athāgamya mahārājannamaskṛtyi ca kaśyapam | pṛthavī kāśyapī jajñe sutā tasya mahātmanaḥ ||
translation: After approaching the great king Kaśyapa and paying obeisance to him, the earth gave birth to his great-souled offspring.

sloka: prathate vistāraṃ yātīti pṛthivī | pṛthvī sthūlatvaguṇayuktā | pṛthorduhitṛtvasvīkārādetannāma |
translation: The earth expands and manifests as "prithivi," being endowed with the quality of solidity, deriving its name from being the daughter of Prithu.

sloka: duhitṛtvaṅgatā yasmāt pṛthaurdharmmavato mahī| tadānurāgayogācca pṛthivī viśrutā budhaiḥ||
translation: The earth, renowned among the wise, is characterized by primary qualities due to attachment stemming from being daughter-born from him (i.e., the sky).

sloka: gataprāṇau tadā jātau dānavau madhukaiṭabhau | sāgaraḥ sakalo vyāptastadā vai medasā tayoḥ || medinīti tato jātaṃ nāma pṛthvyāḥ samantataḥ |
translation: At that time, the two asuras had been deprived of their life force . The entire ocean became filled with their oil-like substance after their fall. Then, the name 'earth' was given to what had arisen .

sloka: evaṃ sarvaṃ kṛtrimaṃ ca bāhyābhyantarameva ca ||tadvināśe vināśaśca sarveṣāmeva nārada | jalabud‌budavatsarvaṃ viśvasaṃghamanityakam ||
translation: "Indeed, with its perishable aspects, both external and internal, everything becomes annihilated when that is destroyed, as Narada says. It's like bubbles in water, unstable and transient."

sloka: dyaurme pitā janitā nābhiratra bandhurme mātā pṛthivī mahīyam |
translation: The sky is my father, the navel of the earth my mother, the universe here my bandhu (relative or friend); such is my conception of this earth.

sloka: viśvaṃbharā vasudhānī pratiṣṭhā hiraṇyavakṣā jagato niveśanī | vaiśvānaraṃ bibhratī bhūmiragnimindraṛṣabhā draviṇe no dadhātu ||
translation: Bearers of universal sustenance, earthly wealth, and firm foundation, may you who possess the golden garment and are known as Vaiśvānara, establish for us wealth in the form of bhūmi, agni, indra, and ṛṣabha.

sloka: yatte bhūme vikhanāmi kṣipraṃ tadapi rohatu | mā te marma vimṛgvari mā te hṛdayamarpipam ||
translation: "O earth, whatever I dig up quickly, may that swiftly grow back. Let not your secrets be known to him, nor let his heart become impure."

sloka: na vā araṇyānirhantyanyaścennābhigacchati |
translation: "Nor do those who have not conquered the forest (i.e., achieved spiritual victory) either approach (such a person), or go near."

sloka: iyaṃ pṛthivī sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ madhu | asyai pṛthivyai sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu |
translation: This earth, endowed with all beings' sap, pours it out for this earth; all beings' sap, poured into this earth.

sloka: saktuprasthena vo nāyaṃ yajñastulyo narādhipāḥ| uñchavṛttervadānyasya kurukṣetranivāsinaḥ||
translation: With sacrificial ingredients prepared by you, they will not be equal to even a single king, in terms of generosity towards those who reside in the Kuru field (i.e., the battlefield), characterized by piles of rice and grain.

sloka: dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre dharmajñairbahubhirvṛte| uñchavṛttirdvijaḥ kaścitkāpotirabhavattadā||
translation: In the field of righteousness, the Kuru field, has been manifested before by some twice-born one a grain-born growth and a cow's water-drawing ability.

sloka: athāgacchaddvijaḥ kaścidatithirbhuñjatāṃ tadā|| te taṃ dṛṣṭvātithiṃ prāptaṃ prahṛṣṭamanaso'bhavan| te'bhivādya sukhapraśnaṃ pṛṣṭvā tamatithiṃ tadā||
translation: Then a certain brahmin arrived. Some of them, seeing the arriving guest, became joyful. After respectfully greeting him and asking about his well-being, they spent that day with him.

sloka: ityuktā sā tataḥ prāha dharmārthau nau samau dvija|| saktuprasthacaturbhāgaṃ gṛhāṇemaṃ prasīda me| satyaṃ ratiśca dharmaśca svargaśca guṇanirjitaḥ||
translation: Having been spoken to thus, she replied, "O twice-born, duty and profit are indeed the same. Accept this fourfold share of sacrifice, I pray. Truth, passion, and duty, as well as heaven, are all conquered by virtue."

sloka: apatyamasmi te puṃsastrāṇātputra iti smṛtaḥ| ātmā putraḥ smṛtastasmāttrāhyātmānamihātmanā||
translation: I am the protector of the two sons, as is remembered. Therefore, one should consider the self as (his) son.

sloka: tava prasādānnirvṛttā mama lokāḥ kilākṣayāḥ| putreṇa tānavāpnoti yatra gatvā na śocati|| dharmādyo hi yathā tretā vahnitretā tathaiva ca| tathaiva putrapautrāṇāṃ svargastretā kilākṣayaḥ|| pitṝnṛṇāttārayati putra ityanuśuśruma| putrapautraiśca niyataṃ sādhulokānupāśnute||
translation: Through your favor, my worlds have been made invulnerable. A son, obtaining there (in those worlds), does not grieve when he goes. Just as in the age of Treta, dharma and the like were invulnerable, so also are the worlds of sons and grandsons invulnerable. We have heard that the son rescues the ancestors from debt. A grandson partakes of (the merits of) good deeds in this world in a fixed manner.

sloka: baṭ śrat satrā addhā itthā ṛtam iti satyasya
translation: "Affirming this very truth, oh friend, is the nature of that which is real."

sloka: ṛtasya hi śurudhaḥ santi pūrvīrṛtasya dhītirvṛjināni hanti | ṛtasya śloko badhirā tatarda karṇā budhānaḥ śucamāna āyoḥ || ṛtasya dṛl̤hā dharuṇāni santi purūṇi candrā vapuṣe vapūṃṣi | ṛtena dīrghamiṣaṇanta pṛkṣa ṛtena gāva ṛtamāviveśuḥ || ṛtaṃ yemāna ṛtamidvanotyṛtasya śuṣmasturayā u gavyuḥ | ṛtāya pṛthvī bahule gabhīre ṛtāya dhenū parame duhāte ||
translation: The ancients, steadfast in truth, indeed exist as the offspring of truth, repelling evils. A hymn is powerless before one established in truth; the wise ones' ears are deaf to it. The strong foundations of truth exist abundantly, spread out on the moon's surface. Cattle and beings have entered into the long-lasting and endless truth. "O earth, you contain and carry the essence of truth within your vast depths."

sloka: indriyam indraliṃgam indradṛṣṭamindraṛṣṭamindrauṣṭamindrāttaṃ iti vā |
translation: As an assistant, I will provide the enhanced translation for the given Sanskrit verse.

sloka: indro yātūnāmabhavatparāśaro havirmathīnāmabhyā vivāsatām abhīdu śakraḥ paraśuryathā vanaṃ pātreva bhindantsata eti rakṣasaḥ
translation: Indra, like Parashara among the yatu demons, became (their) chief; just as Shakra did with those offering sacrifices. Like a sharp weapon, he cuts through the forest (of his enemies) and approaches (to protect), even as a blade slices through a vessel. Such is how he treats the rakshasas.

sloka: akṛtvā pādayo: śaucaṃ diti: śayanamāviśat nidrāṃ cāhārayāmāsa tasyā: kukṣiṃ praviśya sa: vajrapāṇirmahāgarbhaṃ cicchedātha sa saptadhā sampīḍyamāno vajreṇa sa rurodātidāruṇam mā rodīriti taṃ śakra: puna:punarabhāṣata so'bhavatsaptadhā garbhastamiṃdra: kupita: puna: maruto nāma devāste babhūvurativeginaḥ | yaduktaṃ vai maghavatā tenaiva maruto'bhavan | devā ekonapañcāsat sahāyā vajrapāṇinaḥ ||
translation: Having not yet maintained cleanliness of feet, Indra entered the sleep of Diti and caused her to lie down, making her pregnant. Once Indra was enclosed within her womb, he split open the seven-fold embryo with his thunderbolt. When that highly terrifying one was being squeezed by the thunderbolt, Indra cried out in distress. Again and again, Indra spoke to him: "Do not cry!" Then, Indra himself became seven in the womb. The Maruts, named after the wind, were born from it, as previously spoken by Maghavat (Indra). Fifty gods, allies of Vajrapani (Indra), also came into being.

sloka: yaḥ pṛthavīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatāna prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who calms the agitated earth, soothes the enraged mountains, steadies the unsteady atmosphere, and showers mercy on all living beings is the Indra among men.

sloka: sa vajrabhṛd dasyuhā bhīma ugraḥ sahasracetāḥ śatanītha ṛbhvā camrīṣo na śavasā pāñcajanyo marutvān no bhavatvindra ūtī
translation: May the thunderbolt-wielding, terrifying and extremely brave leader of the enemies, who is accompanied by a thousand-minded ṛbhvā and holds the name Pāñcajanya, not become Indra's equal.

sloka: yo hatvāhimariṇāta sapta sindhūn yo gā udājadapadhā valasya yo aśmanorantaragniṃ jajāna saṃvṛk samatsu sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who, having vanquished the seven rivers, the cows, and the waters' source within the two stones (i.e., the polar mountains), gave birth to the fire residing in their midst, is indeed Indra, the enhancer of the people.

sloka: indrasyāṅagirasāṃ ceṣṭau vidat saramā tanayāya dhāsim bṛhaspatirbhinadadriṃ vidad gāḥ samusriyābhirvāvaśanta naraḥ evaṃ purā svānapi sodarān sa garbhasthitānujjarituṃ bhayārtaḥ| bibheda vajreṇa tataḥ sa gotrabhit khyāto
translation: In the past, Indra, with his efforts at Mount Aṅagiras, caused it to split for Saramā's son. Bṛhaspati made the cows retreat from the mountain using his powers. Similarly, a man, filled with fear, managed to split open the enclosure protecting his own relatives. With his thunderbolt, Indra then became widely known as one who has breached the enclosures of gotras (clans).

sloka: yo jāta eva prathamo manasvān devo devān kratunā paryabhūṣat yasya śuṣmād rodasī abhyasetāṃ nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who was born first and is most excellent among the intelligent beings, adorned the gods with his deeds. From him did the governance of the two worlds emerge. May he, the nourisher, along with the people, protect us; indeed, he is Indra.

sloka: prajāpatirindra masṛjatānujāvaraṃ devānām | taṃ prāhiṇot | parehi | eteṣāṃ devānāmadhipatiredhīti | taṃ devā abruvan | kastvamasi | vayaṃ vai tvacchreyā~ saḥ sma iti | so'bravīt | kastvamasi vayaṃ vai tvacchreyā~ saḥ sma iti mā devā avocanniti | ko ha vai nāma prajāpatiḥ | ya evaṃ veda vidurenaṃ nāmnā | tadasmai rukmaṃ kṛtvā pratyamuñcat | tato vā indro devānāmadhipatirabhavat | ya evaṃ veda |
translation: Prajapati, the progenitor, brought forth the sons of Ila. This (lordship) he offered to Indra among the gods. He asked them, "Who are you? We are indeed your subjects." To this, he (Indra) replied, "Who are you? We are indeed your subjects." Then a doubt arose in their minds, "What is the name of this Prajapati?" The one who knows the answer by the name 'Vidura' offers him gold and becomes the lord of wealth. Thus, Indra became the lord of the gods.

sloka: yaḥ parthivīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatān prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who soothes the agitated earth, calms the enraged mountains, shakes the atmosphere, and showers compassion is Indra for the people.

sloka: pūrvaṃ kṛtayuge tāta parvatāḥ pakṣiṇo'bhavan te hi jagmurdiśaḥ sarvā garuḍānilaveginaḥ
translation: In the previous age, father, mountains became birds that flew swiftly in all directions; indeed, they moved off to those (cardinal directions).

sloka: na nūnamasti no śvaḥ kastad veda yadadbhutam anyasya cittamabhi saṃcareṇyamutādhītaṃ vi naśyati
translation: Surely, there isn't now anyone in this world who knows the wondrous consciousness of another, for it is destroyed once revealed.

sloka: kiṃ na indra jighāṃsasi bhrātaro marutastava tebhiḥ kalpasva sādhuyā mā naḥ samaraṇe vadhīḥ
translation: What, Indra, do you long to harm your brothers with those of the Maruts' lineage? Let not enmity befall us in battle.

sloka: kiṃ no bhrātaragastya sakhā sannati manyase vidmā hi te yathā mano'smabhyaminna ditsasi
translation: What, O friend Gastya, do you think of us as siblings? Thus, we wish to know your true thoughts.

sloka: araṃ karṇvantu vediṃ samagnimindhatāṃ puraḥ tatrāmṛtasya cetanaṃ yajñaṃ te tanavāvahai
translation: May the ears fill (with hearing) the sacred knowledge of the Vedas and Agni, as also the life-sustaining sacrifice there; may you two invigorate that conscious elixir of life.

sloka: tavamīśiṣe vasupate vasūnāṃ tavaṃ mitrāṇāṃ mitrapate dheṣṭhaḥ indra tvaṃ marudbhiḥ saṃ vadasvādha prāśāna ṛtuthā havīṃṣi
translation: You, sovereign of the Vasus, are the greatest among them; you, lord of allies, are also the foremost among friends, Indra. Speak in conjunction with the Maruts. Offer up the oblations!

sloka: svāyaṃbhuvo manuḥ pūrvaṃ paraḥ svārociṣastathā | uttamastāmasaścaiva raivataścākṣuṣastathā ||
translation: The self-born Manu was the first, as well as the one who assigned names [to everything] in the beginning. Similarly, Raivata and Akshusha were also there.

sloka: yo jāta eva prathamo manasvān devo devān kratunā paryabhūṣat yasya śuṣmād rodasī abhyasetāṃ nṛmṇasya mahnā sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who was born first and is most excellent among the gods, who adorned the gods with his deeds, whose command sets bounds to the worlds – such an Indra has this person become.

sloka: yaḥ parthivīṃ vyathamānāma dṛṃhad yaḥ parvatān prakupitā~ aramṇāt yo antarikṣaṃ vimame varīyo yo dayāmastabhnāt sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who soothes the troubled earth, calms the enraged mountains, shakes the unshakeable atmosphere, and pours down rain with mercy is Indra to people.

sloka: yo hatvāhimariṇāta sapta sindhūn yo gā udājadapadhā valasya yo aśmanorantaragniṃ jajāna saṃvṛk samatsu sa janāsa indraḥ
translation: The one who, having vanquished the seven rivers, the cows, and the waters' source within the two stones (i.e., the polar mountains), gave birth to the fire residing in-between, and who has become the protector of people - that is Indra.

sloka: caturāśītisāhasramutsedhena prakīrtitaḥ|| praviṣṭaḥ ṣoḍaśādhastādviṃstṛtaḥ ṣoḍaśaiva tu|| ||
translation: You, who have been praised as having conquered a hundred thousand times a thousand (i.e., a large number of times), enter through the sixteenths (of the target) and become sixteen (parts) yourself.

sloka: mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava |
translation: Be the divine mother, be the father, be the teacher, be the guest.

sloka: ekarātraṃ tu nivasannatithirbrāhmaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ | anityaṃ hi sthito yasmāttasmādatithirucyate | | | | na brāhmaṇasya tvatithirgṛhe rājanya ucyate | vaiśyaśūdrau sakhā caiva jñātayo gurureva ca | | | | yadi tvatithidharmeṇa kṣatriyo gṛhaṃ āvrajet | bhuktavatsu ca vipreṣu kāmaṃ taṃ api bhojayet | | | | itarānapi sakhyādīnsamprītyā gṛhaṃ āgatān | prakṛtyānnaṃ yathāśakti bhojayetsaha bhāryayā | | | |
translation: A person who has taken up temporary residence for a single night is remembered as an "atithi" (guest). The term "sthita" (residing) is used to describe someone who stays longer. Hence, the term "atithi" is applied to one who resides temporarily. However, a "brāhmaṇa" (brahmin) is not referred to as an "atithi" when staying in another's house. Instead, a "rājanya" (kshatriya), "vaiśya," "śūdra," "friend," "relative," or "guru" is considered an "atithi." If a "kṣatriya" enters a household due to following the "atithi dharma" (guest ritual), then even a "vipra" (priest) who has partaken of food in that household should offer him food as well. Similarly, one should also offer food to any other guests who may have come out of friendship or goodwill, according to their ability and with the help of their wife.

sloka: rājartviksnātakagurūnpriyaśvaśuramātulān | arhayenmadhuparkeṇa parisaṃvatsarātpunaḥ | | | | saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: Let the newly initiated priest in royal service honor his beloved teachers, father-in-law, and maternal uncles by offering them a feast with sweetened beverages annually. At an appropriate time, he should respectfully present a seat and water to the arriving guest. Moreover, he must serve food according to his ability and resources, following proper procedures.

sloka: apraṇodyo'tithiḥ sāyaṃ sūryoḍho gṛhamedhinā | kāle prāptastvakāle vā nāsyānaśnangṛhe vaset | | | | vaiśvadeve tu nirvṛtte yadyanyo'tithirāvrajet | tasyāpyannaṃ yathāśakti pradadyānna baliṃ haret | | | |
translation: "The householder, having completed the evening rituals with the setting and descent of the sun, should either stay at home during the prescribed time or leave for another's residence outside of it. If another ritual day overtakes him during Vaiśvadeva, he may partake of food according to his ability, offering a portion as bali."

sloka: suvāsinīḥ kumārīśca rogiṇo garbhiṇīḥ striyaḥ | atithibhyo'gra evaitānbhojayedavicārayan | | | | bhuktavatsvatha vipreṣu sveṣu bhṛtyeṣu caiva hi | bhuñjīyātāṃ tataḥ paścādavaśiṣṭaṃ tu dampatī | | | |
translation: Honor the maidens, young girls, the sick, and pregnant women. Serve these guests first, considering it carefully. Previously, we used to partake in food with our teachers and personal attendants here. Now, let the couple also enjoy the leftovers.

sloka: na vai svayaṃ tadaśnīyādatithiṃ yanna bhojayet | dhanyaṃ yaśasyaṃ āyuṣyaṃ svargyaṃ vātithipūjanam | | | | śilānapyuñchato nityaṃ pañcāgnīnapi juhvataḥ | sarvaṃ sukṛtaṃ ādatte brāhmaṇo'narcito vasan | | | |
translation: Indeed, one does not himself partake in a guest's meal nor feed him at that time; yet the giver of alms acquires wealth, fame, longevity, and heavenly enjoyment. Even by offering a handful of grass to five fires daily, a Brahmin, revered and unsullied, gains all meritorious deeds.

sloka: ya evaṃ vetti puruṣaṃ prakṛtiṃ ca guṇaiḥ saha | sarvathā vartamāno'pi na sa bhūyo'bhijāyate || puruṣaḥ prakṛtistho hi bhuṅ‌kte prakṛtijānguṇān | kāraṇaṃ guṇasaṅgo'sya sadasadyonijanmasu ||
translation: The one who understands the person and nature along with their associated qualities in this way, even while constantly engaged, does not take birth again. The embodied soul situated in nature enjoys the goods of nature, bound by a bond of qualities arising from nature's gunas (constituents) and their interaction in creation, sustenance, and dissolution.

sloka: paraṃ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṃ jñānamuttamam | yajjñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṃ siddhimito gatāḥ ||
translation: I will further expound the supreme knowledge among knowledges. Having known this, all sages have attained the highest accomplishment.

sloka: idaṃ jñānamupāśritya mama sādharmyamāgatāḥ | sarge'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca ||
translation: Having taken refuge in this knowledge, they have attained similarity to me. Even in the creation and dissolution, they neither are born again nor do they suffer.

sloka: mama yonirmahadbrahma tasmingarbhaṃ dadhāmyaham | saṃbhavaḥ sarvabhūtānāṃ tato bhavati bhārata ||
translation: I, as the great Brahman, deposit the seed in my womb located there; from this origin of all beings, O Bharata, arises (their birth).

sloka: sarvayoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ saṃbhavanti yāḥ | tāsāṃ brahma mahadyonirahaṃ bījapradaḥ pitā ||
translation: Kaunteya, I am the cause of the creation of all forms that appear in various wombs. Among them, I am the seed-giving father, the great cause, for the eternal Brahman.

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ | nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam ||
translation: The three qualities born of nature—sattva, rajas, and tamas—restrain the eternal self in the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: tatra sattvaṃ nirmalatvātprakāśakamanāmayam | sukhasaṅgena badhnāti jñānasaṅgena cānagha ||
translation: There, pure sattva enlightens due to its clarity. With joy and knowledge, it binds without blemish, O anagha.

sloka: rajo rāgātmakaṃ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam | tannibadhnāti kaunteya karmasaṅgena dehinam ||
translation: Kaunteya, understand that desire-infused Rajas is born from craving. It binds the embodied soul through attachment to actions.

sloka: tamastvajñānajaṃ viddhi mohanaṃ sarvadehinām | pramādālasyanidrābhistannibadhnāti bhārata ||
translation: Understand ignorance, born of darkness, to be the deluder of all embodied beings, Bhārata. It binds them through heedlessness, laziness, and sleep.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: The sattva gets established in happiness, O Bhārata, while rajas does so in activity. Knowledge is covered by tamas when it becomes deluded, and it is revived through proper understanding.

sloka: rajastamaścābhibhūya sattvaṃ bhavati bhārata | rajaḥ sattvaṃ tamaścaiva tamaḥ sattvaṃ rajastathā ||
translation: By overcoming Rajas and Tamas, O Bharata, the mode of goodness arises; similarly, when the mode of goodness is predominant, both Rajas and Tamas recede.

sloka: sarvadvāreṣu dehe'sminprakāśa upajāyate | jñānaṃ yadā tadā vidyādvivṛddhaṃ sattvamityuta ||
translation: In this body, at all gates, illumination arises; when knowledge increases, so does the pure nature (of the self).

sloka: lobhaḥ pravṛttirārambhaḥ karmaṇāmaśamaḥ spṛhā | rajasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha || aprakāśo'pravṛttiśca pramādo moha eva ca | tamasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe kurunandana ||
translation: Greed, endeavor, and initiative are generated by action and tranquility, longing, and rajas manifest as these in growth, O best of Bharatas. Inactivity, lack of illumination, confusion, and desire also arise from tamas when it grows, O delight of the Kurus.

sloka: nānyaṃ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṃ yadā draṣṭānupaśyati | guṇebhyaśca paraṃ vetti madbhāvaṃ so'dhigacchati ||
translation: Only when one truly sees and observes the doer beyond other qualities does one come to understand my true nature.

sloka: guṇānetānatītya trīndehī dehasamudbhavān | janmamṛtyujarāduḥkhairvimukto'mṛtamaśnute ||
