sloka: brahmacaryyācaraṇasya yaḥ śāstrabodhito'vadhiḥ | tāvadvedamupāsyāsamāptaveda evāśramāntaraṃ gato yaḥ sa vratasnātakaḥ |samāpya vratamasamāpya vedaṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vratasnātakaḥ
translation: The one who is dedicated to the conduct of brahmacarya, identified by scriptural knowledge, has reached beyond this stage up to the point indicated by the scriptures; he who has completed his vow and bathed, having finished his vow, returns, having completed the Veda.

sloka: vedamadhītyagurusannidhau vedābhyāsaṃ yaḥ karoti sa vidyāsnātakaḥ |samāpya vedamasamāpya vrataṃ yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāsnātakaḥ
translation: The one who studies the Vedas in the presence of the guru and causes himself to be initiated into knowledge, and the one who completes the vow and returns having completed it, both are known as knowers of knowledge.

sloka: pālitasamyagvrataḥ prāptavedo yo dvitīyāśramaṃ gataḥ sa ubhayasnātakaḥ |ubhayaṃ samāpya yaḥ samāvartate sa vidyāvratasnātaka iti
translation: The one who, having been properly conducted by his duties, has obtained knowledge of the Vedas, has approached the second stage of life after having undergone the rite of passage, and has completed both (parts of the rite) - he is called an upanayana-snataka.

sloka: tadya itthaṃ viduḥ | ye ceme'raṇye śraddhā tapa ityupāsate te'rciṣamabhisambhavantyarciṣo'harahna āpūryamāṇapakṣamāpūryamāṇapakṣādyānṣaḍudaṅṅeti māsā~stān || ||
translation: They, who worship faith and austerity in the forest of immortality, are able to fill what is diminishing and empty themselves when they have become full; such is the nature of the six seasons in the months.

sloka: agniḥ sūryo divā prāhṇaḥ śuklo rākottaraṃ svarāṭ viśvo'tha taijasaḥ prājñasturya ātmā samanvayāt devayānamidaṃ prāhurbhūtvā bhūtvānupūrvaśaḥ ātmayājyupaśāntātmā hyātmastho na nivartate
translation: They declare this to be the divinely appointed vehicle, born of the merging of Agni and Surya in daytime, pure and superior, self-willed, all-pervading, and subtler than the subtle. It is the conscious self in the state of turya (transcendental consciousness), the object of meditation for those seeking self-realization. This identified with the inner offering, brings about pacification and stillness within one's own self. The atmastha (the self-established) one does not regress from this path.

sloka: atha ya ime grāma iṣṭāpūrte dattamityupāsate te dhūmamabhisambhavanti dhūmādrātri~ rātreraparapakṣamaparapakṣādyānṣaḍdakṣiṇaiti māsā~stānnaite saṃvatsaramabhiprāpnuvanti || ||
translation: Once those who worship the benefactor of the village, named Iṣṭāpurta, as a deity start to venerate them, they attain the smoke (of fame) that arises during the night and day, extending up to six months and a year.

sloka: dravyasūkṣmavipākaśca dhūmo rātrirapakṣayaḥ ayanaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ somo darśa oṣadhivīrudhaḥ annaṃ reta iti kṣmeśa pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ ekaikaśyenānupūrvaṃ bhūtvā bhūtveha jāyate
translation: Subtle transformations of substances and smoke, night and waning moon, the southern path, the Soma, the Darsha plants, herbs in bloom, food and semen - all these, O Lord of the earth, are reborn again and again, each taking its own new form in this existence.

sloka: athaitayoḥ pathorna katareṇa ca na tānīmāni kṣudrāṇyasakṛdāvartīni bhūtāni bhavanti jāyasva mriyasvetyetattṛtīya~sthānaṃ tenāsau loko na sampūryate tasmājjugupseta tadeṣa ślokaḥ || ||
translation: "So, which of the two paths, through either of them, do these insignificant beings who constantly revolve as 'be born and die', not become numerous? Therefore, one should despise this verse."

sloka: tadantarapratipattau raṃhati sampariṣvaktaḥ praśnanirūpaṇābhyām
translation: In the pursuit of understanding its inner meaning, he interrogates and examines (the scripture) closely.

sloka: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttimanyayāvartate punaḥ
translation: In the white and black (i.e., in day and night), these two paths of the world are eternal. By one, it proceeds to a fixed destination; by another, it returns through a different course, again and again.

sloka: agne devā~ ihā vaha sādayā yoniṣu triṣu | pari bhūṣa piba ṛtunā ||
translation: O Fire, bring here the gods and grace the three birthplaces. Be adorned and drink the nectar.

sloka: ā vakṣi devā~ iha vipra yakṣi cośan hotarni ṣadā yoniṣu triṣu ||
translation: O seer, which gods indeed protect here in these three worlds - as givers of sustenance and nourishment?

sloka: yajñasya ketuṃ prathamaṃ purohitamagniṃ narastriṣadhasthe samīdhire ||
translation: The foremost among those who ignite the sacrificial fire, the officiant, has been appointed as the sign of the sacrifice.

sloka: dakṣiṇaṃ tveva prathamaṃ vijñāyate pitā vā eṣo'gnīnāṃ yaddakṣiṇaḥ putro gārhapatyaḥ pautra āhavanīyastasmādevaṃ paryukṣet
translation: Indeed, the southerly direction is recognized first. Surely, this is the father of the fires, namely the son who is called the southern fire (dakshinaagni), the Gharapatya and the Aahavaniiya fires. Therefore, he should be duly honored.

sloka: gārhapatyena santya ṛtunā yajñanīrasi | devān devayate yaja ||
translation: With the domestic fire, performing the ritual at the proper time, you should cause the gods to be pleased.

sloka: ta eva hi trayo lokāsta eva traya āśramāḥ | ta eva hi trayo vedāsta evoktāstrayo'gnayaḥ | |
translation: These three worlds are indeed the triple stages of life, and these three Vedas are also referred to as the triple fires.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | | | |
translation: Having done this task of serving the guest, one should establish (him) in advance. And (one) should give alms to the mendicant in the prescribed manner.

sloka: vidyātapaḥsamṛddheṣu hutaṃ vipramukhāgniṣu | nistārayati durgācca mahataścaiva kilbiṣāt | | | |
translation: "In the prosperity of learning and austerities, the officiating priest tends to the fires and rescues from great sins, even small ones, coming from durgā and mahata."

sloka: bhikṣāṃ apyudapātraṃ vā satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | vedatattvārthaviduṣe brāhmaṇāyopapādayet | | | |
translation: Even to a mendicant, one should properly and according to rules cause to be given alms; to the brahmin versed in the true meaning of the Vedas.

sloka: yatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti gāṃ dattvā vidhivadguroḥ | tatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti bhikṣāṃ dattvā dvijo gṛhī | | | |
translation: By properly giving away the cow and subsequently partaking in the meritorious fruit, it is similarly achieved by a dvija who gives alms respectfully to a guru.

sloka: na mṛ॒tyu: āsīt amṛta॒ṃ na tarhi॒
translation: Death never existed nor was there immortality in the past.

sloka: ānī̭t avā॒taṃ sva॒dhayā॒ tat ekamtasmāddhānyanna paraḥ kiñcanāsa
translation: Brought near by one's own nature, that alone is to be resorted to, nothing else, nor any other thing.

sloka: tapasa॒: tatmahi॒naajāya॒taekam
translation: Through dedicated meditation, we realize the single, unchanging reality.

sloka: divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ apraṇo hyamanāḥ śubhro hyakṣarātparataḥ paraḥ
translation: The divine and unaging Purusha, untouched from within or without, free from desire and want, self-contained, pure, and shining, transcending the physical world and originating from a source beyond.

sloka: sahasraśīrṣā puruṣaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ sahasrapāt
translation: The being with a thousand heads and a thousand eyes, as well as a thousand feet, is he.

sloka: puruṣa evedaṃ sarvaṃ yadbhūtaṃ yacca bhavyam
translation: The being, this alone is all that has been and will be.

sloka: tasmādvirāl̤ajāyata virājo adhi pūruṣaḥsa jāto atyaricyata paścādbhūmimatho puraḥ
translation: Then, from him ( emerged) the heroic Viraj and first the Purusha expanded in front and behind, and also below and above.

sloka: devānāṃ pūrvye yuge'sataḥ sadajāyata || devānāṃ yuge prathame'sataḥ sadajāyata | tadāśā anvajāyanta taduttānapadaspari ||
translation: In the previous age, the forefathers of the gods were born from this; in the first age, the gods themselves were born from this. Then longings arose and spread towards it.

sloka: ekam sat vipra bahudhā vadanti
translation: The sage declares the One Truth in many ways .

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tato vai sadajāyata | tadātmāna~ svayamakuruta | tasmāttatsukṛtamucyata iti | yadvai tat sukṛtam | raso vai saḥ |
translation: Initially, this was non-existent. Then existence emerged from it. The very Self then, of its own accord, became the manifestation. Therefore, it is known as "the made" because of that manifestation. Indeed, that manifestation is the essence.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tadāhuḥ kiṃ tadasadāsīdityṛṣayo vāva te'gre'sadāsīt
translation: Were there once only two (entities)? Then, did the seers say, "What was that then?" or did Ditis and Ṛṣis exist before? You all indeed know (the answer).

sloka: naiveha kiṃcanāgra āsīn mṛtyunaivedamāvṛtamāsīdaśanāyayā'śanāyā hi mṛtyus tanmano'kurutā''tmanvī syāmiti | so'rcannacarat tasyārcata āpo'jāyantārcate vai me kamabhūditi | ||
translation: Indeed, have not two been here before, uncovered by death, desiring to see, seeking to understand each other's essence. Like this, death does not touch those who are engaged in my worship. Thus, the waters (of life) arise for him who performs my worship, just as I once became for you.

sloka: sadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam | taddhaika āhurasadevedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyaṃ tasmādasataḥ sajjāyata || || sattveva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīyam || ||
translation: Indeed, my dear, in the beginning, there was only one unrivaled Being; they say that He alone was present in the beginning, as the One, unparalleled. And from Him , all these have originated . The reference here is to the Absolute Reality, denoted by 'tattva' and 'sattvā' .

sloka: iṣṭaprāpti aniṣṭapariharyor alaukikam upāyam yo grantho vedayati sa vedaḥ
translation: The text that explains the extraordinary means to obtain the desirable and renounce the undesirable is called a treatise. He who knows thus.

sloka: ekaviṃśatiśākhātmaka ṛk śataśākhātmaka yajuḥ sahasraśākhāmayasāma navaśākhāmayātharvva iti purāṇam api ca śrīmārkaṇḍeya uvāca |
translation: The sage Marakanda, after mentioning the 20-branched Rig Veda, the 100-branched Yajur Veda, and the thousand-branched Sama Veda, spoke of the old Atharva Veda with its nine branches.

sloka: tebhyastaptebhyastrayo vedā ajāyanta | agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurvedaḥ sūryāt sāmavedaḥ |
translation: From them, having been heated, originated the three Vedas: from Agni came the Ṛgveda, from Vāyu the Yajurveda, and from the sun the Sāmaveda.

sloka: tasmādṛca: sāma yajūṃṣi dīkṣā
translation: Hence, the Ṛc, Sāman, and Yajus; such is the initiation.

sloka: etasya vā mahato bhūtasya ni:śvasitametad yad ṛgvedo yajurveda: sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa
translation: Of this great entity, would it not be its exhalation, the Ṛkveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvangedira?

sloka: upa tvāgne divedive doṣāvastardhiyā vayaṃ namo bharanta emasi
translation: Before you, we bow down in reverence, you (singular) being consistently free from faults, while we two (dual) have become afflicted with shortcomings.

sloka: vedaśāstrārthatattvajño yatra tatrāśrame vasan | ihaiva loke tiṣṭhansa brahmabhūyāya kalpate | | |
translation: The knower of the true meaning of the Vedas and Shastras resides in that ashram, where he becomes eligible for spiritual enlightenment (brahmabhuyaya) here in this world itself.

sloka: dharmabrahmapratipādakamapauruṣeyavākyam iti vedāntaśāstram
translation: The Vedanta Shastra is defined as the teaching that effectively establishes dharma and brahman, being impersonally spoken and constituting the conclusion of the Vedas.

sloka: sanātanaṃ niteyam | vedāpauruṣeyatvapakṣa eva manorabhimataḥ| pūrvakalpe ye vedāsta eva paramātmamūrterbrahmaṇaḥ sarvajñasya smṛtyārūḍhāḥ | tāneva kalpādau agnivāyuravibhya ācakarṣa|
translation: Regarded as the eternal and chosen object of the mind is the indestructible nature of the Vedas. In the previous cycle, the Vedas, as the manifestation of the omniscient Brahman, had established fire, wind, and sun.

sloka: yathā ca śrutiḥ agnerṛgvedo vāyoryajurveda ādityātsāmaveda ||
translation: Just as the shruti (revelation) in the ṛgveda concerning Agni, in the yajuḥ concerning Vayu, and in the sāma from the Āditya.

sloka: anantā vai vedāḥ |
translation: The Vedas are indeed infinite.

sloka: pitṛdevamanuṣyāṇāṃ vedaścakṣuḥ sanātanam | aśakyaṃ cāprameyaṃ ca vedaśāstraṃ iti sthitiḥ | |
translation: The eternal vision of the Vedas, regarded as the deity of humanity, is considered unspeakable and immeasurable knowledge. This is the established view.

sloka: vedo'khilo dharmamūlaṃ smṛtiśīle ca tadvidām | ācāraścaiva sādhūnāṃ ātmanastuṣṭireva ca | | | |
translation: The Veda is the foundation of dharma, as is smrti for the knowing ones. Also, proper conduct is that of the noble-minded, while contentment is the supreme state of the self.

sloka: bibharti sarvabhūtāni vedaśāstraṃ sanātanam | tasmādetatparaṃ manye yajjantorasya sādhanam | | | |
translation: "She who sustains all beings carries the eternal Veda scripture. I believe this to be the supreme means for the being's accomplishment."

sloka: ārṣaṃ dharmopadeśaṃ ca vedaśāstrāvirodhinā | yastarkeṇānusaṃdhatte sa dharmaṃ veda netaraḥ | | | |
translation: One who cements the ancient teaching of dharma, in accordance with the Vedic scriptures using logical reasoning, is the one who truly knows dharma, not others.

sloka: yānīhāgamaśāstrāṇi yāśca kāścitpravṛttayaḥ| tāni vedaṃ puraskṛtya pravṛttāni yathākramam||
translation: Having mastered those sacred texts and traditions that have come down to us, as well as the various ways they have been put into practice, one should study and follow them in the proper sequence.

sloka: parābhidhyānātu tirohitaṃ tato hyasya bandhaviparyayau
translation: Then, what lies hidden beyond explicit meditation is, in that case, the reversal of his relationships.

sloka: ata eva copamā sūryakādivat
translation: Then compare yourself to the likes of the sun.

sloka: śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chandasāṃ cayaḥ | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ caiva vedāṅgāni ṣaḍeva tu ||
translation: The six ancillary sciences of the Vedas are: phonetics , ritual science , grammar , etymology , meter , and astrology-calendrics , along with their respective textual traditions.

sloka: atha śikṣāṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ | varṇaḥ svaraḥ | mātrā balam | sāma santāna| ityuktaḥ śikṣādhyāyaḥ ||
translation: Now we will explain the teaching, which includes phonemes, syllables, their strength, and the lineage of sāman; so is declared the chapter on śikṣā.

sloka: mantro hīnaḥ svarato varṇato vā mithyā prayukto na tamarthamāha | sa vāgvajro yajamānaṃ hinasti yathendraśatruḥ svarato'parādhāt ||
translation: If a mantra is incorrectly used, either due to its incorrect pronunciation or misinterpretation, it does not accomplish its intended purpose. Indeed, such a person's speech becomes as destructive as a thunderbolt to the one who sacrifices (yajamāna). This is because the enemy of Indra, when acting with hostility towards it (aparādhāt), can harm the mantra.

sloka: tattvaṣṭāhavanīyamupa prāvartayatsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti yadavartayattadvṛtrasya vṛtratvaṃ yadabravītsvāhendraśatrurvardhasveti tasmādasyendraḥ śatrurabhavat
translation: You had caused the ritualistic observance of Tattvastha-avanīyam, which had been perfectly ordered by the rite "svāhā." When you were causing Vardhasva, the enemy of Indra, to revolve as the vṛtra of Vrtrasya, he declared, "Vardhasva is my enemy." Therefore, Indra became his enemy.

sloka: vyākriyante śabdāḥ anena iti vyākaraṇam | vyākriyante vyutpādyante sādhuśabdā asmin aneneti vā iti durgādāsaḥ
translation: Words are analyzed by this; hence, this is called vyākaraṇa. Also, through this, good words are generated in this (context). As for Durgādāsa, it is so through this (as well).

sloka: indraścandraḥ kāśakṛtsnāpiśalī śākaṭāyanaḥ | pāṇinyamarajainendrāḥ jayantyaṣṭau ca śābdikāḥ ||
translation: Indra and Chandra, Kaashakritsnapishalii, Shaakatayana, Paṇini, Amarajaina, and the eight Śābdika are famously known.

sloka: arthāvabodhe nirapekṣatayā padajātaṃ yatroktaṃ tanniruktam |
translation: In the context of understanding the meaning of words, it is said that 'artha' has been explained where it occurred without any bias in the spoken form of 'pada-jātam'. Likewise, 'that which is called niruktam' (etymology) is also stated there.

sloka: samāmnāyaḥ samāmnātaḥ sa vyākhyātavyaḥ | idamantareṇa mantreṣvarthapratyayo na vidyate iti |
translation: This explanation, previously designated and highly praised, must be clarified. In this context, there is no recognition of a meaning for the word "artha" in the mantra.

sloka: udāharaṇasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ|| {hetulakṣaṇam} tathā vaidharmyāt|| {hetulakṣaṇam}
translation: The means for achieving a result similar to a given example is caused by that very similarity, and so too is it caused by dissimilarity.

sloka: udāharaṇena sāmānyātsādhyasya dharmasya sādhanaṃ prajñāpanaṃ hetuḥ | sādhye pratisaṃdhāya dharmamudāharaṇe ca pratisaṃdhāya tasya sādhanatāvacanaṃ hetuḥ utpattidharmakatvāditi | utpattidharmakamanityaṃ dṛṣṭamiti | udāharaṇavaidharmyācca sādhyasādhanaṃ hetuḥ | katham anityaḥ śabdaḥ utpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ yathā ātmādidravyaniti ||
translation: Exposition of the means to achieve the general duty: Inquiry into it is the revealing cause; in establishing the means and in establishing the general duty regarding the object, the statement of being the means is the cause due to its nature as an attribute. This has been observed as the case with attributes and their means; how can the word 'anitya' (transient) be the means for the eternal 'śabda' (word), just as it is for ātma and other objects?

sloka: sādhyasādharmyāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta udāharaṇam || {udāharaṇalakṣaṇam} tadviparyayādvā viparītam||{udāharaṇalakṣaṇam}
translation: The example that illustrates becoming characterized by what is different from the inherent nature of the target [sādhya] is described as a [dṛṣṭānta]. Its opposite is described as its reverse.

sloka: sādhyena sādharmyaṃ samānadharmatā sādhyasādharmyātkāraṇāttaddharmabhāvī dṛṣṭānta iti | tasya dharmastaddharmaḥ | tasya sādhyasya | sādhyaṃ ca dvividhaṃ dharmiviśiṣṭo vā dharmaḥ śabdasyānityatvaṃ dharmaviśiṣṭo vā dharmī anityaḥ śabda iti| ihettaraṃ tadgrahaṇena gṛhyate|
translation: The property of being similar to the accomplishment is understood as being accomplished through the instrument of a similar property with the same characteristics . This is because of the reason that such a property exists in it , leading to the manifestation of the accomplishment . A distinction is made between the eternal nature of the word "property" and the transient nature of the thing characterized by it . This distinction is grasped through this very means . The property of that which is to be accomplished is twofold: a property characterized by the word "property" , and a transient property . This is presented as an illustrative example .

sloka: udāharaṇāpekṣaḥ tathā iti upasaṃhāraḥ na tathā iti vā sādhyasya upanayaḥ || {upanayalakṣaṇam}
translation: The illustrative example or the preliminary part, and the summary statement – these are not (the same as) the introduction of the conclusion; rather, it is (possible that) the conclusion itself is being introduced.

sloka: sādhyāsādharmyayukte udāharaṇe sthālyādi dravyamutyatidharmakatvamupasaṃhriyate sādhyavaidarmyayukte punarudāharaṇe ātmādi dravyamanutpattidharmakaṃ nityaṃ dṛṣṭaṃ na ca tathā śabda iti anutpattidharmakatvasyopasaṃhārapratiṣedhena utpattidharmakatvamupasaṃhiyate |
translation: In the illustration of similarity with the probandum, a substance like sthālī is presented; its having attributes different from those of the probandum is subsumed. On the other hand, when illustrated with dissimilarity to the probandum, the eternal manifestation of substances starting from ātman is observed; this is not the case with sound, as established by negating the attribute of non-manifestation and affirming the attribute of manifestation.

sloka: hetvapadeśātpratijñāyāḥ punarvacanaṃ nigamanam||{nigamanalakṣaṇam}
translation: After the explanation of the reason and promise, what follows next is the conclusion.

sloka: sādharmyokte vaidharmyokte vā yathodāharaṇamupasaṃhriyate tasmādutpattidharmakatvādanityaḥ śabda iti nigamanam |
translation: When similarity or dissimilarity is illustrated as an example, it is called a term that signifies the characteristic of emergence.

sloka: brahma vai mantraḥ | ḥ saptākṣaraṃ vai brahmargityekamakṣaraṃ yajuritidve sāmeti dve atha yadato'nyadbrahmaiva taddvyakṣaraṃ vai brahma tadetatsarvaṃsaptākṣaraṃ brahma |
translation: The Vedic hymn indeed is Brahman, consisting of seven syllables; the one-syllabled Brahma is called the path of Brahman. In the Yajurveda, there are two kinds of Brahmas named "same" and "ti." Other than these, any other Brahma is not the actual Brahman; this whole seven-syllabled Brahman is indeed the actual Brahman.

sloka: mantrabrāhmaṇe yajñasya pramāṇam mantrabrāhmaṇayorvedanāmadheyam karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: The standard of the yajna (sacrificial ritual) is the mantra-brAhman, and the mantra-brAhman is the identified aspect of the veda. The brAhmanas are the incitement for the action.

sloka: śeṣe brāhmaṇa śabdaḥ
translation: In the end, O Brahmin, is the word.

sloka: dvividham brāhmaṇam vidhiḥ arthavādaśca
translation: The rule and exhortation concern two types of brahmans.

sloka: heturnirvacanaṃ nindā praśaṃsā saṃśayo vidhiḥ| parakriyā purākalpo vyavadhāraṇakalpanā|| upamānaṃ daśaite tu vidhayo brāhmaṇasya tu| etadvai sarvavedeṣu niyataṃ vidhilakṣaṇam||
translation: The causes, designations, blame, praise, doubt, and rules for the brahmin are indeed established as marks in all the Vedas. They are: purpose, past actions, subsequent ritual implementation, and the decree regarding the ten aspects, referred to as "upamana."

sloka: itthaṃ vākyaistadarthānusandhānaṃ śravaṇaṃ bhavet yuktyā saṃbhāvitatvānusaṃdhānaṃ mannantu tat
translation: By examining the meanings and grammatical context, one should listen to such explanations of meaning. Through proper understanding, let that (explanation) be established as true.

sloka: yat saṃbaddhaṃ sat tadākārollekhi vijñānaṃ tat pratyakṣaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: That which is logically connected, that is directly perceived knowledge. This is the teaching of Sankhya.

sloka: pratibandhadṛśaḥ pratibaddhajñānamanumānaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: Like the system of Sankhya, which is a treatise on cognition, identifying the previously bound consciousness as the object to be known, along with the process of inferring its current state of bondage.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: The term that has been taught by the worthy is called 'sāṃkhyasūtra'.

sloka: dṛṣṭamanumānamāptavacanaṃ ca sarvapramāṇasiddhatvāt | trividhaṃ pramāṇamiṣṭaṃ prameyasiddhi: pramāṇāddhi || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and verbal testimony are established as threefold means of valid cognition, because they establish the object to be known, due to their own established nature.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Perception, inference, and scriptural testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: āptena dṛṣṭo'numitaḥ vā arthaḥ paratra svabodhasaṅkrāntaye śabdenopadiśyate | śabdāttadarthaviṣayā vṛttiḥ śroturāgamaḥ | yasyāśraddheyārtho vaktā na dṛṣṭānumitārthaḥ sa āgamaḥ plavate |
translation: "The truth that has been seen and ascertained by a reliable source is declared through words. The usage of words relates to the object of that knowledge, while the arrival of such knowledge is through hearing. If the speaker who expresses unestablished meaning is not trustworthy, then that kind of communication drifts away."

sloka: tadvacanādāmnāyasya prāmāṇyam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: "From the statement (of the scripture), the validity of Vaiśeṣika's (teachings) becomes established."

sloka: asyedaṃ kāryaṃ kāraṇaṃ saṃyogi virodhi samavāyi ceti laiṅgikam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: Of this , what is to be done by the follower of Vaiśeṣika system, namely as regards cause , conjunction , disjunction , and inherence ?

sloka: asyedaṃ kārya kāraṇasambandhaścāvayavādbhavati | vaiśeṣika |
translation: Of the Vaiśeṣika system, this is how the relationship between cause and effect arises from constituent elements.

sloka: etena śābdaṃ vyākhyātam | vaiśeṣika |
translation: With this word, explain (the concept of) Vaiseshika.

sloka: heturapadeśo liṅgaṃ pramāṇaṃ karaṇamityanarthāntaram | vaiśeṣika |
translation: Cause, indication, gender, means of knowledge, and instrument are distinguished as having separate meanings in the Vaiseshika system.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni || || {pramāṇauddeśasūtram}
translation: Perception, inference, and reliable testimony are the means of valid knowledge. (Pramaanauddesasutra)

sloka: indriyārthasannikarṣotpannaṃ jñānaṃ avyapadeśyaṃ avyabhicāri vyavasāyātmakaṃ pratyakṣam|||| {pratyakṣalakṣaṇam} atha tatpūrvakaṃ trividhaṃ anumānaṃ pūrvavatśeṣavatsāmānyatodṛṣṭaṃ ca|||| {anumānalakṣaṇam} prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam |||| {upamānalakṣaṇam} āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ |||| {śabdalakṣaṇam}
translation: Knowledge arising from the contact of sense organs and objects is unteachable, unfailing, determined in nature, and constitutes direct perception . Prior to this, there exists threefold inference: based on cause , based on effect , and based on similarity ; also known as sādharmya-based inference. Additionally, there are two types of reliable testimony: verbal testimony and expert testimony .

sloka: satsaṃprayoge puruṣasyendriyāṇāṃ buddhijanma tatpratyakṣam
translation: In the conjunction of a person's senses, the arising of understanding is directly perceptible.

sloka: autpattikas tu śabdasyārthena saṃbandhas tasya jñānam upadeśo'vyatirekaś cārthe'nupalabdhe tatpramāṇaṃ bādarāyaṇasyānapekṣatvāt
translation: The intrinsic connection of a word's meaning is its knowledge, while the indication of it is called upadeśa; avyatireka is the means of knowing in the absence of the directly perceivable object, and Badarayana's pramana is independent of it.

sloka: api vā kartṛsāmānyāt pramāṇam anumānaṃ syāt
translation: Even inferential knowledge could serve as a means of establishing the common characteristic of agents.

sloka: anumānaṃ jñātasambandhasyaikadeśadarśanādekadeśāntare'sannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhiḥ| tattu dvividhaṃ pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandham ca| pratyakṣatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā dhūmākṛtidarśanādagnyākṛtivijñānam| sāmānyatodṛṣṭasaṃbandhaṃ yathā devadattasya gatipūrvikāṃ deśāntaraprāptimupalabhyādityagatismaraṇam|
translation: Inference is the means of knowing the connection between things, when one of them has been directly perceived and the other is close by. Understand that there are two kinds of such connections - one based on direct perception and the other based on inference. An example of a connection based on direct perception is the knowledge that smoke arises from fire. An example of a connection based on inference is the understanding that Devadatta has gone to another place, since his footprints have been found there.

sloka: śāstraṃ śabdavijñānādasannikṛṣṭe'rthe vijñānam||
translation: Knowledge derived from scriptural teachings and sound analysis is to be acquired in the context of closely related matters.

sloka: upamānamapi sādṛśyam asannikṛṣṭe'rthe buddhimutpādayati| yathā gavayadarśanaṃ gosmaraṇasya|
translation: Even a comparison invokes similarity in close proximity, just as the sight of a gavaya does for a cow's recollection.

sloka: arthāpattirapi dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho'nyathā nopapadyate ityarthakalpanā| yathā jīvati devadatte gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyādṛṣṭasya kalpanā ||
translation: Even if one perceives or hears about a different interpretation of a word's meaning, it should not be accepted. Just as Devadatta continues to live, experiencing the absence of his home externally, through mental constructs, so too does the unseen become known.

sloka: abhāvo'pi pramāṇābhāvo nāsti ityasyārthasyāsannikṛṣṭasya||
translation: The absence of proof is not considered as true for something that is closely established.

sloka: śabdād eva pramitaḥ |
translation: Derived from sound alone, that's how it has been ascertained.

sloka: api saṃrādhanepratyakṣānumānābhyām |
translation: Even through perception and inference.

sloka: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne |
translation: They reveal it so, as manifest and inferred.

sloka: phalamata upapatteḥ |
translation: The result/fruit of having reached/attained/understood?

sloka: athocyeta mā bhūtkarmānantaraṃ phalotpādaḥ karmakāryādapūrvātphalamutpatsyata iti tadapi nopapadyate apūrvasyācetanasya kāṣṭhaloṣṭasamasya cetanenāpravartitasya pravṛttyanupapatteḥ tadastitve eva pramāṇābhāvāt arthāpattiḥ pramāṇamiti cet na īśvarasiddherarthāpattikṣayāt||
translation: "Should it be declared that the result arises immediately after an action? No, it is not appropriate. Even if there is no consciousness similar to a piece of wood or a straw, activity cannot occur without a sentient being. The very establishment of this leads to the inference of the thing, which serves as evidence. But if the inference is destroyed by the determination of the existence of the Lord, then what?"

sloka: idānīmarthāpattirnirūpyate| tatropapadyajñānenopapādakakalpanamarthāpattiḥ| tatropapadyajñānaṃ karaṇam upapādakajñānaṃ phalam|
translation: The emergence of the intended meaning is being determined here. At that point, the emergence of the intended meaning arises from your planning, which is based on correct knowledge. Here, the lack of knowledge is the cause, and the resulting manifestation of the intended meaning is the effect.

sloka: samyagarthe ca saṃśabdo duṣprayoganivāraṇaḥ | prayoga indriyāṇāṃ ca vyāpāro'rtheṣu kaththate ||duṣṭatvācchuktikāyogo vāryate rajatekṣaṇāt | evaṃ satyanuvādatvaṃ lakṣaṇasyāpi saṃbhavet ||
translation: Correctly for the purpose and saṃśabda is said to be the remover of improper usage. The use of the senses is described as prayoga, and its application in objects is spoken of as artheṣu. When the union of impurity and oyster (indicating something unnatural or against the proper order) is avoided, then truthful assertion also becomes possible in the case of lakṣaṇa. Thus, you (singular, informal) have become established in that (sambhavet).

sloka: pramāṇaṣaṭkavijñāto yatrā'rtho nā'nyathā bhavet | adṛṣṭaṃ kalpayedanyaṃ sā 'rthāpattirudāhṛtā ||
translation: Where the object is not otherwise than as known through the six means of valid knowledge, therein its manifestation is to be inferred; one should hypothesize what is unseen.

sloka: ānumānikam apy ekeṣām iti cen na śarīrarūpakavinyastagṛhīterdarśayati ca |
translation: Even if some (of them) claim to have fixed their senses in the body, it is not evident; such a presentation does not show itself.

sloka: mātāpitrorgurau mitre vinīte copakāriṇi | dīnānāthaviśiṣṭebhyo dattantu saphalaṃ bhavet ||
translation: Let the selfless service to mother, father, teacher, and friends, as well as to the distressed and the most excellent among the distressed, bear fruit; may it be accomplished.

sloka: dhūrte vandini mande ca kuvaidye kitave śaṭhe | cāṭucāraṇacaurabhyo dattaṃ bhavati niṣphalam ||
translation: To a deceitful person, offering even great riches to those who are unintelligent, dishonest, and treacherous becomes unfruitful.

sloka: ārūḍhapatite dattamanyāyopahṛtaṃ ca yat| vyarthaṃ tu patite dānaṃ brāhmaṇe taskare tathā||
translation: Given (as past participle) have been bestowed and also taken away through injustice, but a gift to a brahmin, snatched away, becomes pointless.

sloka: avyaktādvyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame | rātryāgame pralīyante tatraivāvyaktasaṃjñake || || parastasmāttu bhāvo'nyo'vyakto'vyaktātsanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati || || avyakto'kṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim |
translation: From the unmanifested, all manifestations arise in this cycle of day and night; they dissolve back into the unmanifested at the end of the night. The inherent nature is other than this unmanifested; it is eternal and remains unchanged in all beings, unaffected by their destruction or loss. It is called the indestructible unmanifested and is considered the ultimate destination.

sloka: tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ
translation: "Just like with a beloved wife, (one should speak) to women."

sloka: sattvasaktamatiḥ kṛṣṇe dahyamano mahārogaiḥ na vivedātmano gatram tartatyalhada saṃstitaḥ
translation: With a mind attached to virtue, why don't you understand that the body is being consumed by great afflictions in Krishna? You did not recognize your own self.

sloka: pañcaiva mahāyajñāḥ| tānyeva mahāsattrāṇi bhūtayajño manuṣyayajñaḥ pitṛyajño devayajño brahmayajña iti
translation: There are five great sacrifices indeed, which are also the grand rituals: the sacrifice to creatures, that to humans, to ancestors, to gods, and to the Brahman.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan
translation: The five implements of a householder - the water vessel, the grinding stone, the broom, the container for holding water, and the pot - are what get used (by someone); those that are used are specifically the moving ones.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti
translation: Then, the five sacrificial acts: deva-yajna for the gods, bhuta-yajna for living beings, pitri-yajna for ancestors, brahma-yajna for knowledge, and manushya-yajna for humans.

sloka: tadvidhiprasaṅgena pañcamahāyajñānvidhatte
translation: Through dedicated adherence to ritual rules, he performs the five great sacrifices.

sloka: pitṛyajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yatpitṛbhyaḥ svadhā karotyapyapastatpitṛyajñaḥ saṃtiṣṭhateiti | tatra piṇḍadānāsaṃbhave jalamātramapi pitṛbhyaḥ svadhā'stviti svadhāśabdena yaddadāti so'yaṃ pitṛyajñaḥ
translation: The characteristic of the pitryajna sacrifice is described: one offers svadha to the pitrs with it, and the pitryajna establishes itself, even with just a water offering to the pitrs if a pindadaana has not occurred. Through the word 'svadha', what is offered is called pitryajna.

sloka: vaiśvadevānuṣṭhānādūrdhvaṃ bahirdeśe vāyasādibhyo bhūtebhyo yadbalipradānaṃ so'yaṃ bhūtayajña:
translation: The ritualistic observance of Vaishvadeva, when performed with excellence, surpasses other offerings made to various beings such as cows, etc., outside or in a designated place. Such a complete and perfect observance is indeed the sacrifice to all creatures.

sloka: yajñaḥ kasmāt | prakhyātaṃ yajatikarma iti nairuktāḥ | yācñaḥ bhavati iti vā | yajurunnaḥ bhavati iti vā | bahukṛṣṇājinaḥ iti aupamanyavaḥ | yajūṃṣi enaṃ nayanti iti vā |
translation: Why is the yajña (sacrifice) known as yajatikarma (act of sacrificing) derived from what; or why is it called yajuḥunna (derived from the Yajurveda); or why does it become a request; or why do the aupamanyavas (experts in etymology) lead the yajūṃṣi (verses of Yajurveda) to this?

sloka: yajati codanādravyadevatākriyaṃ samudāye kṛtārthatvāt
translation: The one who performs the ritual activity involving the appointment of sacrificial materials to the divine entity, is endowed with a complete purpose in this context (of the sacrifice).

sloka: yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ| yajñaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ dravyaṃ devatā tyāgaḥ
translation: We will explain the sacrificial ritual, referring to it as an offering of goods to the deity.

sloka: yajñaḥ |
translation: The (masculine, singular) sacrifice (nominative).

sloka: suvṛttasya śarīrantu vyadhamanmukhavāyunā | svayameva jagatmraṣṭā dakṣiṇāgnistato'bhavat ||kanakasya śarīrantu dhmāpayāmāsa keśavaḥ | tato'bhūdgārhapatyāgniḥ pañcavaitānabhojanaḥ ||ghorasya tu vapuḥ śambhurdhmāpayāmāsa vai svayam | tata āhavanīyo'gnistatkṣaṇāt samajāyata ||etaistribhirjagat vyāptaṃ trimūlaṃ sakalaṃ jagat | etat yatra trayaṃ nityaṃ tiṣṭhati dbijasattamāḥ |
translation: For one of virtuous conduct, the Lord of the universe has become, through the western wind, the degrader of the body. Keśava himself has made the household fire arise from the oblation of the golden body. Śambhu has personally made the āhavanīya fire arise from the degradation of the dreadful form. With these three, the entire universe is pervaded, its triple root is established; where the best of the seeds always reside.

sloka: evaṃ yajñavarāhasya śarīraṃ yajñatāmagāt | yajñarūpeṇa sakalamāpyāyitumidaṃ jagat ||
translation: In this way, the whole universe is fulfilled by assuming the form of the sacrificer's body, which is the essence of the finest sacrificial rituals.

sloka: devatoddeśena hi dravyatyāgo yāgaḥ| sa eva tyajyamānadravyasyāgnau prakṣepāddhoma ityucyate|
translation: The ritual (yāgaḥ) known as dravyatyāga, which is the giving up of resources indicated by devatoddeśena, is described as the casting of the relinquished resource into the fire.

sloka: upaviṣṭahomā svāhākārapradānā juhotayaḥ
translation: The oblation has been offered, addressed as "svaha," along with the ritual conclusion.

sloka: savaṣaṭkārāsu tiṣṭhandakṣiṇata udaṅprāṅ vaṣaṭkṛte
translation: In the rites involving six types of offerings, remain attentive when invited with the Vaṣaṭ mantra.

sloka: darśapūrṇamāsayoścatvāra ṛtvijo'dhvaryurbrahmā hotāgnīdhra iti
translation: The four ṛtvijs – adhvaryu, brahmā, hotā, and āgnīdhra – who have completed the darśa and pūrṇamāsa rituals.

sloka: pākayajñānyajennityaṃ haviryajñāṃśca nityaśaḥ | somāṃśca vidhipūrveṇa ya iccheddharmamavyayam|
translation: "Should one always offer oblations in the fire sacrifice known as pākayajña, and likewise in haviryajña, regularly; and should one wish to follow the unchanging dharmic path, they should also offer soma according to the established rule."

sloka: paśūnāṃ dravyahaviṣāmṛksāmayajuṣāṃ tathā| ṛtvijāṃ dakṣiṇāyāśca saṃyogo yajña ucyate|| ||
translation: The union of sacrificial ingredients belonging to animals, plants, and other substances is called a yajña (sacrifice) in the same way that the union of ṛtvijs (officiants) is. It is also known as dakṣiṇā (fee or reward).

sloka: ayajño vā eṣaḥ | yo'patnīkaḥ |
translation: "Indeed, this one (ayajñaḥ) has not performed the fire sacrifice or is unsociable (apatnīkaḥ)."

sloka: vrīhīnyavānvā haviṣi
translation: Barley and wheat, where are they for the offering?

sloka: pāṇigrahaṇādiragnistamaupāsanamityācakṣate tasmingṛhyāṇi karmāṇi kriyante tasyaupāsanenāhitāgnitvaṃ
translation: The scripture states that the rituals from 'pāṇigrahaṇa' to 'agni' are called 'upāsana'. When performed, they lead to the extinguishing of that 'agni' (inner fire).

sloka: tatra ca sapta pākayajñasaṃsthāḥ aupāsanahomo vaiśvadevaṃ pārvaṇa maṣṭakā māsiśrāddhaṃ sarpabaliṃ rīśānabaliriti |
translation: There, the seven domestic sacrifices are established: the Aupasana and Homa fires, the Vaiśvadeva, Pārvaṇa, Maṣṭakā-Māsiśrāddha, Sarpa-Bali, and Rīśabha-Baliriti.

sloka: athātaḥ pañcayajñāḥ devayajño bhūtayajñaḥ pitṛyajño brahmayajño manuṣyayajña iti tadyadagnau juhoti sa devayajño yadbaliṅkaroti sa bhūtayajño yatpitṛbhyo dadāti sa pitṛyajño yatsvādhyāyamadhīyate sa brahmayajño yanmanuṣyebhyo dadāti sa manuṣyayajña iti tānetānyajñānaharahaḥ kurvīta
translation: Then, he should perform the five sacrifices: the sacrifice to the gods is what he offers in the fire; the sacrifice to beings is what he gives as alms; the sacrifice to ancestors is what he gives to them; the sacrifice of studying and teaching the Vedas is what one studies and teaches; the sacrifice to people is what he gives to them.

sloka: vidārite varāhasya kāye bhargeṇa tatkṣaṇāt | brahmaviṣṇuśivā devāḥ sarvaiśca pramathaiḥ saha | ninyurjalāt samuddhṛtya tat śarīraṃ nabhaḥ prati | tadvibhejuḥ śarīrantu viṣṇoścakreṇa khaṇḍaśaḥ | tasyāṅga sandhito yajñājātāste vai pṛthakpṛthak | yasmād yasmācca ye yajñāstat śṛṇvantu maharṣayaḥ| bhrūnāsāsandhinā jāto jyotiṣṭomo mahādhvaraḥ | hanuśravaṇasandhyostu vahniṣṭomo vyajāyata | cakṣurbhruvoḥ sandhinā tu vrātyastomo vyajāyata | āyuḥ paugarbhavastomastasya potroṣṭha sandhinā | vṛddhastoma vṛhatstomau jihvāmūlādvyajāyata | atirātraṃ savairājamadhojihvāntarādabhūt | adhyāpanaṃ brahmayajñaḥ pidvayajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo valibhauto nṛyajño'tidhipajatam | snānaṃ tarpaṇaparvyantaṃ nityayajñāśca sāṃśaḥ | kaṇṭhasandheḥ samutpannā jihvāto vidhayastathā | yavājimedho mahāmedho naramedhastathaiva ca | prāṇihiṃsākarā ye'nye te kṣātāḥ pādasandhitaḥ | rājasūyo'tha kārīrī vājapeyastathaivaca | pṛṣṭhasandhau samutpannā grahayajñāstathaiva ca |
translation:
In this manner, the deities Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, along with all the ghosts, have at once extracted the body of Varaha from the water. They trembled in fear of its limbs, as they were torn apart by Viṣṇu's discus. The yajnas (sacrificial rites) that originated from his limbs are well-known to the great sages. Jyotiṣṭoma and other Ājā sacrifices emerged from his nasal area; Vahniṣṭoma arose from the union of the speech and ear regions; Vṛātyastoma was born from the eye and eyebrow region; Āyustoma originated from the throat region; and Vṛddhastoma, Vṛhatstoma emerged from the root of the tongue. The great Adhyāpana sacrifice arose from between the two rows of teeth, while other sacrifices such as Atirātra were born in various parts of his body.

The Brahmayajña is performed with knowledge, Pidvayajña for offspring, Tarpaṇa for ancestors, Homa to please deities, and Valibhauta sacrifice for all beings. The Nṛyajñas are dedicated to human needs. Snāna (bath) and other rites related to Tarpaṇa constitute the daily sacrifices.

The Yavājimedha is a great sacrifice, Naramedha a still greater one, while Prāṇihiṃsākarā and others are performed in various ways. The Rājasūya is dedicated to royal consecration; Kārīrī denotes the Vājapeya rite; Grahayajñas are related to planets; and sacrifices are also performed during eclipses and other celestial phenomena, as well as in various seasons.

sloka: evaṃ yaḥ sarvabhūtāni brāhmaṇo nityaṃ arcati | sa gacchati paraṃ sthānaṃ tejomūrtiḥ pathā rjunā | | | |
translation: The brahmana who constantly worships all beings in this way, attains the radiant form and goes to the supreme abode.

sloka: agnau gurāvātmani ca sarvabhūteṣvadhokṣajam | bhūtaiḥ svadhāmabhiḥ paśyedapraviṣṭaṃ praviṣṭavat || || evaṃ vidho brahmacārī vānaprastho yatirgṛhī | caran viditavijñānaḥ paraṃ brahmādhigacchati || ||
translation: In the fires and in the revered self, as well as in all beings, one should perceive the imperishable Atman. The embodied being sees it entering and exiting (the bodies) through the vital breaths. Thus, a student who has understood this and is pure becomes a forest-dweller, ascetic, or householder; such a person, with knowledge gained from experience, reaches the ultimate Brahman.

sloka: ya॒masya̭ mā ya॒myaṃ kāma॒ āga̭ntsamā॒ne yonaṷ saha॒śeyyā̭ya | jā॒yeva॒ patyḙ ta॒nva̭ṃ riricyā॒ṃ vi ci̭dvṛheva॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: In the battle of life, who wouldn't engage in enmity against death, seeking to be born again with their spouse, just like in a Vedic ritual or a chariot race?

sloka: na ti̭ṣṭhanti॒ na ni mi̭ṣantye॒te de॒vānā॒ṃ spaśa̭ i॒ha ye cara̭nti | a॒nyena॒ madā̭hano yāhi॒ tūya॒ṃ tena॒ vi vṛ̭ha॒ rathyḙva ca॒krā ||
translation: "The gods do not welcome nor recognize those who, acting meanly, roam here; approach the divine assembly with a sacrificial offering, you will be uplifted and honored there."

sloka: ā ghā॒ tā ga̭cchā॒nutta̭rā yu॒gāni॒ yatra̭ jā॒maya̭: kṛ॒ṇava॒nnajā̭mi | upa̭ barbṛhi vṛṣa॒bhāya̭ bā॒huma॒nyami̭cchasva subhage॒ pati॒ṃ mat ||
translation: O fortunate one, become eager to perform the yuga sacrifices at that place where the churning of the ocean of milk took place. Approach Bhumi, the wife of Vishnu, as a bridgeroom, O handsome one.

sloka: na vā ṷ te ta॒nvā̭ ta॒nvaṃ saṃ pa̭pṛcyāṃ pā॒pamā̭hu॒ryaḥ svasā̭raṃ ni॒gacchā̭t | a॒nyena॒ matpra॒muda̭: kalpayasva॒ na te॒ bhrātā̭ subhage vaṣṭye॒tat ||
translation: Should not you, oh delight of friends, lay claim to your brother's property with a false pretext, but arrange it through appropriate means? Surely, it is not befitting for you.

sloka: ayane viṣuve caiva ṣaḍaśītimukheṣu ca| candrasūryoparāge ca dattamakṣayamucyate||
translation: In the two junctions of the year, at sixteenth day-parts (of the lunar month) and at the meeting of the sun and moon, it is declared to have been given and made imperishable.

sloka: śatamindukṣaye dānaṃ sahasrantu dinakṣaye | viṣuve śatasahasraṃ vyatīpātetvantakam ||
translation: A hundred Indus, given in the waning moon period, a thousand at the sunset, during a universal deluge, a hundred times a thousand to ward off calamities.

sloka: kṛttikāsu mahābhāge pāyasena sasarpiṣā| santarpya brāhmaṇānsādhū~llokānāpnotyanuttamān||
translation: Having offered oblations of payasam (sweet rice pudding) to the constellation of Kritika, the highly fortunate one should appease the virtuous Brahmins and then attain the supreme world.

sloka: āhāraṃ maithunaṃ nidrāṃ sandhyākāle tu varjjayet | karma cādhyayanañcaiva tathā dānapratigrahau |
translation: In the period of sandhyā, one should abstain from eating, sexual activity, and sleep. One should also refrain from actions, studying, and giving/receiving at that time.

sloka: tato'bhūttrivṛdaoṃkāro yo'vyaktaprabhavaḥ svarāṭyattalliṅgaṃ bhagavato brahmaṇaḥ paramātmanaḥ ||
translation: The one who arose as the distinct sound Om before the creation, who is self-existent and has an indescribable form, is the supreme self of the divine Brahman.

sloka: svadhāmno brāhmaṇaḥ sākṣādvācakaḥ paramātmanaḥ sa sarvamantropaniṣadvedabījaṃ sanātanam ||
translation: The brahmin, manifesting the Self's abode in person, is indeed the eternal seed of all mantras and Upanishads.

sloka: tenāsau caturo vedāṃścaturbhirvadanairvibhuḥ savyāhṛtikānsaoṃkārāṃścāturhotravivakṣayā || ||
translation: By this, he (the Sun god) illuminates the four Vedas with his four radiant faces.

sloka: te paramparayā prāptāstattacchiṣyairdhṛtavrataiḥ caturyugeṣvatha vyastā dvāparādau maharṣibhiḥ || ||
translation: These (te) have been directly received through the traditional lineage, the teachings adhered to by the disciples in the four yugas, previously passed down by great sages in the dvapara age.

sloka: parāśarātsatyavatyāmaṃśāṃśakalayā vibhuḥ avatīrṇo mahābhāga vedaṃ cakre caturvidham || asmin yuge kṛto vyāsaḥ pārāśaryaḥ parantapaḥ| dvaipāyana iti khyāto viṣṇoraṃśaḥ prakīrtitaḥ ||
translation: Born of Parāśara and Satyavatī, the all-powerful one took on a bodily form, creating the fourfold Veda in this age. Vyāsa, known as Dvaipāyana, born into the lineage of Viṣṇu, you performed the dutiful task in this era.

sloka: tatrargvedadharaḥ pailaḥ sāmago jaiminiḥ kaviḥ | vaiśaṃpāyana evaiko niṣṇāto yajuṣāmuta || || atharvāṅ‌girasāmāsīt sumanturdāruṇo muniḥ |
translation: Among them, the guardian of the Rigveda is Paila, and Jaimini of the Samaveda; Vaisampayana alone is well-versed in the Yajurveda; a sage named Sumantu has deeply mastered the Atharvangirasa.

sloka: pādenārthena copetā vṛttabaddhā mantrā ṛcaḥ| gītirūpā mantrāḥ sāmāni| vṛttagītivarjitatvena praśliṣṭapaṭhitā mantrā yajūṃṣi|
translation: Oh ārtha, along with the pāda, you should recite the mantras and ṛcas that are bound by vṛtta. The gīti and rūpā mantras are sāmāni. The mantras, which are causal present participle of varjita, are specially established when they are not connected with yajūṃṣi, through the instrumental singular mantrā.

sloka: śabdātirikta śabdopajīvipramāṇātiriktaṃ ca yatpramāṇaṃ tajjanyapramitiviṣayānatiriktārthako yo yastadanyatve sati āmuṣmikasukhajanakoccāraṇakatve sati janyajñānājanyo yo pramāṇaśabdastattvaṃ vedatvam iti ca prācīnastallakṣaṇamuktam |
translation: That which is a means of valid knowledge, separate from words and dependent on words, such a means of valid knowledge is called "jnyana-pramana" in the context of discussing the object of cognition of hetu (reason) in inference. This has been classically defined in ancient texts. The word that signifies this means of valid knowledge becomes "veda" (true knowledge) when it leads to the realization of the self, which is distinct from other objects and causes happiness, knowledge, and experience.

sloka: ṛcāṃ tva: poṣamāste pupuṣvāngāyatraṃ tvo gāyati śakvarīṣu | brahmā tvo vadati jātavidyāṃ yajñasya mātrāṃ vi mimīta u tvaḥ ||
translation: You, who have nourished the ṛcas (hymns) in the past, now sing in the Śakvarīs (a group of songs). Brahmā speaks of your acquired knowledge. You also set the measure for the yajña (sacrifice).

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda ātharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśirdaivo
translation: Indeed, the fourth is named Rigveda, Yajurveda the second, the third Samaveda, and  Atharvana; the fifth, rooted in tradition, is called Itihasa-Purana, as the ancestral one among the Vedas, and Dvaivo (two gods or sacred texts).

sloka: purāṇaṃ pañcamo veda iti brahmānuśāsanam
translation: The fifth Veda, as proclaimed by Brahma, is the ancient Purana.

sloka: ṛgyajuḥsāmātharvākhyā vedāścatvāra uddhṛtāḥ | itihāsapurāṇaṃ ca pañcamo veda ucyate || ||
translation: The four Vedas known as Rig, Yajur, Sama, and Atharva have been extracted. The fifth Veda is said to be the collection of itihāsa and purāṇa.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca | taṃ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭamaśrupūrṇākulekṣaṇam | viṣīdantamidaṃ vākyamuvāca madhusūdanaḥ || ||
translation: Sanjaya, filled with compassion, spoke to him in that manner. Madhusudana, his eyes filled with tears, spoke these words in a dejected state.

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | kutastvā kaśmalamidaṃ viṣame samupasthitam | anāryajuṣṭamasvargyamakīrtikaramarjuna || ||
translation: The Blessed One said, "Whence has this impurity befallen you, O Arjuna, in this critical situation? This is unbefitting of a non-Aryan and leads to infamy, not to heaven."

sloka: kla‍aibyaṃ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitattvayyupapadyate | kṣudraṃ hṛdayadaurbalyaṃ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa || ||
translation: Don't go for cowardice, Pārtha. This does not befit you. Give up this small-hearted weakness and rise, scorcher of foes.

sloka: arjuna uvāca | kathaṃ bhīṣmamahaṃ saṃkhye droṇaṃ ca madhusūdana | iṣubhiḥ prati yotsyāmi pūjārhāvarisūdana || ||
translation: Arjuna said, "How should I fight against Bhishma and Drona in battle, O Madhusudana, with arrows, as they are worthy of worship?"

sloka: gurūnahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śreyo bhoktuṃ bhaikṣyamapīha loke | hatvārthakāmāṃstu gurūnihaiva bhuñjīya bhogān rudhirapradigdhān || ||
translation: By depriving the great masters of their wealth, one may only enjoy a meager living in this world. But by indulging such greedy desires, one should partake of pleasures stained with blood herein, only after becoming a consumer of alms himself.

sloka: na caitadvidmaḥ kataranno garīyo yadvā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ | yāneva hatvā na jijīviṣāmas te'vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ || ||
translation: We indeed do not know which one is superior or if we will conquer, or they will conquer us. Even if we were to kill them, we wouldn't desire to live, having been positioned in front of the Dhārtarāṣṭras.

sloka: kārpaṇyadoṣopahatasvabhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṃ dharmasammūḍhacetāḥ | yacchreyaḥ syānniścitaṃ brūhi tanme śiṣyaste'haṃ śādhi māṃ tvāṃ prapannam || ||
translation: Afflicted by avarice and confusion about duty, I ask you: please tell me decisively what is the best course of action for me. I am your disciple; guide me, who has sought refuge in you.

sloka: na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyādya cchokamucchoṣaṇamindriyāṇām | avāpya bhūmāvasapatnamṛddhaṃ rājyaṃ surāṇāmapi cādhipatyam || ||
translation: I do not see, in fact, anyone who could surpass me in restraining the senses from their objects, for having attained a prosperous kingdom and supremacy over even the gods, I am unrivaled.

sloka: sañjaya uvāca evamuktvā hṛṣīkeśaṃ guḍākeśaḥ parantapa | na yotsya iti govindamuktvā tūṣṇīṃ babhūva ha || ||
translation: Sanjaya, having spoken to Hrishikesha, said: "I will not fight," and fell silent, O Govinda.

sloka: tamuvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasanniva bhārata | senayorubhayormadhye viṣīdantamidaṃ vacaḥ || ||
translation: The Lord, Hrsikesa, spoke to him in the midst of both armies, a smile on his face, as did Bharama before. He said this word...

sloka: śrībhagavānuvāca | aśocyānanvaśocastvaṃ prajñāvādāṃśca bhāṣase | gatāsūnagatāsūṃśca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ || ||
translation: The blessed Lord said, "Why do you sorrow for what is unsorrowful, and speak words of wisdom? The wise do not grieve for the departed or for those who have not departed."

sloka: na tvevāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ | na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayamataḥ param || ||
translation: Never indeed was I, you, or any of these kings; nor in the future will any of us exist separate from each other.

sloka: dehino'sminyathā dehe kaumāraṃ yauvanaṃ jarā | tathā dehāntaraprāptirdhīrastatra na muhyati || ||
translation: The embodied being in this body experiences youth, aging, and also the transition to a new body; yet, unconfused, remains aware of the eternal consciousness therein.

sloka: mātrāsparśāstu kaunteya śītoṣṇasukhaduḥkhadāḥ | āgamāpāyino'nityāstāṃstitikṣasva bhārata || ||
translation: "Contact with sensory objects, Kaunteya, such as heat and cold, pleasure and pain, are transient and ephemeral. You must strive to endure them, O Bharata."

sloka: yaṃ hi na vyathayantyete puruṣaṃ puruṣarṣabha | samaduḥkhasukhaṃ dhīraṃ so'mṛtatvāya kalpate || ||
translation: The one who is not troubled by these (events) affects the steadfast, even-tempered man, imbued with both pleasure and pain, as tending towards immortality.

sloka: nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ | ubhayorapi dṛṣṭo'ntastvanayostattvadarśibhiḥ || ||
translation: For those who truly see, there is no existence in the unreal or nonexistence in the real; the nature of both has been realized by the seers as beyond them.

sloka: antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ | anāśino'prameyasya tasmādyudhyasva bhārata || ||
translation: "These perishable bodies have been spoken of as belonging to the eternal self. Therefore, O Bharata, strive for that which is immeasurable and indestructible."

sloka: ya enaṃ vetti hantāraṃ yaścainaṃ manyate hatam | ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṃ hanti na hanyate || ||
translation: The one who knows the killer, and thinks of him as having been killed - neither of these two understands correctly. He does not kill, nor is he killed.

sloka: na jāyate mriyate vā kadācinnāyaṃ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ | ajo nityaḥ śāśvato'yaṃ purāṇo na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre || ||
translation: "It is never born nor dies, having become or not becoming in the past, enduring, constant, ancient. Though the body is destroyed, it does not get destroyed."

sloka: vedāvināśinaṃ nityaṃ ya enamajamavyayam |kathaṃ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṃ ghātayati hanti kam || ||
translation: How, O Partha, can someone harm/destroy the imperishable one, who is constantly engaged in upholding the Vedas and is born of immortal nature?

sloka: vāsāṃsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti naro'parāṇi | tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇānyanyāni saṃyāti navāni dehī || ||
translation: Just as a person discards old garments and takes new ones, similarly the embodied soul casts off worn-out bodies and enters into new ones.

sloka: nainaṃ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṃ dahati pāvakaḥ | na cainaṃ kledayantyāpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ || || acchedyo'yamadāhyo'yamakledyo'śoṣya eva ca | nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇuracalo'yaṃ sanātanaḥ || ||
translation:
Not cut by weapons, not burned by fire,
Unwetted by water, not dried by wind,
Indestructible, inviolable, never to be consumed,
Eternal, omnipresent, stable, and immovable,
Such is this imperishable entity.

sloka: avyakto'yamacintyo'yamavikāryo'yamucyate | tasmādevaṃ viditvainaṃ nānuśocitumarhasi || ||
translation: This unmanifest, incomprehensible, and immutable [entity] is declared. Therefore, having known it thus, you should not grieve.

sloka: jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyurdhruvaṃ janma mṛtasya ca | tasmādaparihārye'rthe na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: Indeed, for one who is born, death is certain; and for one who has died, birth is certain again. Therefore, you should not grief over a matter that is unavoidable.

sloka: avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyaktamadhyāni bhārata | avyaktanidhanānyeva tatra kā paridevanā || ||
translation: O Bhārata, why lament over the manifest and unmanifest beings, which have become hidden within their subtle forms?

sloka: āścaryavatpaśyati kaścidena māścaryavadvadati tathaiva cānyaḥ | āścaryavaccainamanyaḥ śa‍ṛṇoti śrutvāpyenaṃ veda na caiva kaścit || ||
translation:
Some see the wondrous as wonderous, and some describe it as such,
While others listen to it as something wondrous, yet not everyone understands.

sloka: dehī nityamavadhyo'yaṃ dehe sarvasya bhārata| tasmātsarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṃ śocitumarhasi || ||
translation: Indeed, O Bharata, this inherent self within all is indestructible and eternal. Therefore, you should not grieve over any beings.

sloka: svadharmamapi cāvekṣya na vikampitumarhasi | dharmyāddhi yuddhācchreyo'nyatkṣatriyasya na vidyate || ||
translation: Even after considering your own dharma, you should not hesitate. For a kshatriya, engaging in a righteous battle is superior to any other action.

sloka: yadṛcchayā copapannaṃ svargadvāramapāvṛtam | sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddhamīdṛśam || ||
translation: "By chance, you wish for the path to heaven to be unobstructed, O Partha. The Kshatriyas find such a battle, bringing happiness to them."

sloka: atha cettvamimaṃ dharmyaṃ saṃgrāmaṃ na kariṣyasi | tataḥ svadharmaṃ kīrtiṃ ca hitvā pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: If you refuse to engage in this righteous battle, then abandoning your own duty and renown, you will incur sin.

sloka: akīrtiṃ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te'vyayām | sambhāvitasya cākīrtirmaraṇādatiricyate || ||
translation: "Even the born ones will mention your disgrace, but for one who is established, their undying fame is told of from the time of death."

sloka: bhayādraṇāduparataṃ maṃsyante tvāṃ mahārathāḥ | yeṣāṃ ca tvaṃ bahumato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam || ||
translation: You will be considered with great esteem by the mighty charioteers who, due to fear of battle, have withdrawn, if you, being highly valued, choose to proceed lightly against them.

sloka: avācyavādāṃśca bahūnvadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ | nindantastava sāmarthyaṃ tato duḥkhataraṃ nu kim || ||
translation: "Those who are close to you will utter inexpressible criticisms and even denigrate your abilities. What could be more distressing than this?"

sloka: hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṃ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm | tasmāduttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛtaniścayaḥ || ||
translation: Even if defeated, you will attain heaven; by conquering, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, O Kaunteya, resolved to fight, arise.

sloka: sukhaduḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau | tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṃ pāpamavāpsyasi || ||
translation: Treating pleasure and pain, gain and loss, and victory and defeat as the same, prepare yourself for battle in this way, you will not incur sin.

sloka: eṣā te'bhihitā sāṃkhye buddhiryoge tvimāṃ śṛṇu | buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karmabandhaṃ prahāsyasi || ||
translation: This, revealed in Sankhya, is your understanding in yoga. Listen, Partha, to the discipline that, when united with it, will allow you to cast off the bond of action through the power of this very insight.

sloka: nehābhikramanāśo'sti pratyavāyo na vidyate | svalpamapyasya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt || ||
translation: Here, there is no downfall nor regret; even a slight observance of one's duty saves one from great fear.

sloka: vyavasāyātmikā buddhirekeha kurunandana | bahuśākhā hyanantāśca buddhayo'vyavasāyinām || ||
translation: O Kurunandana, the resolute-natured intellect is single, but the intellects of those lacking resolve are many and infinite.

sloka: kāmātmānaḥ svargaparā janmakarmaphalapradām | kriyāviśeṣabahulāṃ bhogaiśvaryagatiṃ prati || || bhogaiśvaryaprasaktānāṃ tayāpahṛtacetasām | vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate || ||
translation: Those who have desires as their souls, seeking heaven and fruits of actions as their goal, such a numerous variety of deeds leading to enjoyment and power does not result in steadfastness of intellect in samadhi. For those who are attached and whose intellects are stolen by that (i.e., enjoyment and power), a resolute intellect is not established in samadhi.

sloka: traiguṇyaviṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna | nirdvandvo nityasattvastho niryogakṣema ātmavān || || yāvānartha udapāne sarvataḥ saṃplutodake | tāvānsarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ || || karmaṇyevādhikāraste mā phaleṣu kadācana | mā karmaphalaheturbhūrmā te saṅgo'stvakarmaṇi || ||
translation:
Arjuna, the Vedas pertain to the three gunas, but one who is free from these gunas is truly established in pure consciousness. Unattached and unwavering, such a person transcends duality and material endeavor. 

To what use are extensive scriptural discussions for one who sees that the essence of all is the same? Like a pool of water on a boat, his needs are already fulfilled. For the self-realized scholar, all the Vedas are only as useful as a small well in a floodplain.

Action is your right, never its fruits; let not your attachment be to inaction or to the results of action, Arjuna. O Dhananjaya, be steadfast in yoga, unattached to success or failure. Such evenness of mind is called yoga.

sloka: arjuna uvāca sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava | sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim‌ || ||
translation: Arjuna said: How does the steady-minded person speak, O Keshava? How does he behave and how should he sit or move?

sloka: bhagavañjāyate tīvraṃ cintayānasya suvrata || karmapākaphalaṃ yasminmānuṣairupabhujyate|||| ñāē īṁ ā || āṁ āṣē||||
translation: The blessed one is born from intense contemplation; understand, what is the fruit of action that humans enjoy in him.

sloka: ṛṣiruddālakirdīkṣāmupagamya tataḥ sutam| tvaṃ māmupacarasveti nāciketamabhāṣata||
translation: Having approached the seer, After performing the initiation rites, you (singular) should serve me, he (Nāciketam) said (to him).

sloka: tadā kṣamasveti prārthayamānasyaiva tasya nāciketasya deho gatasatvo bhūmau nyapatat patitaṃ sutaṃ dṛṣṭvā pitāpi kiṃ mayānuṣṭhitaṃ pāpeneti bruvan bhūmau nipapāta
translation: Then, as he was being prayed to for forgiveness, the embodied soul of Naciketas departed. The father, sitting on the ground, saw his son dead. He said, "What have I done through my actions that this calamity has befallen me?"

sloka: na dṛṣyate mānuṣaṃ te vapuḥ
translation: His human form is not visible.

sloka: yasminvṛkṣe supalāśe devaiḥ sampibate yamaḥ | atrā no viśpati: pitā purāṇā~ anu venati ||
translation: In which tree, the sacred fig, does Yama offer oblations to the gods? Here, our ancient progenitor performs his worship.

sloka: tatko vṛtraḥ| megha iti nairuktāḥ | tvāṣṭro'sura ityaitihāsikāḥ | apāṃ ca jyotiṣaśca miśrībhāvakarmaṇo varṣakarma jāyate | tatropamārthena yuddhavarṇā bhavanti |
translation: Who is that vṛtra (enemy) known as megha in the tradition of Nairuktas, and Tvāṣṭra or Asura according to the itihāsa texts? From the mixture of water and light, the act of rainfall is produced. Then, with a comparison to that, names of warlike activities arise.

sloka: jaṭādhīstīvratapā brahmavādisabhāpatiḥ aṅkīkṛtya sriyaṃ cāste gatahrīḥ prākṛte yathā prāyaśaḥ prākṛtāścāpi sriyaṃ rahasi bibhrati | ayaṃ mahāvratadharo bibhrarti sadasi sriyam
translation: The leader of the Brahma vadi sabha, endowed with matted hair and severe austerities, adorns himself with (his own) natural splendor, just as is usual for ordinary people. Even this great observant of vows wears his natural splendor in public.

sloka: nāyamarhati vaikuṇṭha pādamūlopasarpaṇam sambhāvitamatiḥ stabdhaḥ sādhubhiḥ paryupāsitam ataḥ pāpīyasīṃ yonimāsurīṃ yāhi durmate yatheha bhūyo na kartā putra kilbiṣamjajñe tvaṣṭurdakṣiṇādnau dānavīṃ yonimāśritaḥ vṛtra ityabhivikhyāto jñānavijñānasaṃyutaḥ
translation: I do not consider it appropriate to approach the divine abode of Vaikuṇṭha, nor did you instruct me to approach the base of its pillar. Yet, established in your resolute counsel, you stood mute while being worshiped by the virtuous. Therefore, why are you now, O wicked one, going toward the sinful and asuri womb? O unrighteous one, listen: don't you remember that you were born from the purifying union of Tvaṣṭu and his sister Dakṣiṇā, and have been known as Vṛtra, endowed with knowledge and discrimination?

sloka: atṛpṇuvantaṃ viyatamabudhyamabudhyamānaṃ suṣupāṇamindra sapta prati pravata āśayānamahiṃ vajreṇa vi riṇā aparvan
translation: Noticing the wind stirring in the sky, Indra, the wielder of thunder, strikes with his weapon the still unperceived (by others) enemy approaching for the first time.

sloka: samudrajyeṣṭhāḥ salilasya madhyātpunānā yantyaniviśamānāḥ indro yā vajrī vṛṣabho rarāda tā āpo devīrihamāmavantu
translation: Supreme rulers of the ocean, partaking in purifying the water from within and all around, may Indra, the thunderbolt-wielder, the bull, having roared, protect those waters and the goddess Devi as well for us.

sloka: i॒damasmi॒ tatte॒ pra dāsyā॒mīti॒ tvī
translation: I am indeed he to whom you will offer (this) in front.

sloka: āhāranidrābhayamaithunaṃ ca samānametatpaśubhirnarāṇām | dharmo hi teṣāmadhiko viśeṣo dharmeṇa hīnāḥ paśubhiḥ samānāḥ ||
translation: The common activities of eating, sleeping, fear, and procreation for animals and humans; yet, the distinguishing trait for them is a matter of greater adherence to dharma. Those devoid of dharma are comparable to animals.

sloka: ahiṃsā satyam asteyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | etaṃ sāmāsikaṃ dharmaṃ cāturvarṇye'bravīnmanuḥ | | | |
translation: Manu declared to the two social classes the following constituent duty of dharma: non-violence , truthfulness , not stealing , cleanliness , and controlling the senses .

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyam akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: Fortitude, forgiveness, self-control, honesty, purity, mastery of the senses, understanding, wisdom, truthfulness, and absence of anger – these ten are the characteristics of dharma.

sloka: na rājyaṃ na rājā'sīnna daṇḍayo na ca dāṇḍika: dharmeṇaiva prajāssarvā rakṣanti sma parasparam
translation: Neither the kingdom nor the kings nor their punishments, nor the executioners protect people; only through dharma do they all collectively protect each other.

sloka: prajanārthaṃ striyaḥ sṛṣṭāḥ saṃtānārthaṃ ca mānavaḥ | tasmātsādhāraṇo dharmaḥ śrutau patnyā sahoditaḥ | | | |
translation: Women were created for the sake of procreation, and men for the continuity of the lineage. Therefore, the common duty (dharma) for both, as heard in the scriptures, is born along with a wife.

sloka: dharme cārthe ca kāme ca nāticaritavyā tvayeyam |
translation: In duty, in benefit, and in desire, you should not swerve from this path.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntirārjavameva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānamāstikyaṃ brahmakarma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Self-control, restraint, austerity, purity, forbearance, straightforwardness, and indeed, knowledge, understanding, faith – these are the inherent duties of Brahman that are naturally expressed as one’s own nature.

sloka: śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtirdākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpyapalāyanam | dānamīśvarabhāvaśca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Valor, brilliance, steadfastness, and prowess in battle, as well as the tendency to not retreat—all these are the inherent duties of the warrior class, along with generosity and the nature of a lord.

sloka: kṛṣigaurakṣyavāṇijyaṃ vaiśyakarma svabhāvajam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāvajam || ||
translation: Plowing, tending cows, and trading are the inherent duties of a vaishya, while serving others is the inherent duty of a shudra.

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucaṃ indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyaṃ akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: The ten characteristics of dharma are: steadfastness, forgiveness, self-control, non-stealing, cleanliness, mastery of the senses, wisdom, truthfulness, and absence of anger.

sloka: īśā vāsyamidaṃ sarvaṃ yatkiṃ ca jagatyāṃ jagat | tena tyaktena bhuñjīthā mā gṛdhaḥ kasya sviddhanam || ||
translation: With Ishvara (the Supreme Ruler), everything in this world, both moving and non-moving, should be enjoyed, having been acquired through renunciation. Do not covet anyone's wealth.

sloka: paropakārāya phalanti vṛkṣāḥ paropakārāya vahanti nadyaḥ | paropakārāya duhanti gāvaḥ paropakārārthamidaṃ śarīram || satyaṃ vada | dharmañcara | svādhyāyānmā pramadaḥ | ācāryāya priyaṃ dhanamāhṛtya prajātantuṃ mā vyavacchetsīḥ | satyānna pramaditavyam | dharmānna pramaditavyam | kuśalānna pramaditavyam | bhūtyai na pramaditavyam | svādhyāyapravacanābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam || ||
translation: Trees bear fruit for the benefit of others, rivers flow for the benefit of others, cattle graze for the benefit of others - this body also has a purpose. Speak the truth, follow dharma, don't be negligent in your studies. Give wealth to the worthy teacher, but do not neglect your offspring. Do not fail to uphold truth, dharma, auspiciousness, and your studies.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam | mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava | yānyanavadyāni karmāṇi tāni sevitavyāni | no itarāṇi | yānyasmākaṃ sucaritāni | tāni tvayopāsyāni | no itarāṇi || || sukhārthinaḥ kuto vidyā nāsti vidyārthinaḥ sukham | sukhārthī vā tyajedvidyāṃ vidyārthī vā tyajet sukham ||
translation: Do not be negligent toward the duties of the gods and ancestors, performed with good deeds. Treat your mother as a goddess, your father as a god, the teacher as a deity, and guests as manifestations of divinity. Engage in blameless actions and serve them. Avoid other things. Perform those actions that are pleasing to us. Those who seek happiness should not abandon learning; those who value learning should not abandon happiness.

sloka: vivītasthalakedāraṣaṇḍakhalaveśmavāhanakoṣṭhānāṃ pūrvaṃpūrvaṃ ābādhaṃ saheta || || samāhartṛvannāgariko nagaraṃ cintayet || || daśakulīṃ gopo viṃśatikulīṃ catvāriṃśatkulīṃ vā || || sa tasyāṃ strīpuruṣāṇāṃ jātigotranāmakarmabhiḥ jaṅghaagraṃ āyavyayau ca vidyāt || || evaṃ durgacaturbhāgaṃ sthānikaścintayet || ||
translation: When inspecting the dwellings and courtyards, should a city-dweller endure every minor damage in the very beginning. He should reflect on a ten-clan, twenty-clan, or even a thirty-clan settlement. In it, one should know the starting points of the classes, castes, names, and actions of both men and women. Likewise, should one attentively consider a four-part fortress' foundation. What is that (durg)?

sloka: bhūtapūrvaṃ abhūtapūrvaṃ vā janapadaṃ paradeśaapavāhanena svadeśaabhiṣyandavamanena vā niveśayet || ||
translation: Should he establish authority over a country, either by having previously traversed distant lands or, having caused his own subjects to vomit (from excessive taxes), and thus become well-known?

sloka: anyonyaārakṣaṃ niveśayet || ||
translation: Let one settle (others) into mutual protection.

sloka: aṣṭaśatagrāmyā madhye sthānīyam | catuhśatagrāmyā droṇamukham | dviśatagrāmyāḥ kārvaṭikam | daśagrāmīsaṃgraheṇa saṃgrahaṃ sthāpayet || ||
translation: In the context of eight hundred grāmyas, two should be established as the focal points; in four hundred grāmyas, Droṇamukha should be made the central point; in twenty grāmyas, Kārvaṭika should be gathered; and in ten grāmīs, a consolidation should be caused.

sloka: niveśasamakālaṃ yathāāgatakaṃ vā parihāraṃ dadyāt || ||
translation: Just as one should offer appropriate help or accommodation at the appropriate time.

sloka: hradasya vā aviśoṣasyāṅke |
translation: Of the water body's and the drying's, on the surface?

sloka: vṛttaṃ dīrghaṃ caturaśraṃ vā
translation: Was the hermitage made long and square in shape, or otherwise?

sloka: ṣaḍdaṇḍaucchritaṃ avaruddhaṃ taddviguṇaviṣkambham |
translation: Made steady by the rod's six strokes, (now it is) unfettered, with its qualities doubled.

sloka: tasya parikhāstisro daṇḍaantarāḥ kārayetcaturdaśa dvādaśa daśaiti daṇḍānvistīrṇāḥ |
translation: Of those rods within (the body of) him, three are (called) parikhās, while fourteen are the daṇḍas, (measuring) twelve, ten, and six angulas each.

sloka: trayaḥ prācīnā rājamārgāstraya udīcīnā iti vāstuvibhāgaḥ || ||
translation: The three eastern royal paths and the three northern ones are known as divisions of the route.

sloka: daśakulīvāṭaṃ kūpasthānaṃ || ||
translation: a ten-clan settlement, or a commonplace for lower classes; as the object.

sloka: pitṝṇāṃ māsikaṃ śrāddhaṃ anvāhāryaṃ vidurbudhāḥ || ||
translation: The monthly ritual of the ancestors, consisting of offerings brought near and performed by the wise.

sloka: ṛṣayaḥ pitaro devā bhūtānyatithayastathā | āśāsate kuṭumbibhyastebhyaḥ kāryaṃ vijānatā || ||
translation: Rishis, fathers, and deities along with beings of ancient times enjoin: "Knowing your duties toward the family members and others, you should act."

sloka: daivakāryāddvijātīnāṃ pitṛkāryaṃ viśiṣyate | daivaṃ hi pitṛkāryasya pūrvaṃ āpyāyanaṃ smṛtam
translation: The religious duty for the dvijatins is superior; indeed, the nourishment of the pitrkarya is considered to be previously ordained.

sloka: pitṛyajñaṃ tu nirvartya vipraścandrakṣaye'gnimān | piṇḍānvāhāryakaṃ śrāddhaṃ kuryānmāsānumāsikam || ||
translation: Having performed the pitṛyajña ritual and caused the extinguishing of the sacrificial fire during the lunar eclipse, the brāhmaṇa should perform the offering of piṇḍas, the āhārya portion, and the śrāddha ceremony every month.

sloka: kṛṣṇapakṣe daśamyādau varjayitvā caturdaśīm | śrāddhe praśastāstithayo yathaitā na tathetarāḥ
translation: In the dark fortnight, on the eleventh day, having excluded the fourteenth, at the rite, they should be established as honorable. Unlike these, which are so established, it will not be in such a way for others.

sloka: yukṣu kurvandinarkṣeṣu sarvānkāmānsamaśnute | ayukṣu tu pitṝnsarvānprajāṃ prāpnoti puṣkalām
translation: In favorable circumstances, one experiences all desired objects while performing actions in such seasons and months. But in unfavorable conditions, one acquires abundant offspring by fathers.

sloka: yathā caivāparaḥ pakṣaḥ pūrvapakṣādviśiṣyate | tathā śrāddhasya pūrvāhṇādaparāhṇo viśiṣyate
translation: Just as the later argument stands out from the previous one, so does the pre- and post-scripture rites of the shraddha ceremony.

sloka: rātrau śrāddhaṃ na kurvīta rākṣasī kīrtitā hi sā | sandhyayorubhayoścaiva sūrye caivācirodite
translation: In the night, one should not perform the śrāddha ritual, for it has been described as demonic. This applies to both sandhyas and when the sun has risen shortly before.

sloka: anena vidhinā śrāddhaṃ trirabdasyeha nirvapet | hemantagrīṣmavarṣāsu pāñcayajñikamanvaham
translation: With this procedure, one should offer the shraddha ritual three times in the current life, during the hemanta and grishma seasons, as well as on every panchayajnika day.

sloka: kuryād āparapakṣīyaṃ māsi prauṣṭhapade dvijaḥ | śrāddhaṃ pitroryathāvittaṃ tad‍bandhūnāṃ ca vittavān || ||
translation: A twice-born should perform in the opposite camp a sacrifice in the spring season on the full moon day . He should also perform the śrāddha ritual for his ancestors and give wealth to his relatives .

sloka: saṃskārakālo jāyāyā apatyasyātmanastathā | pretasaṃsthā mṛtāhaśca karmaṇyabhyudaye nṛpa || ||
translation: Time of rituals, O king, for the wife and her offspring's self, and for the deceased and the departed; at the manifestation of actions, dual.

sloka: kuryādaharahaḥ śrāddhaṃ annādyenodakena vā | payomūlaphalairvāpi pitṛbhyaḥ prītimāvahan || ||
translation: Should a daily rite offering be made to the ancestors using food and drink, or even with water and fruit, so as to bring them pleasure?

sloka: tilairvrīhiyavairmāṣairadbhirmūlaphalena vā | dattena māsaṃ tṛpyanti vidhivatpitaro nṛnām
translation: With sesame, rice, barley, and beans, as well as with water, given according to custom, fathers of men are sated.

sloka: yadeva tarpayatyadbhiḥ pitṝnsnātvā dvijottamaḥ | tenaiva kṛtsnaṃ āpnoti pitṛyajñakriyāphalam rājatairbhājanaireṣāṃ atho vā rajatānvitaiḥ | vāryapi śraddhayā dattaṃ akṣayāyopakalpate
translation: When the most excellent of the twice-born, by satisfying the forefathers with ablutions, partakes of them, then indeed he attains fulfilment of the ritual offering's fruit. Moreover, that which is given with faith, even if it be little, becomes inexhaustible for him.

sloka: aparāhṇastathā darbhā vāstusaṃpādanaṃ tilāḥ | sṛṣṭirmṛṣṭirdvijāścāgryāḥ śrāddhakarmasu saṃpadaḥ
translation: At dusk, the arrangement of darbha grass and preparation of the ritual site are indeed the foremost duties of the twice-born. Such is the endowment in performing Sraddha rituals.

sloka: api naḥ sa kule bhūyādyo no dadyāttrayodaśīm | pāyasaṃ madhusarpirbhyāṃ prākchāye kuñjarasya ca yatkiṃ cinmadhunā miśraṃ pradadyāttu trayodaśīm | tadapyakṣayaṃ eva syādvarṣāsu ca maghāsu ca
translation: Even if someone from our lineage, becoming more prevalent, were to give us the eleventh day's offering - a rice pudding mixed with honey and sesame seeds, or any other sweet concoction - it would only amount to its consumption. It would not increase our prosperity during the Magha (lunar month) or any other time. You (singular), however, should perform the rite of sprinkling (of water) at that time.

sloka: yadyaddadāti vidhivatsamyakśraddhāsamanvitaḥ | tattatpitṝṇāṃ bhavati paratrānantamakṣayam
translation: If one gives, in accordance with duty and complete devotion, then indeed becomes infinite and unending for the ancestors.

sloka: teṣāmārakṣabhūtaṃ tu pūrvaṃ daivaṃ niyojayet | rakṣāṃsi hi vipralumpanti śrāddhamārakṣavarjitam daivādyantaṃ tadīheta pitrādyantaṃ na tadbhavet | pitrādyantaṃ tvīhamānaḥ kṣipraṃ naśyati sānvayaḥ
translation: For those, the previous divine ordinance ought to be established as their protector. For, the protectors, when the shraddha-ritual is not observed, tend to abandon (their duties). That (protection) extending from divinity to ancestors should never cease; otherwise, one who neglects it will soon perish along with his lineage.

sloka: śuciṃ deśaṃ viviktaṃ ca gomayenopalepayet | dakṣināpravaṇaṃ caiva prayatnenopapādayet avakāśeṣu cokṣeṣu jalatīreṣu caiva hi | vivikteṣu ca tuṣyanti dattena pitaraḥ sadā
translation: You should sprinkle a clean and secluded place with cow dung. Also, you should make it inclined towards the south with deliberate effort. Moreover, in all open spaces, on riverbanks, etc., one finds pleasure in giving generously in secluded places. Fathers are always pleased with such generous gifts.

sloka: āsaneṣūpaklpteṣu barhiṣmatsu pṛthakpṛthak | upaspṛṣṭodakānsamyagviprāṃstānupaveśayet upaveśya tu tānviprānāsaneṣvajugupsitān | gandhamālyaiḥ surabhibhirarcayeddaivapūrvakam
translation: On separate, unevenly prepared sacrificial seats, he should cause the priests to be seated with water previously touched, and those same priests on separately prepared, unsullied seats. He should honor them with fragrant garlands and pleasing scents, in accordance with divine tradition.
