sloka: yeṣāmudakamānīya sapavitrāṃstilānapi | agnau kuryādanujñāto brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaiḥ saha
translation: Of whom (neuter genitive plural) the water is to be fetched, even their impure stone platforms, a Brahmin, authorized by other Brahmins, should make offerings in the fire.

sloka: agneḥ somayamābhyāṃ ca kṛtvāpyāyanamāditaḥ | havirdānena vidhivatpaścātsaṃtarpayetpitṝn agnyabhāve tu viprasya pāṇāvevopapādayet | yo hyagniḥ sa dvijo viprairmantradarśibhirucyate na paitṛyajñiyo homo laukike'gnau vidhīyate | na darśena vinā śrāddhamāhitāgnerdvijanmanaḥ
translation: After performing the Soma sacrifice along with Agni, one should make offerings and satisfy the ancestors according to the scriptural rules. For a priest, his life depends on the fire in the absence of which no ritual is performed without a Darshapurnamasa ritual. The fire, revered by priests as Dvija, is not used for domestic rituals or for the Paitryajna. Just as life depends on breath, so does a priest's existence depend on the fire.

sloka: apasavyamagnau kṛtvā sarvamāvṛtya vikramam | apasavyena hastena nirvapedudakaṃ bhuvi trīṃstu tasmāddhaviḥśeṣātpiṇḍānkṛtvā samāhitaḥ | audakenaiva vidhinā nirvapeddakṣiṇāmukhaḥ
translation: Having turned to the left towards the fire, having accomplished all actions and having offered the oblation with the left hand, one should offer water three times on the ground. Then, after making the remnants of the offering, being fully focused, he should, with regard to the concluding portion of the ritual, offer it with the audaka (a specific type of water) as per the prescribed method, facing south.

sloka: nyupya piṇḍāṃstatastāṃstu prayato vidhipūrvakam | teṣu darbheṣu taṃ hastaṃ nirmṛjyāllepabhāginām
translation: Having prepared himself, the one should place the rice balls there in a prescribed manner. Having cleaned the hand with those [grass blades], he should offer them to the participants.

sloka: ācamyodakparāvṛtya trirāyamya śanairasūn | ṣaḍṛtūṃśca namaskuryātpitṝneva ca mantravat
translation: After respectfully sipping water three times, having carefully controlled breaths, one should offer obeisance to the ancestors as if chanting a mantra.

sloka: udakaṃ ninayeccheṣaṃ śanaiḥ piṇḍāntike punaḥ | avajighrecca tānpiṇḍānyathānyuptānsamāhitaḥ piṇḍebhyastvalpikāṃ mātrāṃ samādāyānupūrvaśaḥ | tāneva viprānāsīnānvidhivatpūrvamāśayet
translation: Desiring to make the waters pure, one by one, carefully and repeatedly at the edge, you should cause those impure (waters) to be abandoned in a manner similar to before. Then, making (the waters) fit for the priests, having made them scanty with a measured amount and in an orderly fashion, you should establish (them).

sloka: dhriyamāṇe tu pitari pūrveṣāṃ eva nirvapet | vipravadvāpi taṃ śrāddhe svakaṃ pitaramāśayet pitā yasya nivṛttaḥ syājjīveccāpi pitāmahaḥ | pituḥ sa nāma saṅkīrtya kīrtayetprapitāmaham pitāmaho vā tacchrāddhaṃ bhuñjītetyabravīnmanuḥ | kāmaṃ vā samanujñātaḥ svayaṃ eva samācaret
translation: When the father is aging, one should perform the funeral rites for the earlier ones. A priest should make him, who has completed his duties, consider his own father as dear. Manu said, "After mentioning the name of the father, he should cause him to be praised; whether it is the grandfather or the great-grandfather, they both should partake in that funeral rite." If authorized, one may personally perform the desired rites.

sloka: teṣāṃ dattvā tu hasteṣu sapavitraṃ tilodakam | tatpiṇḍāgraṃ prayaccheta svadhaiṣāmastviti bruvan
translation: Having given them the sacred water to touch their hands, one should offer this mixture of sesame and water, saying "May this be your svadha." This is the prescribed ritual.

sloka: pāṇibhyāṃ tūpasaṃgṛhya svayamannasya vardhitam | viprāntike pitṝndhyāyanśanakairupanikṣipet ubhayorhastayormuktaṃ yadannamupanīyate | tadvipralumpantyasurāḥ sahasā duṣṭacetasaḥ
translation: By personally taking hold with your two hands of the growth that has been nurtured by him, and then carefully placing it down near the priest during the pitr-tarpanam ritual, you release both of your hands from what is to be offered as food. The malicious demons, with wicked consciousness, quickly snatch away such offerings.

sloka: guṇāṃśca sūpaśākādyānpayo dadhi ghṛtaṃ madhu | vinyasetprayataḥ pūrvaṃ bhūmāveva samāhitaḥ
translation: He should first and foremost prepare with a focused mind, setting out in front of him, curds, milk, ghee, honey, and also vegetables and herbs.

sloka: upanīya tu tatsarvaṃ śanakaiḥ susamāhitaḥ | pariveṣayeta prayato guṇānsarvānpracodayan
translation: Having carefully gathered all [these] teachings, one should cause (someone) to be established in them; activating and arousing all excellent qualities, let him diligently attend to it.

sloka: nāsramāpātayejjātu na kupyennānṛtaṃ vadet | na pādena spṛśedannaṃ na caitadavadhūnayet asraṃ gamayati pretānkopo'rīnanṛtaṃ śunaḥ | pādasparśastu rakṣāṃsi duṣkṛtīnavadhūnanam
translation: Let not arrogance make one cause the downfall of a spiritual guide, nor let him grow angry or speak untruthfully. Let him not use his foot to strike anything animate or inanimate, and nor should he cause anxiety to the spirit of the departed. The touch of his foot is protective for those who are sinful and troubled.

sloka: yadyadroceta viprebhyastattaddadyādamatsaraḥ | brahmodyāśca kathāḥ kuryātpitṝṇāṃ etadīpsitam svādhyāyaṃ śrāvayetpitrye dharmaśāstrāṇi caiva hi | ākhyānānītihāsāṃśca purāṇāni khilāni ca harṣayedbrāhmaṇāṃstuṣṭo bhojayecca śanaiḥśanaiḥ | annādyenāsakṛccaitānguṇaiśca paricodayet
translation: Whatever a priestly person observes, that he should impart without delay; this is the longed-for study and hearing of the scriptures for the ancestors. He should make the narratives, precepts, history, and legends, as well as the wholesome texts, delightful to the brahmins, satisfying them gradually. With food and other things that are primary and not obtained casually, he should uplift these qualities in himself.

sloka: vratasthamapi dauhitraṃ śrāddhe yatnena bhojayet | kutapaṃ cāsanaṃ dadyāttilaiśca vikirenmahīm trīṇi śrāddhe pavitrāṇi dauhitraḥ kutapastilāḥ | trīṇi cātra praśaṃsanti śaucamakrodhamatvarām
translation: Even the established son at the rite of śrāddha should be made to partake with diligence. Who gives a seat, arising from where, along with the lifted tilas? Here, three things are praised as pure for the son at the śrāddha: non-anger, self-control, and enthusiasm.

sloka: brāhmaṇaṃ bhikṣukaṃ vāpi bhojanārthamupasthitam | brāhmaṇairabhyanujñātaḥ śaktitaḥ pratipūjayet
translation: When invited by brahmanas, a mendicant who has arrived for a meal should be respectfully honored by them with their permission and with one's capability.

sloka: sārvavarṇikamannādyaṃ saṃnīyāplāvya vāriṇā | samutsṛjedbhuktavatāmagrato vikiranbhuvi
translation: Let the entirely virtuous one, having caused to be swamped (by the water), subsequently release (it) forward, beginning from what has been consumed; (for) he is scattering (his virtues) on the earth.

sloka: āsapiṇḍakriyākarma dvijāteḥ saṃsthitasya tu | adaivaṃ bhojayecchrāddhaṃ piṇḍam ekaṃ ca nirvapet sahapiṇḍakriyāyāṃ tu kṛtāyāmasya dharmataḥ | anayaivāvṛtā kāryaṃ piṇḍanirvapanaṃ sutaiḥ
translation: Even for a fixed dwija, the ritual of offering food and a single pinda should be performed at the very beginning. The ritual's proper nature, having been completed by oneself, binds one to it. This very act is to be carried out by the sons for offering pinda.

sloka: pṛṣṭvā svaditam ityevaṃ tṛptānācāmayettataḥ | ācāntāṃścānujānīyādabhito ramyatam iti
translation: After inquiring, when one has tasted the sweetness, they should satisfy themselves and cause others to be content as well. Having made them tranquil, one should then approach and order those men (to do something). Such is the proper course of action.

sloka: svadhāstvityeva taṃ brūyurbrāhmaṇāstadanantaram | svadhākāraḥ parā hyāṣīḥ sarveṣu pitṛkarmasu
translation: Indeed, they should declare that one as 'svadhā' (a ritual action dedicated to ancestors). Immediately after, the brāhmaṇas should declare the form of 'svadhā' as supreme in all ancestral rituals.

sloka: tato bhuktavatāṃ teṣāmannaśeṣaṃ nivedayet | yathā brūyustathā kuryādanujñātastato dvijaiḥ
translation: Once they have finished eating, let them (the priests) offer the remainder as prescribed, in the manner stated and carried out by reliable brahmins, who have been authorized.

sloka: pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi pitrye svaditam ityeva vācyaṃ goṣṭhe tu suśṛtam | saṃpannam ityabhyudaye daive rucitam ityapi
translation: In the rite for ancestors, it should be called 'svaditam' (the offering made to fire); in the herd gathering, 'sushritam' (well-spoken of). At the completion of rites, 'sampannam' (accomplished) is considered appropriate; even in the rite for ancestors, it should be called 'svaditam'; in the divine gathering, 'rucitam' (pleasing to mind) is appreciated.

sloka: visṛjya brāhmaṇāṃstāṃstu niyato vāgyataḥ śuciḥ | dakṣiṇāṃ diśamākāṅkṣanyācetemānvarānpitṝn dātāro no'bhivardhantāṃ vedāḥ saṃtatireva ca | śraddhā ca no mā vyagamadbahudeyaṃ ca no'stviti
translation: Having released the brahmins from their duties, pure and resolved, he should desire to approach the southward direction, seeking alms. May those givers of alms increase for us! May the sacred teachings endure perpetually! And may our faith not wane, and instead be established in many places.

sloka: evaṃ nirvapaṇaṃ kṛtvā piṇḍāṃstāṃstadanantaram | gāṃ vipramajamagniṃ vā prāśayedapsu vā kṣipet piṇḍanirvapaṇaṃ ke citparastādeva kurvate | vayobhiḥ khādayantyanye prakṣipantyanale'psu vā
translation: Having laid out the offerings, one should then cause the priest, who is the son of a nobleman or the fire to partake in them. Some promptly consume the remains of the offerings, while others scatter them in the fire or elsewhere.

sloka: pativratā dharmapatnī pitṛpūjanatatparā | madhyamaṃ tu tataḥ piṇḍamadyātsamyaksutārthinī āyuṣmantaṃ sutaṃ sūte yaśomedhāsamanvitam | dhanavantaṃ prajāvantaṃ sāttvikaṃ dhārmikaṃ tathā prakṣālya hastāvācāmya jñātiprāyaṃ prakalpayet | jñātibhyaḥ satkṛtaṃ dattvā bāndhavānapi bhojayet
translation: Designate as the mistress of duty, devoted to her husband, focused on honoring father and ancestor, a middle offering, fully realizing the purpose of the rite, endowed with progeny and strength, righteousness and virtue. After properly honoring kinfolk and feeding relatives, make ready with joined hands and speech, an instruction signifying knowledge; offer the prepared food to the guest as sacred knowledge incarnate.

sloka: uccheṣaṇaṃ tu tattiṣṭhedyāvadviprā visarjitāḥ | tato gṛhabaliṃ kuryāditi dharmo vyavasthitaḥ
translation: "Let him occupy the post of a judge, as long as ascetics and seers have left society. Then, he should perform the ritual of establishing the household. This is how duty becomes established."

sloka: prācīnāvītinā samyagapasavyamatandriṇā | pitryam ā nidhanātkāryaṃ vidhivaddarbhapāṇinā
translation: Performing the final rites for the ancestors, with focused mind and proper procedure, using sacred grass, is what should be done.

sloka: dvau daive pitṛkārye trīnekaikamubhayatra vā | bhojayetsusamṛddho'pi na prasajjeta vistare || || satkriyāṃ deśakālau ca śaucaṃ brāhmaṇasaṃpadaḥ | pañcaitānvistaro hanti tasmānneheta vistaram || ||
translation:
In sacred rites for the gods, offer to three deities with one handful; in rituals for ancestors, to two with one. The prosperous one should also offer in this way, without being excessive.
In both cases, proper conduct, place and time, and cleanliness are crucial. Observing these five factors is what destroys (an obstacle). Therefore, never be excessively elaborate in your actions.

sloka: ekamapyāśayedvipraṃ pitrarthe pāñcayajñike || ||
translation: Should even a single priest be made to stay (as a guest) for the sake of a father during the five sacrificial rituals?

sloka: atyuṣṇaṃ sarvamannaṃ syādbhuñjīraṃste ca vāgyatāḥ | na ca dvijātayo brūyurdātrā pṛṣṭā havirguṇān yāvaduṣmā bhavatyannaṃ yāvadaśnanti vāgyatāḥ | pitarastāvadaśnanti yāvannoktā havirguṇāḥ yadveṣṭitaśirā bhuṅkte yadbhuṅkte dakṣiṇāmukhaḥ | sopānatkaśca yadbhuṅkte tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate | | | |
translation: Let the heated (overly eager) food be consumed by all. Those who are disciplined and desire to eat should do so. The qualities of the offering shouldn't be discussed here. They may eat as long as they don't become overheated. Their ancestors will eat if the offerings' qualities have been stated. If someone eats with a veiled face or eats the southern portion, that action is protective. Indeed, you have eaten and will protect (them).

sloka: jñānotkṛṣṭāya deyāni kavyāni ca havīṃṣi ca || || sahasraṃ hi sahasrāṇāmanṛcāṃ yatra bhuñjate | ekastānmantravitprītaḥ sarvānarhati dharmataḥ || || yatnena bhojayecchrāddhe bahvṛcaṃ vedapāragam | śākhāntagamathādhvaryuṃ chandogaṃ tu samāptikam || || eṣāmanyatamo yasya bhuñjīta śrāddhamarcitaḥ | pitṝṇāṃ tasya tṛptiḥ syācchāśvatī sāptapauruṣī || ||
translation: Offer superior poetry and oblations to the one who is distinguished, for it is there where thousands of hymns are enjoyed. A single individual, well-versed in mantras, is pleased and satisfies all obligations according to dharma. One should carefully feed and offer abundant vedic recitations to the one who has reached the end of the branches and the concluding hymns; adhvaryu and chandogas. This is the least one can do for the one whose shraddha ceremony is being offered, such that their ancestors' satisfaction may last forever.

sloka: mātāmahaṃ mātulaṃ ca svasrīyaṃ śvaśuraṃ gurum | dauhitraṃ viṭpatiṃ bandhuṃ ṛtvigyājyau ca bhojayet || ||
translation: He should honor as mother his mother's sister, along with his father's sister, his own sister, his father-in-law, teacher, son-in-law, maternal uncle, the officiating priests at rituals, and those who are to be feasted.

sloka: jñānaniṣṭhā dvijāḥ ke cittaponiṣṭhāstathāpare | tapaḥsvādhyāyaniṣṭhāśca karmaniṣṭhāstathāpare || || jñānaniṣṭheṣu kavyāni pratiṣṭhāpyāni yatnataḥ | havyāni tu yathānyāyaṃ sarveṣveva caturṣvapi || || dūrādeva parīkṣeta brāhmaṇaṃ vedapāragam | tīrthaṃ taddhavyakavyānāṃ pradāne so'tithiḥ smṛtaḥ || ||
translation:
Among the dvijas, who are steadfast in knowledge and who, respectively, are steadfast in meditation, austerity, learning, and action? One should carefully establish poetic compositions for those focused on knowledge; sacrifices, however, should be established according to rule for everyone, across all four.

A brahmana who has reached the end of the Vedas, an observer of rites, should be examined from a distance as a guest, for giving (such a one) at a tirtha is remembered as atithi.

sloka: na brāhmaṇaṃ parīkṣeta daive karmaṇi dharmavit | pitrye karmaṇi tu prāpte parīkṣeta prayatnataḥ || || aśrotriyaḥ pitā yasya putraḥ syādvedapāragaḥ | aśrotriyo vā putraḥ syātpitā syādvedapāragaḥ || || jyāyāṃsamanayorvidyādyasya syācchrotriyaḥ pitā | mantrasaṃpūjanārthaṃ tu satkāram itaro'rhati || ||
translation: A wise man should not examine a brahmin's conduct in relation to divine duties, but he should carefully scrutinize his conduct in the context of familial duties. The father of a son who is uneducated in the Vedas and engages in forbidden actions is also impure; similarly, such a son becomes impure if his father is uneducated in the Vedas. In terms of superior or equivalent knowledge, the one who knows the Vedas is preferable for performing Vedic rituals; others are suitable only for carrying out menial tasks.

sloka: na śrāddhe bhojayenmitraṃ dhanaiḥ kāryo'sya saṃgrahaḥ | nāriṃ na mitraṃ yaṃ vidyāttaṃ śrāddhe bhojayeddvijam || || yasya mitrapradhānāni śrāddhāni ca havīṃṣi ca | tasya pretya phalaṃ nāsti śrāddheṣu ca haviḥṣu ca || || yaḥ saṃgatāni kurute mohācchrāddhena mānavaḥ | sa svargāccyavate lokācchrāddhamitro dvijādhamaḥ || || saṃbhojāni sābhihitā paiśācī dakṣiṇā dvijaiḥ | ihaivāste tu sā loke gaurandhevaikaveśmani || ||
translation: One should not feast a friend with wealth at a funeral rite, that is his proper observance. One should not feast a woman or a friend at a funeral rite for a Brahmin. For one who makes a feast at a funeral rite of his friends and relatives, there is no fruit after death in funeral rites and offerings. A person who gathers people for a false funeral rite goes to a lower grade in heaven; such is the degraded Brahmin who eats the offerings at a false funeral rite. The gifts given at a false funeral rite are impure, spoken of as such by the learned. They exist here in this very world, like a cow in a blind enclosure.

sloka: etānvigarhitācārānapāṅkteyāndvijādhamān | dvijātipravaro vidvānubhayatra vivarjayet brāhmaṇo tvanadhīyānastṛṇāgniriva śāmyati | tasmai havyaṃ na dātavyaṃ na hi bhasmani hūyate
translation: The wise brahmin should avoid these improper conducts of the lowly twice-born ones, as one would avoid burning trash. One should not give an offering to such a person, for they do not get purified in the ash (i.e., their sins are not absolved).

sloka: avratairyaddvijairbhuktaṃ parivetrādibhistathā | apāṅkteyairyadanyaiśca tadvai rakṣāṃsi bhuñjate
translation: The impious twice-born consume what is offered by those who are not their proper food givers, as well as by outcastes and such; they partake of that very protection (i.e., sustenance).

sloka: somavikrayiṇe viṣṭhā bhiṣaje pūyaśoṇitam | naṣṭaṃ devalake dattamapratiṣṭhaṃ tu vārdhuṣau
translation: To the moon's seller, position the pure blood; given at the sacred place, restore what has been lost, or also the unestablished.

sloka: yattu vāṇijake dattaṃ neha nāmutra tadbhavet |
translation: That which has been given in trade does not become (yours) here or there.

sloka: prathitā pretakṛtyaiṣā pitryaṃ nāma vidhukṣaye | tasminyuktasyaiti nityaṃ pretakṛtyaiva laukikī || ||
translation: This pretakrtya (ritual for the dead) is famously known as pitrya nama, and it is performed in the case of a vidhu's (deceased person's) ksaya (demise). It is always carried out on a regular basis, being laukiki (mundane/worldly), using the designation eti (this is called) for the one who is yuktasya (connected with it).

sloka: śrotriyāyaiva deyāni havyakavyāni dātṛbhiḥ | arhattamāya viprāya tasmai dattaṃ mahāphalam || || ekaikamapi vidvāṃsaṃ daive pitrye ca bhojayet | puṣkalaṃ phalamapnoti nāmantrajñānbahūnapi || || yatheriṇe bījamuptvā na vaptā labhate phalam | tathānṛce havirdattvā na dātā labhate phalam || || dātṝnpratigrahītṝṃśca kurute phalabhāginaḥ | viduṣe dakṣiṇāṃ dattvā vidhivatpretya ceha ca || ||
translation: To the teacher, offerings should be made; such is the highest duty to the worthy priest. Even giving to a single knowing one brings abundant rewards, not to mention many consecrated by mantra knowledge. Like a seed not tended, it bears no fruit; so too, he who doesn't give makes no gain. Giver and recipient share in the reward; after death, giving to the deserving brings merit.

sloka: kāmaṃ śrāddhe'rcayenmitraṃ nābhirūpamapi tvarim | dviṣatā hi havirbhuktaṃ bhavati pretya niṣphalam || ||
translation: In the sacrificial rite, should one cause a friend to offer (the oblation) with longing, even if he is unworthy; for, consumed by an enemy, it becomes futile after death.

sloka: ta ete śreyasaḥ kālā nṝṇāṃ śreyovivardhanāḥ | kuryāt sarvātmanaiteṣu śreyo'moghaṃ tadāyuṣaḥ || || eṣu snānaṃ japo homo vrataṃ devadvijārcanam | pitṛdevanṛbhūtebhyo yad dattaṃ taddhyanaśvaram || ||
translation: These two auspicious times, beneficial for people and promoting their welfare, should one utilize fully for the ultimate benefit. Then, offerings made to them in the form of bathing (ablutions), recitation, fire ritual, vows, and worshiping gods, twice-borns, pitrs, and other beings become permanent.

sloka: ṛtāmṛtābhyāṃ jīvettu mṛtena pramṛtena vā | satyānṛtābhyāṃ api vā na śvavṛttyā kadā cana ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet
translation: Let him choose to live either by the unchanging truth or the changing falsehood; never, however, by a life of deceit. The truly edible and praised elixir is to be known as the pure truth, while what is sought as alms is spoken of as the falsehood that causes weariness. The former is remembered as agriculture, while the latter, trade; one survives through both. Service is known by the name of livelihood based on deceit; therefore, one should certainly avoid it.

sloka: varjayettāṃ sadā vipro rājanyaśca jugupsitām | sarvavedamayo vipraḥ sarvadevamayo nṛpaḥ || ||
translation: The pious Brahmin and noble king should always reject that which is worthy of disgust; a Brahmin who embodies all knowledge, and a king who embodies all deities.

sloka: vṛttiḥ saṅkarajātīnāṃ tattatkulakṛtā bhavet | acaurāṇāmapāpānāmantyajāntevasāyinām || ||
translation: The source of livelihood for the ones born from mixed caste groups is established according to their respective ancestral customs. This remains inescapable for those who commit unrighteous acts and are completely engrossed in them.

sloka: vṛttyā svabhāvakṛtayā vartamānaḥ svakarmakṛt | hitvā svabhāvajaṃ karma śanairnirguṇatāmiyāt || ||
translation: Acting according to one's inherent nature, and being engaged in one's own duty, he should give up his natural tendencies. Approaching a state of being free from qualities, he will achieve it slowly.

sloka: jaghanyo nottamāṃ vṛttimanāpadi bhajennaraḥ | ṛte rājanyamāpatsu sarveṣāmapi sarvaśaḥ || ||
translation: Let a man not choose the inferior path, but rather should he adopt the uttamā (highest) vṛtti. Except for in the case of royal duties, he should serve respectfully towards all in every way.

sloka: kuśūladhānyako vā syātkumbhīdhānyaka eva vā | tryahaihiko vāpi bhavedaśvastanika eva vā caturṇām api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām | jyāyānparaḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavatyeṣāṃ tribhiranyaḥ pravartate | dvābhyām ekaścaturthastu brahmasattreṇa jīvati
translation: Is he a collector of paddy or one who gives it away, or perhaps a user of firewood? Or is he simply content with just enough for himself? Among these four householders who are performing the ritual of gṛhamedha, the one who knows dharma is superior, the most distinguished and foremost. For them, there are six duties that must be performed: three are to be carried out and one is to be abandoned, while two lead to liberation through knowledge of brahman.

sloka: na bhojanārthaṃ sve vipraḥ kulagotre nivedayet | bhojanārthaṃ hi te śaṃsanvāntāśītyucyate budhaiḥ
translation: A householder priest should not offer food with an intent to eat (for himself) in his family; for, such food is called leftovers, as explained by the learned.

sloka: adroheṇaiva bhūtānāṃ alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ | yā vṛttistāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīvedanāpadi yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhiragarhitaiḥ | akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam
translation: By showing kindness even to those who have slight hostility, or once again to those who have greater enmity, a virtuous man should conduct his life, directing his activities towards maintaining his livelihood through actions that earn him praise. He should accumulate wealth without any difficulty, by taking care of his body.

sloka: vartayaṃśca śiloñchābhyāṃ agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ | iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapetsadā na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana | ajihmāṃ aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīvedbrāhmaṇajīvikām saṃtoṣaṃ paraṃ āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet | saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ
translation: Is it not fitting to follow the rites and customs, being always devoted to the agnihotra, and performing only the final libations of the pārvāyaṇī fire? One should never lead a worldly life in this matter. How could one, when performing the purest form of brahminical existence, not wish to live ascetically, being fully satisfied and intent on achieving ultimate happiness? Indeed, satisfaction is the root of happiness, while its opposite leads to unhappiness.

sloka: edhodakaṃ mūlaphalaṃ annaṃ abhyudyataṃ ca yat | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānmadhvathābhayadakṣiṇām āhṛtābhyudyatāṃ bhikṣāṃ purastādapracoditām | mene prajāpatirgrāhyāṃ api duṣkṛtakarmaṇaḥ nāśnanti pitarastasya daśavarṣāṇi pañca ca | na ca havyaṃ vahatyagniryastāṃ abhyavamanyate
translation: In this world, one should accept with reverence the water from the original source, the edible fruits and food offerings that have been prepared and are ready to be offered. This includes accepting gifts of cows and gold from all sides. Prajapati considers it appropriate even for those who have committed misdeeds to partake of this meal. For ten plus five years, the father does not consume these offerings made to him. And Agni does not carry away that which has been properly prepared for sacrifice.

sloka: śayyāṃ gṛhānkuśāngandhānapaḥ puṣpaṃ maṇīndadhi | dhānā matsyānpayo māṃsaṃ śākaṃ caiva na nirṇudet
translation: Let not the bed, houses, Kusha grass, fragrances, water, flowers, minerals, curd, grains, fish, payasam, meat, and vegetables be excluded.

sloka: gurūnbhṛtyāṃścojjihīrṣannarciṣyandevatātithīn | sarvataḥ pratigṛhṇīyānna tu tṛpyetsvayaṃ tataḥ guruṣu tvabhyatīteṣu vinā vā tairgṛhe vasan | ātmano vṛttiṃ anvicchangṛhṇīyātsādhutaḥ sadā
translation: Desiring to serve the teachers, being about to serve the disciples as well, one should always receive gods, guests, and offerings from all sides. One should not become satisfied with oneself; only then should one attend to the duties of the venerable teachers, whether they have passed on or are still present, with those [duties] or without them, in their homes or elsewhere, by seeking after one's own conduct.

sloka: imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavānahamavyayam vivasvānmanave prāha manurikṣvākave'bravīt
translation: I taught this imperishable yoga to Vivasvan, and he passed it on to Manu, who spoke of it to Ikshvaku.

sloka: bhagavo kasmin vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati
translation: Upon knowing him (bhagavan), everything in this world becomes known.

sloka: yattadadreśyamagrāhyamagotramavarṇaṃmacakṣuḥśrotraṃ tadapāṇipādam nityaṃ vibhuṃ sarvagataṃ susūkṣmaṃ tadavyayaṃ yadbhūtayoniṃ paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ
translation: The wise perceive the imperceptible, incomprehensible, unmanifest, uncolored, touchable, with hands and feet, ever-present, all-pervading, extremely subtle, immutable, and origin of all things.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣyaḥ yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavati amataṃ mataṃ avijñātaṃ vijñātaṃ iti
translation: By which the unheard becomes heard, the unsaid known, and the unknown recognized as such, that is the power of this mantra. (Referring to a spiritual teaching or mantra) Use it in this way.

sloka: yathā somyaikena mṛtpiṇḍena sarvaṃ mṛnmayaṃ vijñātaṃ syātvācārambhaṇaṃ vikāro nāmadheyaṃ mṛttiketyeva satyam”
translation: "Just as, O Somya, by knowing a single clay lump, everything made of clay can be known; the process of creation is just nomenclature, 'clay' alone is the truth."

sloka: annamayaṃ hi mana āpomayaḥ prāṇaḥ tejomayī vāk
translation: Indeed, the mind and speech are, in their essential nature, nourishment-made, energy-made, and light-made, respectively.

sloka: svaṃ apīto bhavati tasmāt enamsva pitītyācakṣate
translation: "Hence, one should refer to him as 'father' instead of 'one's own,' for he becomes like one's own."

sloka: sa ya eṣoഽṇimā aitadātmyamidam sarvaṃ tat satyam sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who truly understands this self of all as 'you are that,' O Svetaketu, that is the truth.

sloka: ta iha vyāghro vā siṃho vā vṛko vā varāho vā kīṭo vā pataṅgo vā daṃśo vā maśako vā yadyad bhavanti tadābhavanti’
translation: Is it a tiger , a lion , a wolf , a boar , a bug , a fly , a tooth , or a mosquito that exists here? Whatever it is, if it ceases to exist, something else takes its place.

sloka: śṛṇu nāmāni lokānāṃ mātṝṇāṃ śaṅkarāṇi ca || atha kaśyapapatnīnāṃ yatprasūtamidaṃ jagat | aditirditirdanuḥ kāṣṭhā ariṣṭā surasā ilā || muniḥ krodhavaśā tāmrā surabhiḥ saramā timiḥ | timeryādogaṇā āsanśvāpadāḥ saramāsutāḥ
translation: Listen to the names of the mothers and Shankaras in the world. Also, know the origin of this world, as brought forth by the wives of Kashyapa: Aditi, Diti, Danu, Kasta, Ariṣṭa, Surasa, Ila, Muni endowed with anger, Tāmrā, Surabhi, Saramā and Timi. The offspring of Timi are Timeryādogaṇā, Āsanśvāpadāḥ and Saramāsutāḥ.

sloka: catvārivāka parimitāpadānitāni vidurbrāhmaṇāye manīṣiṇaḥ guhā tarīṇi nihitā neṅagayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti
translation: Scholars of brahman, the thinkers, understand these words as having a limited scope and leading to liberation. They cause them to be spoken in the fourth degree of speech, which is hidden and deposited in humans.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni ||
translation: Perception, inference, and comparison of qualities are the means to attain valid knowledge.

sloka: indriyasyārthena sannikarṣād utpadyate yat jñānaṃ tat pratyakṣam ||
translation: The knowledge that arises from the direct contact of the sense organ with its object is called sensory perception.

sloka: tatpūrvakamityanena liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbandhadarśanaṃ liṅgadarśanaṃ cābhisaṃbadhyate | liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbadhdyordarśanena liṅgasmṛtirabhisaṃbadhyate | smṛtyā liṅgadarśanena cā'pratyakṣaḥ arthaḥ anumīyate |
translation: Through this very perception of the marker and the marked,

sloka: pūrvavaditi yatra kāraṇena kāryyamanumīyate| yathā medhonnatyā bhaviṣyati vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: Just as the future rainfall will happen based on the previous causes, in that same way, it is determined/decided.

sloka: athavā pūrvavaditi yatra yathā pūrvvaṃ pratyakṣabhūtayoḥ anyataradarśanena anyatarasya apratyakṣasya anumānam | yathā dhūmenāgniriti |
translation: Or, like the perception of fire through smoke, inference is the apprehension of what is unseen based on what has been seen , either similarly or differently . For example, we infer the presence of fire from smoke .

sloka: śeṣavat yatra kāryyeṇa kāraṇamanumīyate | pūrvvodakaviparītamudakaṃ nadyāḥ pūrṇatvamaṃ śīdhratvañca dṛṣṭvā srotaso'numīyate bhūtā vṛṣṭiriti |
translation: Where, in the case of a task, the effect is perceived to arise from a non-causal agent, and the flow of rivers is observed to be reversed at the onset of the rainy season, only then can one infer that the rain has truly occurred.

sloka: śeṣavat nāma pariśeṣaḥ sa ca prasaktapratiṣedhe'nyatra aprasāṅgāt śiṣyamāṇe sampratyayaḥ | yathā sadanityamityevamādinā dravyaguṇakarmaṇāmaviśeṣeṇa sāmānyaviśeṣasamavāyebhyo vibhaktasya śabdasya tasmin dravyakarmaguṇasaṃśaye na dravyamekadravyatvāt na karma śabdāntarahetutvāt yastu śiṣyate so'yamiti śabdasya guṇatvapratipattiḥ |
translation: The remainder is named 'sesa' and it, being firmly established, becomes known in the case of uncertainty regarding the nature of substances, qualities, and actions. Just as with things, qualities, and actions, when there is no singularity in a substance, nor is there a cause for the word to refer to something other than an action, then one who is learned through this connection between generalities and specifics becomes known as 'sesavat.' This is the injunction.

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ vrajyāpūrvakam anyatra dṛṣṭasya anyatra darśanamiti tathā cā''dityasya | tasmāt asti apratyakṣā api āpyādityasya vrajyeti|
translation: The sighting of the sun's course in a general sense is commonly seen, but its manifestation at other times is not. Therefore, even the unseen aspects of the sun are indeed approachable.

sloka: sāmānyato dṛṣṭaṃ nāma yatrāpratyakṣe liṅgaliṅginoḥ sambandhe kenacidarthena liṅgasya sāmānyādapratyakṣo liṅgī gamyate | yathecchādibhirātmā | icchādayo guṇāḥ | guṇāśca dravyasaṃsthānāḥ | tadyadeṣāṃ sthānaṃ sa ātmeti |
translation: In general, a name is observed where there is no perceptible distinction between the marked and unmarked aspects in some connection through a certain reason or meaning. The marked aspect is understood as the self, according to one's desires and other qualities, which are the states of substances. This self is referred to as that which is the location of those states.

sloka: prasiddhasādharmyātsādhyasādhanaṃ upamānam || || {upamānalakṣaṇam}
translation: The means for achieving the well-known universal qualities is a comparison. (This is the definition of upamana, a term in Indian philosophy.)

sloka: prajñātena sāmānyātprajñāpanīyasya prajñāpanamupamānamiti | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya iti | yadā khalvayaṃ gavā samānadharmaṃ pratipadyate tadā pratyakṣatastamarthaṃ pratipadyata iti | samākhyāsambandhapratipattiḥ rūpamānārtha ityāha | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya ityupamāne prayukte gavā samānadharmamarthamindriyārthasannikarṣādupalabhamāno asya gavayaśabdaḥ saṃjñeti saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyataiti | yathā mudgastathā mudgaparṇi yathā māṣastathā māṣapaṇi ityupamāne prayukte upamānāt saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyamānastāmoṣadhīṃ bhaiṣajyāyāharati | evamanyo apyupamānasya loke viṣayo bubhutsitavya iti |
translation: The definition of the commonly apparent through a pointed illustration  is understood as something that cannot be fully expressed (prajnapaniyasya). Just as the term "gauh" (cow) indicates the common qualities of cows, when one understands the shared characteristics of cows in this way, it becomes immediately clear what is meant by a cow. Similarly, when one realizes the common attribute of these objects through comparison, their true nature is understood. For instance, when "mudga" (bean) and "parni" (its leaf) are compared, it leads to recognizing the shared characteristic of beans; then, as a result, this recognition allows one to call something else "tamasah" (black gram) with certainty. Likewise, when the properties of "masha" (lentil) and its accompanying objects are understood through comparison, it enables one to refer to similar things appropriately. In this context, "gavayah" is used as an example; its meaning becomes clear through the illustration, as its individual qualities are recognized by the observer (sañjnasyambandham pratipadyamana atmaoshadhim bhaishajyaya hari). This same principle applies to other objects of comparison in this world.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ||||{śabdalakṣaṇam} saḥ dvividhaḥ dṛṣṭādṛṣṭārthatvāt||||{śabdabhedaḥ}
translation: Instructional speech, manifesting in two forms due to the distinction between what is directly perceived and what is not.

sloka: yasyāmutra pratīyate so'dṛṣṭārthaḥ | evamṛṣi laukikavākyānāṃ vibhāga iti |
translation: Of whom it is perceived later as something seen ; such is the division of mundane statements , [this is] declared .

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni || ||
translation: Perception, inference, and testimony are the means of valid knowledge.

sloka: tayā ca sarveṣāṃ vyavahārāḥ pravartanta iti | evamebhiḥ pramāṇairdevamanuṣyatiraśca vyavahārāḥ prakalpante nāto'nyatheti| arthāpattiḥ apramāṇaṃ anaikāntikatvāt ||||{arthāpattiprāmāṇyaparīkṣā}
translation: By her, all conduct functions – this is certain. Thus, the behavior of both gods and humans is fashioned, it is not otherwise. This is an instance of presumptive evidence, which is not authoritative because it is not definitive.

sloka: autpattikastu śabdasyārthena sambandhastasya jñānamupadeśo'vyatirekaścārthe'nupalabdhe tat pramāṇaṃ bādarāyaṇasyānapekṣatvāt sū
translation: Knowledge of the inherent connection of a word's meaning is described as a means of valid cognition by Badarayana, distinct from other means, in cases where that meaning is not directly perceived.

sloka: arthāpattirapi dṛṣṭaḥ śruto vārtho'nyathā nopapadyate ityarthakalpanā| yathā jīvati devadatte gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyādṛṣṭasya kalpanā||
translation: Even if perceived or reported, wealth's true meaning cannot be otherwise; just as Devadatta continues to live, externally perceiving the absence of home, so is the unseen established through inference.

sloka: arthāpattilakṣaṇam| vinā kalpanayā'rthena dṛṣṭenā'nupapannatām| nayatā'dṛṣṭamarthaṃ yā sā'rthāpattistu kalpanā || | dṛṣṭenā'rthenā'dṛṣṭasyā'rthasyā'rthāntarakalpanāyāmasatyāmanupapattimāpādayatā yā'rthāntarakalpanā sā'rthāpatti:| yathā jīvato devadattasya gṛhābhāvadarśanena bahirbhāvasyā'dṛṣṭasya kalpanā|
translation: The definition of "arthapatti" is the formation of a concept through inference, not perceived directly. Without the aid of assumptions, it leads to a contradiction if one attempts to consider something unperceived as existent. The process of inferring an unperceived object is called 'arthapatti'. Like when we infer that Devadatta is alive, based on seeing his home inhabited, despite not directly observing him.

sloka: abhāvo'pi pramāṇabhāvo nāstītyasyārthasyāsannikṛṣṭasyeti|
translation: Even the absence of proof is not non-existent in the case of something closely related to this meaning.

sloka: pramāṇapañcakaṃ yatra vasturūpe na jāyate| vastusattāvabodhārthaṃ tatrābhāvapramāṇatā|||| vasttvasaṅkarasiddhiśca tatprāmāṇyasamāśrayā|
translation: Where five means of valid knowledge do not arise in relation to the true nature of an object, there is the purpose of understanding its existence and non-existence; also, it is the basis for establishing the combination of objects.

sloka: kṣīre dadhyādi yannāsti prāgabhāvassa ucyate||||
translation: What is referred to as the beginningless absence, encompassing butter and such (substances) in dual form?

sloka: nāstitā payaso dadhni pradhvaṃsābhāva iṣyate| ||||
translation: The melting of the snow-like solidified milk is considered as disappearance.

sloka: gavi yo'śvādyabhāvastu so'nyonyābhāva ucyate||||
translation: The one who is nonexistent in the horse (i.e., not a horse) is said to be characterized by absence in others as well, as applies to the cow.

sloka: śiraso'vayavā ninmā vṛddhikāṭhinyavarjitāḥ| śaśaśrṛṅgādirūpeṇa so'tyantābhāva ucyate||||
translation: The supreme being, described as having a shape like that of a deer with antlers, is said to be completely free from decay and death.

sloka: śaraṇāgatasya kartavyamātithyaṃ hi prayatnataḥ| pañcayajñapravṛttena gṛhasthena viśeṣataḥ|| pañcayajñāṃstu yo mohānna karoti gṛhāśrame| tasya nāyaṃ na ca paro loko bhavati dharmataḥ||
translation: For one who has sought refuge, it is the duty of a householder, accomplished with devotion through performing the five daily sacrificial rituals. One who neglects these rituals at home, indulging in delusion—for such a person, neither this world nor the next remains in accord with dharma.

sloka: sa tu śītahatairgātrairna jagāma na tasthivān| dadarśa patitāṃ bhūmau kapotīṃ śītavihvalām||
translation: He, remaining unperturbed by the cold, did not go or stay . Seeing a shivering pigeon with its body benumbed by the cold, lying on the ground .

sloka: dharmārthakāmakāleṣu bhāryā puṃsaḥ sahāyinī| videśagamane cāsya saiva viśvāsakārikā|| nāsti bhāryāsamo bandhurnāsti bhāryāsamā gatiḥ| nāsti bhāryāsamo loke sahāyo dharmasaṅgrahe|| yasya bhāryā gṛhe nāsti sādhvī ca priyavādinī| araṇyaṃ tena gantavyaṃ yathāraṇyaṃ tathā gṛham||
translation: In matters of dharma, artha, and kama, the wife is the helpmate for the husband, both at home and when traveling abroad. She is his confidante. There is no friend like a wife, no companion like a wife, no one who can take her place in the world. If a virtuous, pleasant-speaking wife is not present in the house, it should be abandoned, just as one would abandon an infertile wilderness.

sloka: arāvapyucitaṃ kāryamātithyaṃ gṛhamāgate| chettumapyāgate chāyāṃ nopasaṃharate drumaḥ||
translation: Even the two meeting occasions that surely deserve recognition and hospitality , the tree does not neglect to provide shade when coming or going , nor in its growth .

sloka: niścitā khalu me buddhiratithipratipūjayane|| tataḥ kṛtapratijño vai sa pakṣī prahasanniva| tamagniṃ triḥparikramya praviveśa mahāmatiḥ||
translation: Undoubtedly, my understanding is now steady and widely praised. After making a firm resolution, the great-souled one, resembling a bird laughing, circumambulated that fire three times and entered it.

sloka: mitaṃ dadāti hi pitā mitaṃ bhrātā mitaṃ sutaḥ|| amitasya hi dātāraṃ bhartāraṃ kā na pūjayet| nāsti bhartṛsamo nātho nāsti bhartṛsamaṃ sukham||
translation: A father, brother, or son gives moderately, yet who doesn't honor the giver and protector, equivalent to a non-giver? There's no equal to a protector, nor is there happiness comparable to him.

sloka: tatrāparā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvavedaḥ śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chando jyotiṣamiti |
translation: There the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvaveda are known as śikṣā, kalpa, vyākaraṇa, nirukta, chanda, and jyotiṣa.

sloka: śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chandasāṃ cayaḥ | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ caiva vedāṅgāni ṣaḍeva tu ||
translation: The six ancillary sciences of the Vedas are phonetics, grammar, etymology, meter, astrology, and ritual implementation.

sloka: chandaḥ pādau tu vedasya hastau kalpo'tha ucyate | jyotiṣāmayanaṃ cakṣurniruktaṃ śrotramucyate || śikṣā ghrāṇaṃ tu vedasya mukhaṃ vyākaraṇaṃ smṛtam | tasmāt sāṅgamadhītyaiva brahmaloke mahīyate ||
translation: The meter is considered the feet of the Vedas, and so is its structure . Illumination is said to be its eye, while what is enunciated is its ear. The Vedas' teaching is considered its nose, its face is grammar , and it is established in the world of Brahma because of this integration of its parts.

sloka: āyurvedo dhanurvedo gāndharvaścaiva te trayaḥ | arthaśāstraṃ caturthaṃ tu vidyā hyaṣṭādaśaiva tāḥ || ||
translation: The three are Ayurveda, Dhanurveda, and Gandharva; the fourth is Artha-shastra, and there are also eighteen knowledge systems including Vidya.

sloka: aṣṭādaśa purāṇāni purāṇajñāḥ pracakṣate| brāhmaṃ pādmaṃ vaiṣṇavañca śaivaṃ bhāgavataṃ tathā|
translation: Eighteen Puranas are proclaimed by the knowers of the Purana. The Brahma, Padma, and Vaishnava, as well as Shaiva and Bhagavata, are spoken of in this way.

sloka: varṇādidharmasmaraṇaṃ yatra vedāvirodhakam | kīrtanaṃ cārthaśāstrāṇāṃ smṛtiḥ sā ca prakīrtitā |
translation: Where recalling (the principles of) caste duties, not conflicting with the Vedas, is prescribed, and also proclaiming the teachings of treatises on meaning, that recollection and proclamation have been made famous.

sloka: manvatriviṣṇuhārīta yājñavalkyośano'ṅgirāḥ | yamāpastambasaṃvartāḥ kātyāyanabṛhaspatī | | | |
translation: O Vishnu, Atri, and Hari, as well as Yajnavalkya Usana Angiras, Katyayana, and Brihaspati, who are to be approached for the Samvartas' sacrifice.

sloka: vitathasya sutān manyoḥ bṛhatkṣatro jayastataḥ | mahāvīryo naro gargaḥ saṅkṛtistu narātmajaḥ || ||guruśca rantidevaśca saṅ‌kṛteḥ pāṇḍunandana |
translation: Of the foolish one's (vitathasya) sons, Bṛhatkṣatra is indeed the victor, while Mahāvīrya, the man, is the one who has achieved great fame. Garga, the descendant of Nara, is renowned as well. Moreover, Rantideva and his son Sankṛti are also celebrated ones.

sloka: yasya dviśatasāhasrā āsansūdā mahātmanaḥ|| gṛhānabhyāgatānviprānatithīnpariveṣakāḥ| pakvāpakvaṃ divārātraṃ aparyāptaṃ dhanaṃ tadā[varānnamamṛtopamam|| nyāyenādhigataṃ vittaṃ brāhmaṇebhyo hyamanyata| vedānadhītya dharmeṇa yaścakre dviṣato vaśe||
translation: Of the one with great soul, hundreds and thousands of seats were occupied by suitors when his wealth, unmeasurable and superior to any other, was rightfully obtained and distributed to Brahmins. The one who, following proper conduct, established himself as a master over his rivals after having studied/recited the Vedas with dedication.

sloka: vyatīyuḥ aṣṭacatvāriṃśat ahani apibataḥ kila | ghṛtapāyasasaṃyāvaṃ toyaṃ prātarupasthitam || ||
translation: Thirty-eight nights had passed, during which they had been drinking only ghee, milk, and curd that were present at dawn.

sloka: na kāmaye'haṃ gatimīśvarātparāṃ aṣṭarddhiyuktāmapunarbhavaṃ vā | ārtiṃ prapadye'khiladehabhājāṃ antaḥsthito yena bhavantyaduḥkhāḥ || ||
translation: "I do not desire a higher destiny than the one granted by Lord Īśvara, nor do I long for another birth. I seek refuge in That which alleviates the distress of all embodied beings, residing within them and mitigating their sorrows."

sloka: puruṣabahutvaṃ vyavasthātaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | nādvaitamātmano liṅgāt tadbhedapratīteḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | nānātmāpi pratyakṣabādhāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | nobhābhyāṃ tenaiva | sāṃkhyasūtra | anyaparatvamavivekānāṃ tatra | sāṃkhyasūtra | nātmāvidyā nobhayaṃ jagadupādānakāraṇaṃ nissaṅgatvāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | naikasyānandacidrūpatve dvayorbhedāt | sāṃkhyasūtra | duḥkhanivṛttergauṇaḥ | sāṃkhyasūtra | vimuktipraśaṃsā mandānāṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra | jananamaraṇakaraṇānāṃ pratiniyamādayugapatpravṛtteśca | puruṣabahutvaṃ siddhaṃ traiguṇyaviparyayāccaiva || ||
translation: The multiplicity of puruṣa, established in its distinct aspects, is not dualistic due to the distinction perceived from the perspective of liṅga. The plurality of self-aware entities is proven by direct perception. You two have both merged into that very one. Only through this union with it does non-duality arise for those who cannot distinguish between self and other. Ignorance, the cause of worldly existence, does not concern the true self, which is free from duality. The nature of bliss is not shared by the two aspects of puruṣa. Happiness arising from eliminating suffering is a quality associated with the one who has realized this unity. Praiseworthy are those who understand this concept. Regulated actions such as birth and death occur for each individual in their respective stages. The multiplicity of puruṣa becomes established, along with the reversal of its three gunas (sattva, rajas, tamas).

sloka: kleśakarmavipākāśayairaparāmṛṣṭaḥ puruṣaviśeṣa īśvaraḥ ||
translation: The distinct Purusha, who is untainted by the results of action and its causes, as well as the impressions of afflictions.

sloka: niratiśayaṃ tatra sarvajñatvabījam ||
translation: There the seed of omniscience lies, in its highest form.

sloka: sa pūrveṣāmapi guruḥ kālenānavacchedāta||
translation: Even the ancient teacher, uninterrupted by time.

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam||
translation: The self, body, senses, objects, intellect, and mind, along with their activities, faults, states at death, results, suffering, and liberation – all these constitute the object of knowledge.

sloka: tatrā''tmā sarvasya draṣṭā sarvasya bhoktā sarvajñaḥ sarvānubhavakaḥ | tasya bhogā''yatanaṃ śarīram | bhogasādhanānīndriyāṇi |
translation: The self is the observer and enjoys everything, all-knowing and experiencing all. Its enjoyment basis is the body; the instruments of enjoyment are the senses and objects.

sloka: jagaduvyāpāravarjam prakaraṇāt asannihitatvācca ||
translation: Excluding the pervasiveness of the world, move away from it, based on its inherent nature.

sloka: jaṭā mālā śikhā lekhā dhvajo daṇḍo ratho ghanaḥ aṣṭau vikṛtayaḥ proktā kramapūrvā manīṣibhiḥ
translation: "Eight distinct emblems, spoken of in sequence by the sages, have been designated: the tuft , garland , crest , mark , banner , staff , chariot , and mass ."

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ | saṃ | vadante | somena | saha | rājñā | yasmai | kṛṇoti | brāhmaṇaḥ | taṃ | rājan | pārayāmasi ||
translation: We, O king, are striving to become the one whom the wise Brahmin, with the help of Soma, refers to as "that which stimulates the growth of herbs" along with the king , through his words ; to whom he attributes such actions .

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ | saṃ vadante | vadante somena | somena saha | saha rājñā | rājñeti rājñā | yasmai kṛṇoti | kṛṇoti brāhmaṇaḥ | brāhmaṇastaṃ | taṃ rājan | rājan pārayāmasi | pārayāmasīti pārayāmasi ||
translation: "Herbs are indeed called 'somena saha' (together with soma) by the one who makes offerings to him. O king, we seek to attain that very thing."

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ samoṣadhayaḥ oṣadhayaḥ sam | saṃ vadante vadante sam saṃ vadante | vadante somena somena vadante vadante somena | somena saha saha somena somena saha| saha rājñā rājñā saha saha rājñā | rājñeti rājñā | yasmai kṛṇoti kṛṇoti yasmai yasmai kṛṇoti| kṛṇoti brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇaḥ kṛṇoti kṛṇoti brāhmaṇaḥ| brāhmaṇastaṃ taṃ brāhmaṇo brāhmaṇastam | taṃ rājan rājaṃstaṃ taṃ rājan | rājan pārayāmasi pārayāmasi rājan rājan pārayāmasi | pārayāmasīti pārayāmasi ||
translation:
Plants are called equal to other plants, they say,
Also speaking of them being mixed with soma, they say.
Together with the king, they say, they speak, they say,
Together with soma, they say, they speak, they say.
Along with the brahmina, he makes him that, they say,
The brahmin makes him that, they say, the brahmin makes him that.
The brahminas designates him as that, they say,
You designate him as king, they say, you designate him as king.
We strive for that crossing, we strive for that crossing,
Strive for that crossing, we say.

sloka: oṣadhayaḥ saṃ samoṣadhayaḥ oṣadhayaḥ saṃ vadante| saṃ vadante vadante sam saṃ vadante somena|
translation: Herbs are called "samosa" (companion herbs), as they speak of "soma" together.

sloka: brahmakṣatriyaviṭśūdrā varṇāstvādyāstrayo dvijāḥ | niṣekādyāḥ śmaśānāntāsteṣāṃ vai mantrataḥ kriyāḥ || ||
translation: The first three classes of society, namely the brahmin, kshatriya, and vaishya, their primary duties consist of ritual actions such as niṣeka (marriage) and those performed at a śmaśāna (cremation ground). These are the actions to be performed by them according to the mantras.

sloka: saṃskārā yadavicchinnāḥ sa dvijo'jo jagāda yam |
translation: The sacred rituals, which were uninterrupted, were indeed spoken of by the twice-born Aja.

sloka: viprasyādhyayanādīni ṣaḍanyasyāpratigrahaḥ |
translation: The neglect of the study and other six pursuits belonging to a brahmin is called unacceptable.

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva dānaṃ pātre pratigrahaḥ| adhyāpanamadhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgṛjuḥ||
translation: Conducting a ritual, assisting in a ritual, giving in charity, receiving in a worthy vessel, teaching, studying, and performing religious duties – these six are the components of righteousness.

sloka: satyaṃ dānaṃ kṣamā śīlamānṛśaṃsyaṃ tapo ghṛṇā | dṛśyante yatranāgendrasa brāhmaṇa iti smṛtaḥ ||
translation: The following are recognized as a brahmin: truth, charity, forgiveness, good conduct, absence of arrogance, austerity, and lack of contempt; these qualities are seen in him.

sloka: śamo damastapaḥ śaucaṃ santoṣaḥ kṣāntirārjavam | jñānaṃ dayācyutātmatvaṃ satyaṃ ca brahmalakṣaṇam || ||
translation: Serenity, self-control, austerity, purity, contentment, forbearance, straightforwardness, knowledge, compassion (derived from cyuta, meaning "fallen" and ātman, meaning "self"), and truth are the characteristics of Brahman.

sloka: adhyāpanam adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānām akalpayat || ||
translation: He used to cause the assignment of teaching, studying, performing sacrifices, officiating at sacrifices, giving, and accepting [gifts] to Brahmins.

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ śrutyuktaḥ smārta eva ca | tasmādasminsadā yukto nityaṃ syādātmavāndvijaḥ || ||
translation: Conduct is the highest virtue, as declared in scriptures and tradition. Therefore, a dvija should constantly be aligned with it and possess self-awareness.

sloka: idaṃ śāstram adhīyāno brāhmaṇaḥ śaṃsitavrataḥ | manovāggehajairnityaṃ karmadoṣairna lipyate || || ācārādvicyuto vipro na vedaphalam aśnute | ācāreṇa tu saṃyuktaḥ sampūrṇaphalabhāgbhavet || ||
translation: While studying this scripture, the brahmin who is known for his praised vows does not become tainted by faults of actions committed through body, speech, and home, day after day. A priest who has deviated from proper conduct does not partake of the fruit of the Veda, but one who is joined with correct conduct becomes worthy of attaining complete fruit of the scriptural knowledge.

sloka: ṛtaṃ uñchaśilaṃ jñeyaṃ amṛtaṃ syādayācitam | mṛtaṃ tu yācitaṃ bhaikṣaṃ pramṛtaṃ karṣaṇaṃ smṛtam || || satyānṛtaṃ tu vāṇijyaṃ tena caivāpi jīvyate | sevā śvavṛttirākhyātā tasmāttāṃ parivarjayet || ||
translation: The previously mentioned righteous act is to be known, imperishable and providing the means for sustenance. Begged food is perishable, named as "karshana," remembered as such. Trade, based on truth and falsehood, is lived upon by that very (means). Service, in the form of a livelihood, is designated as "svavrtti." Therefore, one should cause oneself to avoid this.

sloka: varjayettāṃ sadā vipro rājanyaśca jugupsitām | sarvavedamayo vipraḥ sarvadevamayo nṛpaḥ || ||
translation: The learned one and the nobleman should always reject that which is to be abhorred. The one who is infused with all branches of knowledge is a vipra, while the one who is infused with all deities is a king .

sloka: kusūladhānyako vā syātkumbhīdhānyaka eva vā | tryahaihiko vāpi bhavedaśvastanika eva vā || || caturṇāṃ api caiteṣāṃ dvijānāṃ gṛhamedhinām | jyāyānparaḥ paro jñeyo dharmato lokajittamaḥ || || ṣaṭkarmaiko bhavatyeṣāṃ tribhiranyaḥ pravartate | dvābhyāṃ ekaścaturthastu brahmasattreṇa jīvati || ||
translation: Is he a kusuladhanyaka or a kumbhidhanyaka, or possibly a triahaihika? Or is he an asvastanika? Among these four grahamedhin brahmins, the one who is most superior, distinguished, and worthy of knowing is the one who is jittamahtah in terms of dharma. There are six karma for these individuals, out of which one is performed with three, another with two, while yet another lives through brahmasattrena.

sloka: adroheṇaiva bhūtānāṃ alpadroheṇa vā punaḥ | yā vṛttistāṃ samāsthāya vipro jīvedanāpadi || ||
translation: By showing compassion or even minimal enmity towards all beings, a brāhmaṇa can live his life in such a way.

sloka: yātrāmātraprasiddhyarthaṃ svaiḥ karmabhiragarhitaiḥ | akleśena śarīrasya kurvīta dhanasaṃcayam || ||
translation: To gain fame through a journey, one should skillfully accumulate wealth without causing bodily harm.

sloka: na bhojanārthaṃ sve vipraḥ kulagotre nivedayet | bhojanārthaṃ hi te śaṃsanvāntāśītyucyate budhaiḥ || ||
translation: A household priest should not offer food with the intent of eating it himself, for such behavior is criticized by the wise as being greedy.

sloka: vartayaṃśca śiloñchābhyāṃ agnihotraparāyaṇaḥ | iṣṭīḥ pārvāyaṇāntīyāḥ kevalā nirvapetsadā || || na lokavṛttaṃ varteta vṛttihetoḥ kathaṃ cana | ajihmāṃ aśathāṃ śuddhāṃ jīvedbrāhmaṇajīvikām || || saṃtoṣaṃ paraṃ āsthāya sukhārthī saṃyato bhavet | saṃtoṣamūlaṃ hi sukhaṃ duḥkhamūlaṃ viparyayaḥ || ||
translation: Performing the agnihotra rite, being always engaged in pouring oblations to the fire with sacrificial grass, and offering the concluding and opening oblations, he should regularly offer sacrifices. He should never follow the ways of the world; how could he who seeks to live a pure brahminical life adopt such behavior? Let him live, supporting himself through pure means. Establishing contentment as the highest goal, let him be one who desires welfare while remaining self-controlled. For, contentment is the root of happiness, and its opposite is the root of suffering.

sloka: dāti dāśati dāsati rāti rāsati pṛṇakṣi pṛṇāti śikṣati tuñjata maṃhate iti dānakarmāṇaḥ| |
translation: Giver, one who bestows, serves, and enjoys, as well as one who extracts, delights, learns, and swells - these are the activities of a generous person. (The Sanskrit verse is listing out various meanings related to giving or generosity, describing the activities and attitudes of a person who is generous.)

sloka: devabrāhmaṇādisampradānakadravyamocanam tatparyyāyaḥ tyāgaḥ vihāpitam utsarjanam visarjanam viśrāṇanam vitaraṇam sparśanam pratipādanam prādeśanam nirvvapaṇam apavarjanam aṃhatiḥ ityamaraḥ
translation: The act of casting off, in the sense of giving up, that which is meant for or offered to deities, Brahmanas, and others, is referred to as tyaga. It includes various forms such as vihapita (causing to abandon), utsarjanam (abandonment), visarjanam (discarding), visrananam (freeing), vitaraṇam (handing over), sparsanam (touching), pratipadanam (placing near), pradesanam (pointing out), nirvapanam (dedicating), apavaranam (protecting), and ahamti (effort). This is called amara, the supreme.

sloka: nākasya pṛṣṭhe adhi tiṣṭhati śrito yaḥ pṛṇāti sa ha deveṣu gacchati | tasmā āpo ghṛtamarṣanti sindhavastasmā iyaṃ dakṣiṇā pinvate sadā ||
translation: The one who sustains on the back of the sky and causes rain to fall, goes among the gods. Therefore, the waters that have been churned are constantly nourishing the rivers.

sloka: tapaḥ paraṃ kṛtayuge tretāyāṃ jñānaṃ ucyate | dvāpare yajñaṃ evāhurdānaṃ ekaṃ kalau yuge || ||
translation: In the Satya Yuga, austerity was deemed supreme; in the Treta Yuga, it was declared as knowledge; in the Dvapara Yuga, sacrifice was held as important; while in the current Kali Yuga, charity is considered the only means.

sloka: sa tu dānasya tattvārthī tepe varṣagaṇānbahūn|| || ā āī ēē ṣṇāū|| || tatastaṃ prāha khe vāṇī ślokamekaṃ nṛpa śrṛṇu|| dvihetu ṣaḍadhiṣṭhānaṃ ṣaḍaṃgaṃ ca dvipākayuk|| || catuḥprakāraṃ trividhaṃ trināśaṃ dānamucyate||
translation: The seeker of the truth of charity indeed endured heavy rains. Then he spoke to the king: "Hear, O king, this one sloka about the six causes, six receptacles, and threefold effects of charity." It is said that charity is destructive when of four kinds and threefold in nature.

sloka: śraddhā śaktiśca dānānāṃ vṛddhyakṣayakarehi te|| ||
translation: Faith and power are, in your case, the enhancers of growth and imperishability in giving.

sloka: dharmamarthaṃ ca kāmaṃ ca vrīḍāharṣabhayāni ca|| adhiṣṭhānāni dānānāṃ ṣaḍetāni pracakṣate|| ||
translation: The six foundations of giving are said to be dharma, artha, kama, as well as bhaya (fear), harsha (joy), and vrida (shame), which serve as their respective bases.

sloka: dātā pratigrahītā ca śuddhirdeyaṃ ca dharmayuk|| || deśakālau ca dānānāmaṃgānyetāni ṣaḍviduḥ|| ||
translation: The giver and the acceptor, purity is what ought to be adhered to in dharma, as well as at appropriate times and places; these six aspects pertain to giving.

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva tathā dānapratigrahau| adhyāpanaṃ cādhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgdvijaḥ||
translation: The six duties of a dvija are performing rituals, officiating rituals, giving and accepting gifts, teaching, studying, and carrying out the prescribed actions, all in accordance with dharma.

sloka: sadbhyo yaddīyate kiṃcittatparatropatiṣṭhati|| asatsu dīyate kiṃcittaddānamiha bhujyate|| ||
translation: From what is given by the good, what is offered to others? What is here enjoyed by the feminine entity who herself stands firm regarding that gift, and what is dedicated to the bad over there?

sloka: dhruvamāhustrikaṃ kāmyaṃ naimittikamiti kramāt|| || vaidiko dānamārgo'yaṃ caturdhā varṇyate dvijaiḥ||
translation: "They declare that the religious gift-giving (dāna) is categorized in four ways by the dvija (twice-born): as obligatory (dhruvam), occasional (naimittika), desired (kāmyam), and this (ayam) is its description in order (kramāt)."

sloka: upānacchatrapātrādidadhimadhvāsanāni ca|| || āāāāā || || dīpakāṣṭhopalādīni caramaṃ bahuvārṣikam|| iti kānīyasānyāhurdānanāśatrayaṃ śrṛṇu|| ||
translation: Learn, O worthy one, about the destruction of the three dāna-nāśas (charity-annihilations) that occur from using, for a long time, impure vessels like upānacchatrapātrādi (alms bowls), dadhimadhvāsanaadi (mat made of Kusa grass) and kāṣṭhaupalādi (wooden plates) for carama (eating).

sloka: yaccākruśya dadātyaṃga dattvā vākrośati dvijam|| paiśācaṃ tadvṛthā dānaṃdānanāśāstrayastvamī|| ||
translation: What is given or done after exhorting and touching, even if it is a verbal abuse, is inappropriate charity; you are indeed three destroyers of such gifts.

sloka: ye ke cāsmacchreyā~so brāhmaṇāḥ teṣāṃ tvayā''sanena praśvasitavyam | śraddhayā deyam | aśraddhayā'deyam | śriyā deyam | hriyā deyam | bhiyā deyam | saṃvidā deyam | atha yadi te karmavicikitsā vā vṛttavicikitsā vā syāt || ||
translation: Those brahmins who are worthy of reverence from you, for them, breath should be controlled through meditation; (it) should be given with faith, (it) should not be given without faith, (it) should be given with wealth, (it) should be given with humility, (it) should be given out of fear, (it) should be given with consciousness. If there is doubt in you regarding actions or conduct, then...

sloka: gṛhe daśaguṇaṃ dānaṃ goṣṭhe caiva śatādhikam | puṇyatīrtheṣu sāhasramanantaṃ śivasannidhau ||
translation: In the home, we offered gifts ten times greater; in the cattle pen, [we offered] a hundred more. At holy pilgrimages, thousands and countless more in Shiva's presence.

sloka: devīpurāṇe sarve śivāśramāḥ puṇyāḥ sarvā nadyaḥ śubhapradāḥ |
translation: In the sacred text Devi-Purana, all shiva shrines and rivers are pure and bountiful.

sloka: na hīyate yatra dharmmaścatuṣpāt sakalo dvija! | sa deśaḥ paramo nityaṃ sarvapuṇyatamo mataḥ |
translation: In that place where dharma in its fourfold form does not decline, O twice-born, such a region is considered supreme and eternally the most virtuous.

sloka: gaṅgādvāre prayāge ca avimukte ca puṣkare | nagare cāṭṭahāse ca gaṅgāsāgarasaṅgame | kurukṣetre gayāyāñca tīrthe vā'marakaṇṭake | evamādiṣu tīrtheṣu dattamakṣayatāmiyāt | sarvatīrthamayī gaṅgā tatra dattaṃ mahāphalam |
translation: At the confluence of Ganga and Prayaga, unattached Puskara lakes, in the city's Aṭṭahāsa, at Kurukṣetra, Gayā shrine, and Amarakaṇṭaka, gifts made at these and other sacred sites bring great fruit; indeed, the all-holy Ganga, when given there, yields the highest fruit.

sloka: kuṭumbabhaktavasanād deyaṃ yadatiricyate | anyathā dīyate yaddhi na tad dānaṃ phalapradam ||
translation: Derived from devotion to one's family, what is given after being duly considered brings merit; but what is given without due consideration does not yield fruit.

sloka: na taddānaṃ praśaṃsanti yena vṛttirvipadyate | dānaṃ yajñastapaḥ karma loke vṛttimato yataḥ || ||
translation: Not is praised such giving, through which one's conduct becomes misaligned. In the world, it is that vṛtti (pattern of actions) which is worthy of being designated as dāna (charity), yajña (sacrifice), tapa (austerity).

sloka: brahmaṇāstapasā yuktā yathāśakti pradāyinaḥ | sahasraśaktiśca śataṃ śataśaktirdaśāpi ca || dadyādpaśca yaḥ śaktyā sarve tulyaphalāḥ smṛtāḥ | rantidevo hi nṛpatirapaḥ prādādakiñcanaḥ ||
translation: "Endowed by Brahman, united with self-control and giving according to their ability, one who is capable of granting thousands, hundreds, and even tens of powers, as well as all others equal in reward, is remembered as Rantideva, the king who gives without regard for what he receives."

sloka: dharmāya yaśase'rthāya kāmāya svajanāya ca | pañcadhā vibhajan vittaṃ ihāmutra ca modate || ||
translation: For dharma, reputation, purpose, desire, and kinship, one who distributes wealth in five ways here and hereafter finds delight.

sloka: trividhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāvajā|| sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śrṛṇu|| ||
translation: Faith in embodied beings is of three kinds, hear what they are: svabhāvaja, sāttvikī, rājasī, and tāmasī.

sloka: dātavyamiti yaddānaṃ dīyate'nupakāriṇe | deśe kāle ca pātre ca taddānaṃ sātvikaṃ smṛtam || yattu pratyupakārārthaṃ phalamuddiśya vā punaḥ | dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṃ taddānaṃ rājasaṃ smṛtam ||
translation: That gift which is given to an undeserving person, with the intention of fruit or out of obligation, in a place, time, and to recipients, that gift is considered to be sattvika, given out of goodness, when it is unadulterated by expectation. However, a gift offered with the intent of return favor or tainted with compulsion or reluctance is deemed rajasic, driven by self-interest.

sloka: adeśakāle yaddānamapātrebhyaśca dīyate | asatkṛtamavajñātaṃ tattāmasamudāhṛtam || dānaṃ trividhamityetatkaniṣṭhajyeṣṭhamadhyamam || tatra naiśreyasaṃ jyeṣṭhaṃ kaniṣṭhaṃ svārthasiddhaye || || kāruṇyātsarvabhūteṣu saṃvibhāgastu madhyamaḥ ||
translation: At the appointed time, when charity is given to eligible recipients, if it is not dishonored or unrecognized, it is known as tāmasa charity. Charity is of three types: low, middling, and high. The highest is for spiritual liberation; the low is for fulfilling one's own interests; while sharing equally with all creatures out of compassion is considered middling.

sloka: nityaṃ naimittikaṃ kāmyaṃ trividhaṃ dānamucyate | caturthaṃ vimalaṃ proktaṃ sarvadānottamottamam ||
translation: Charity is described as threefold - occasional, voluntary, and prescribed. The fourth kind, unconditional and spotless, is said to be the best of all.

sloka: sāmānyaṃ yācitaṃ nyāsamādhirdārāśca darśanam|| anvāhitaṃ ca nikṣepaḥ sarvasvaṃ cānvaye sati|| || āpatsvapi na deyāni navavastūni paṃḍitaiḥ|| yo dadāti sa mūḍhātmā prāyāścittīyate naraḥ|| ||
translation: Seek as an offering the common (

sloka: jīvanmukto nāma svasvarūpākhaṇḍabrahmajñānena tadajñānabādhanadvārā svasvarūpākhaṇḍabrahmaṇi sākṣātkṛte ajñāna tatkārya sañcitakarma saṃśaya viparyayādīnāmapi bādhitatvāt akhilabandharahito brahmaniṣṭhaḥ || ||
translation: "Liberated while still alive, named after one's own unchanging Brahman-knowledge, which eliminates the covering of ignorance, and having experienced the self as non-dual Brahman - such a steadfast one in Brahman is free from all bonds, including doubts, contrary thoughts, the accumulated actions, and even the bondage caused by the remaining tendencies towards worldly existence."

sloka: evaṃ ca vedāntavākyaiḥ sadgurūpadeśena ca sarveṣvapi bhūteṣu yeṣāṃ brahmabuddhirutpannā te jīvanmuktāḥ ityarthaḥ |
translation: Thus, those who have developed a understanding of Brahman through the teachings of the wise and the Upanishadic statements, they are liberated while living; this is the meaning.

sloka: sthitaprajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhisthasya keśava | sthitadhīḥ kiṃ prabhāṣeta kimāsīta vrajeta kim || ||
translation: What is the speech of one with stable wisdom, O Keshava, and what should be the contemplative's expression? What should he do, having set out?

sloka: rāgadveṣavimuktaistu viṣayānindriyaiścaran | ātmavaśyairvidheyātmā prasādamadhigacchati || ||
translation: Free from attachment and aversion, when one actively engages with sense objects using self-controlled senses, they attain peace and tranquility.

sloka: nanu jīvanmuktaḥ kaḥ ? yathā deho'haṃ puruṣo'haṃ brāhmaṇo'haṃ śūdro'hamasmīti dṛḍhaniścayastathā nāhaṃ brāhmaṇaḥ na śūdraḥ na puruṣaḥ kintu asaṃgaḥ saccidānanda svarūpaḥ prakāśarūpaḥ sarvāntaryāmī cidākāśarūpo'smīti dṛḍhaniścayarūpo'parokṣajñānavān jīvanmuktaḥ ||
translation: "Is there a jivanmukta (liberated soul) indeed? Just as this body is 'I am this' - a purusha (individual), brahmana (priest), shudra (worker), and 'I am this' in various ways, similarly I am neither a brahmana, nor a shudra, nor a purusha. Rather, I am formless, non-dual consciousness, the embodiment of sat-cit-ananda (existence-consciousness-bliss), and the revealer of all. My true nature is that of pure awareness, and it is established as directly perceivable."

sloka: jñātibhirvā nopajan~ smarannida~ śarīra~ sa yathā prayogya ācaraṇe yukta evamevāyamasmiñcharīre prāṇo yuktaḥ || ||
translation: Just as the vital breath is engaged in this body, working appropriately for its various functions, similarly I am established in this body, engaged in my proper function by the remembrance of those who are related to me.

sloka: dehaṃ ca naśvaramavasthitamutthitaṃ vā | siddho na paśyati yato'dhyagamat svarūpam | daivādapetamatha daivavaśād upetaṃ | vāso yathā parikṛtaṃ madirāmadāndhaḥ|| ||
translation: One who is established in a transient body does not see (the self) when it has been reached, whether it has come about by divine action or under compulsion. Just as a person intoxicated by wine does not understand how he has been dressed, so too...

sloka: jñānabhūmiḥ śubhecchākhyā prathamā samudāhṛtā| vicāraṇā dvitīyā tu tṛtīyā tanumānasā|| satvāpattiścaturthī syāttato'saṃsaktināmikā| padārthābhāvanī ṣaṣṭhī saptamī turyagā smṛtā||
translation: The field of knowledge is called shubhecchaa first, followed by vicaraana as the second, and tanumaanaasaa as the third. The manifestation of satva is the fourth, leading to the development of saamsaktinaamika for those who are attached. The sixth is padaarthabhaavani, and turyagaa is remembered as the seventh.

sloka: yaṃ pravrajantamanupetamapetakṛtyaṃ dvaipāyano virahakātara ājuhāva | putreti tanmayatayā taravo'bhineduḥ taṃ sarvabhūtahṛdayaṃ munimānato'smi || || yaḥ svānubhāvamakhila śrutisāramekaṃ adhyātmadīpaṃ atititīrṣatāṃ tamo'ndham | saṃsāriṇāṃ karuṇayā''ha purāṇaguhyaṃ taṃ vyāsasūnumupayāmi guruṃ munīnām || ||
translation: I approach as my guru the sage Vyasa's son, who is eager to go beyond the darkness of ignorance for those ensnared in saṃsāra, and who has realized the single essence of all scriptural knowledge. I refer to that great one, whose heart is dear to all beings, whom the trees recognized when he left home, abandoning all duties, as 'O son!' And I also approach as my guru the supreme being, described in ancient texts as endowed with his own experience, the sole light in the forest of all scriptures.

sloka: aho kaṣṭaṃ bhraṣṭo'hamātmavatāmanupathādyadvimuktasamastasaṅgasya viviktapuṇyāraṇyaśaraṇasyātmavata ātmani sarveṣāmātmanāṃ bhagavati vāsudeve tadanuśravaṇamananasaṅkīrtanārādhanānusmaraṇābhiyogenāśūnyasakalayāmena kālena samāveśitaṃ samāhitaṃ kārtsnyena manastattu punarmamābudhasyārānmṛgasutamanu parisusrāva
translation: Alas, I am afflicted, having fallen away from the path of self-control and being liberated from all associations. I have not been engaged in hearing, chanting, and worshiping the glorious Bhagavan Vāsudeva, who is the resort of the secluded and pure sacred grove of auspicious qualities. Now, by fully dedicating my mind to this, let me become situated in it without duplicity, and with great enthusiasm vanquish my forgetfulness under the guidance of the scriptures.

sloka: tatrāpi svajanasaṅgācca bhṛśamudvijamāno bhagavataḥ karmabandhavidhvaṃsanaśravaṇasmaraṇaguṇavivaraṇacaraṇāravindayugalaṃ manasā vidadhadātmanaḥ pratighātamāśaṅkamāno bhagavadanugraheṇānusmṛtasvapūrvajanmāvalirātmānamunmattajaḍāndhabadhirasvarūpeṇa darśayāmāsa lokasya
translation: Even there, being deeply agitated by the association with his own people, he (Arjuna), contemplating in his mind, presented before himself the means of destroying the bonds of action as revealed and described by the Lord. Filled with doubt, he said to the Lord, "How could I attack my teachers, relatives, and friends, who have already been seen in previous births by me?" Thus, he appeared confused and almost unconscious, his mind overwhelmed by pity, grief, and fear.

sloka: tanoti vipulānarthān tatvamantrasamanvitān trāṇaṃ ca kurute yasmāt tantramityabhidhīyate
translation: It (the Tantra) that reveals profound truths and is endowed with mantras expands (our understanding of) the protection (it offers), hence it is called 'Tantra'.

sloka: yujyante saṅklpyante sambadhyante parasparamarthāḥ samyaktayā prākaraṇike'bhimate'rthe virodhavyāghātādidoṣamapāsyānayā iti yuktiḥ yuj yojane tasmin yaktiriti rūpaṃ bhavati
translation: The two are integrated, connected, and harmonized with each other in terms of meaningful purpose through the elimination of contradiction and conflict, caused by faults, in a proper manner in that context; thus, the arrangement (of these two) is called 'yukti' (meaningful connection); it relates to 'yuj' (to join) in that context; this is the form it takes.

sloka: yathā'mbujavanasyārkaḥ pradīpo veśmano yathā || prabodha prakāśārthāstathā tantrasya yuktayaḥ | ekasminnapi yasyeha śāstre labdāspadā matiḥ|| sa śāstramanyadapyāśu yuktijñatvāt prabudhyate |
translation: Just as the sun is the lamp for the lotus and the illumination of a house, so too are the means of understanding for a system, when found in one place. One who has gained mastery in that scripture quickly understands any other scripture due to knowledge of its principles.

sloka: dharmamūlaṃ vedamāhuḥ grantharāśimakṛtrimam| tadvidāṃ smṛtiśīle ca sādhvācāraṃ manaḥpriyam ||
translation: The root of dharma is declared to be the Vedas, a collection of abundant unadulterated texts. In the path of righteousness, it is pleasing to the minds of the knowing ones.

sloka: śrautastretāgnisaṃbandhāt smārttaḥ pūrvaṃ mayoditaḥ | śreyaskaratamaḥ śrautastasmācchrautaṃ samācaret ||
translation: The traditionalist, having been previously initiated into the fire rituals should always perform the non-fire ritual practices, for they yield the greatest benefit.

sloka: ubhāvabhihitau dharmau vedavedaviniḥsṛtau | śiṣṭācārastṛtīyaḥ syācchratismṛtyoralābhataḥ ||
translation: The two dharmas (duties) indicated in the Vedas, namely study and sacrifice, should be practiced in accordance with good conduct; such is the third duty that arises from scriptural injunctions related to daily routine, death-related rites, and gain of wealth.

sloka: dharmeṇādhigato yaistu vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | te śiṣṭā brāhmaṇāḥ proktā nityamātmaguṇānvitāḥ ||
translation: Those two Brāhmaṇas, who have thoroughly grasped the Vedas through the path of Dharma, are known as paragons of virtue and are eternally endowed with noble qualities.

sloka: teṣāmabhimato yaḥ syāccetasā nityameva hi | sa dharmaḥ kathitaḥ sadbhirnānyeṣāmiti dhāraṇā ||
translation: The teaching conveyed by those who are truly wise is that the principle of righteousness is constantly determined by one's own mind and intellect, as the one who is revered by them. This, in contrast to others, is what is referred to as dharma.

sloka: śiṣṭāḥ khalu vigatamatsarā nirahaṃkārāḥ kumbhīdhānyā alolupā dambhadarpalobhamohakrodhavivarjitāḥ || dharmeṇādhigato yeṣāṃ vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | śiṣṭās tadanumānajñāḥ śrutipratyakṣahetavaḥ || iti ||
translation: The upright ones, indeed, are devoid of envy and ego, disinterested, free from greed, delusion, anger, and pride. They have attained the Vedas in its entirety through means of direct perception, inference, and testimony. These noble souls are known as those who have acquired knowledge through anumana (inference) and shruti (revelation).

sloka: dharmeṇādhigato yaistu vedaḥ saparibṛṃhaṇaḥ | te śiṣṭā brāhmaṇā jñeyāḥ śrutipratyakṣahetavaḥ | | |
translation: Those who have attained the Veda, expanded through learning, in the sphere of dharma are to be known as the accomplished brahmins, proven through hearing and direct perception.

sloka: dṛṣṭo dharmavyatikramaḥ sāhasaṃ ca mahatāṃ || ̥ṣṭō ḥ āṁ āṁ || iti| sāhasaṃ paraśurāmādeḥ mātuḥ śirachedādi|
translation: Observed violating dharma, Paraśurāma, the mighty one, is a force to be reckoned with, beginning with his mother's head.

sloka: kuśalācaritenaiṣāṃ iha svārtho na vidyate | viparyayeṇa vānartho nirahaṅkāriṇāṃ prabho || ||
translation: The personal benefit of these (accusative plural) acting skillfully does not exist here, O Lord; rather, for those free from ego, harm arises through the opposite.

sloka: dharmajñasamayaḥ pramāṇaṃ vedāśca| vedāśca
translation: The standard of righteousness and the means of correct knowledge are the Vedas. (And) the Vedas too.

sloka: anānmāteṣu dharmeṣu kathaṃ syāditi cedbhavet | yaṃ śiṣṭā brāhṇā bhrūyuḥ sa dharmassyādaśāṅketaḥ|| | |
translation: How could one, who is considered worthy by the virtuous brahmins, become unrighteous in his duties? Such a person would set a bad example for dharma.

sloka: tadabhāve daśāvarā pariṣat|
translation: In its absence, the group of ten becomes inferior.

sloka: catvāro vedadharmajñāḥ pariṣatraividyameva vā| sā brūte yaṃ sa dharmassyādeko vā'dhyātmavittamaḥ||
translation: Oh four keepers of the Vedas' teachings, who is she that can explain which among you is the foremost in self-knowledge, the finest in dharma?

sloka: vedāḥ pramāṇaṃ smṛtayaḥ pramāṇaṃ dharmārthayuktaṃ vacanaṃ pramāṇam| yasya pramāṇaṃ na bhavetpramāṇaṃ na tasya kuryādvacanaṃ pramāṇam||
translation: "Vedas and remembered traditions are, respectively, the means of correct knowledge and the means of establishing dharma and artha. For one whose means of correct knowledge is not (established), one should not consider their words as a means of correct knowledge."

sloka: tathā sampradāyo'pi kacitpramāṇamityāha manuḥ| svakulaparamparāyāta ācāraḥ sampradāyaḥ| so'pi śāstravipratipattau draṣṭavyaḥ|
translation: Thus, Manu also says that a tradition, originating from one's own family and furthered by successive generations, is also a form of proof. Such a custom should be observed in the interpretation of scriptures.

sloka: na me'nyatra kṣatriyāyā mano jātu pravartate| ṛṣiputrīṣu cānyāsu nāvarāsu parāsu ca||
translation: My mind never turns away from the kshatriya woman (to whom I am devoted) and similarly not from the daughters of sages, nor in situations involving other women or during battles.

sloka: tasmātpraṇihitātmānaṃ viddi māṃ kalabhāṣiṇi| yasyāṃ me tvayi bhāvo'sti kṣatriyā hyasi kā vadā||
translation: Understand me, who have been dedicated before, as your very self. In whom my nature exists, tell me, O one who speaks like a kala-bhāṣiṇi, what the kṣatriyaas call you, who possess the quality of vadā?

sloka: smṛtiḥ pratyakṣamaitihyam | anumānaścatuṣṭayam |
translation: The means of knowledge consist of smriti (scriptural testimony), pratyaksa (perception), aitihya (historical evidence or tradition), and anumana (inference), arranged in fourfold form.

sloka: tatra yasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya pravṛttiḥ sa pramātā | sa yenārthaṃ pramiṇoti tatpramāṇaṃ | yo'rthaḥ pratīyate tatprameyaṃ | yadarthavijñānaṃ sā pramitiḥ | catasṛṣu caivaṃvidhāsvārthatatvaṃ parisamāpyate |
translation: The activity of one for whom the desire to speak has ceased is a knower. That by which one cognizes an object is the means of correct knowledge. That object which is perceived is the knowable. Knowledge about that object is comprehension. This fourfold relationship with objects is established in all cases.

sloka: yathā rajate idaṃ rajatamiti jñānam| saiva pramecyute ||||
translation: Just as silver is identified when it appears, similarly, this (knowledge) is ascertained to be that (pure consciousness) when it shines forth.

sloka: pramāṇamanubhūtiḥ sā smṛteranyā na sā smṛtiḥ | na pramāṇaṃ smṛtiḥ pūrvapratipattivyapekṣaṇāt|
translation: The experience of a means of valid knowledge is indeed not referred to as remembered knowledge. Rather, remembered knowledge is that which depends on prior established practice.

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam|| ||{prameyauddeśasūtram}
translation: The self, body, senses, objects, intellect, mind, habits, faults, past and future, happiness, suffering, and liberation are the objects of knowledge. (prameyauddeśasūtram)

sloka: pramāṇato'rthapratipattau pravṛttisāmarththadarthavat pramāṇam | tasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya samīhā pravṛttirityucyate | dvayorekatarasya cāpi asannikṛṣṭārthaparicchittiḥ pramā tatsādhakatamaṃ yattattrividhaṃ pramāṇaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: The means of comprehending the purpose, endowed with the power to fulfill its objective, is called pramana (valid proof). This refers to one's desire to laugh, unrelated to it, and the subsequent emergence of a resolved understanding. Additionally, in the case of two or even just one, when dealing with closely related meanings, the most accurate determination serves as the foremost pramana. This threefold pramana is described in the Sankhya Sutra.
