sloka: tatra yasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya pravṛttiḥ sa pramātā |
translation: The one whose natural tendency is associated with your desired laughter, he is the perceiver.

sloka: agne samidhamāhārṣaṃ bṛhate jātavedase | sa me śraddhāṃ ca medhāṃ ca jātavedāḥ pra yacchatu ||
translation: "O Agni, I offer you oblations! May the all-knowing one (Jātavedas) bestow on me faith and intelligence. may he hear my invocation."

sloka: atha sapta pālāśīḥ samidha ārdrā apracchinnāgrāḥ prādeśamātrā ghṛtāktā abhyādhāpayati |
translation: Now, he prepares the ritual by arranging seven tender and unbroken tips of pala tree branches, which are smeared with ghee, as per the specified measure.

sloka: agniṃ parisamūhya brahmacārī tūṣṇīṃ samidhamādadhyāt tūṣṇīṃ vai prājāpatyaṃ prājāpatyo brahmacārī bhavatīti vijñāyate
translation: After gathering firewood silently, the student is recognized as one who has become a follower of the creator's path by carefully and deliberately offering oblations in the fire.

sloka: sa idbhojo yo gṛhave dadātyannakāmāya carate kṛśāya | aramasmai bhavati yāmahūtā utāparīṣu kṛṇute sakhāyam || balaṃ balavato naśyedannahīnasya dehinaḥ| tasmādannaṃ viśeṣeṇa śraddhayāśraddhayāpi vā|| ādatte hi rasaṃ sarvamādityaḥ svagabhastibhiḥ| vāyustasmātsamādāya rasaṃ megheṣu dhārayet|| tattu meghagataṃ bhūmau śakro varṣati tādṛśam| tena digdhā bhaveddevī mahī prītā ca bhārata|| tasyāṃ sasyāni rohanti yairjīvantyakhilāḥ prajāḥ| māṃsamedo'sthimajjānāṃ sambhavastebhya eva hi||
translation: The one who shares his wealth with others, moves about lean to please the needy, dedicates himself to serve the worthy and makes friends with everyone - such a strong one will never be overwhelmed by weakness. Therefore, one should accept food with faith, either with or without it (faith). Indeed, the sun extracts its essence from everything with its rays, while air absorbs the essence from the sky. Similarly, Indra showers down such rich and nourishing rain on earth, which then becomes delighted and gives life to all creatures through its plants, which grow due to the formation of flesh, fat, bones, and marrow.

sloka: nīrajātaśca bhagavānsomo grahagaṇeśvaraḥ| amṛtaṃ ca sudhā caiva svāhā caiva svadhā tathā|| annauṣadhyo mahārāja vīrudhaśca jalodbhavāḥ| yataḥ prāṇabhṛtāṃ prāṇāḥ sambhavanti viśāmpate|| devānāmamṛtaṃ hyannaṃ nāgānāṃ ca sudhā tathā| pitṝṇāṃ ca svadhā proktā paśūnāṃ cāpi vīrudhaḥ||
translation: The Blessed One, Soma, has indeed been born as the lord of the assembly of planets. The immortal nectar and the honey, as well as svaha and svadha, have also come into existence. O King, the life-sustainers of all living beings arise from the herbal and watery substances born in this way. For the gods, it is the nectar, while for the serpents, it is honey. The offering to the ancestors is called svadha, and that for the animals is the herbal substance.

sloka: tasmādvā etasmādātmana ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ | ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī | pṛthivyā oṣadhayaḥ | oṣadhībhyo'nnam | annātpuruṣaḥ |
translation: Therefore, from this self, space has arisen; from space, air; from air, fire; from fire, water; from water, the earth; from earth, plants; from plants, food; from food, the person.

sloka: sa vā eṣa puruṣo'nnarasamayaḥ | tasyedameva śiraḥ | ayaṃ dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ | ayamuttaraḥ pakṣaḥ | ayamātmā | idaṃ pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhā | tadapyeṣa śloko bhavati ||
translation: Indeed, this person, the supreme being, is infused with essential qualities. This very thing is its crown. This one here is its right wing. The other one is its left wing. And this is its self and the support of its tail feathers. Even this verse speaks of it.

sloka: ahamasmi prathamajā ṛtasya | pūrvaṃ devebhyo amṛtasya nābhiḥ | yo mā dadāti sa ideva mā''vāḥ | ahamannamannamadantamadmi |
translation: I am the first-born of the eternal law, born before the gods from its source. The one who gives (me) is indeed the imperishable. I consume everything as the eater of food and the consumer.

sloka: annaṃ prāṇamannamapānamāhuḥ | annaṃ mṛtyuṃ tamu jīvātumāhuḥ | annaṃ brahmāṇo jarasaṃ vadanti | annamāhuḥ prajananaṃ prajānām |
translation: They call it food, life-breath, and water; they say that food enables one to overcome death and sustain life. The learned ones proclaim it as the very embodiment of Brahman, the cause of procreation for living beings.

sloka: bhojayecchvabhyaḥ śvapacebhyaśca vayobhyaścāvapedbhūmāviti nānavattamaśnīyānnaiko na pūrvaṃ | tadapyetadṛcoktaṃ moghamannaṃ vindate apracetā iti
translation: One should offer hospitality to dogs, crows, and young ones, not partaking of their share first, nor considering it the best. Even this has been declared in vain by those without knowledge.

sloka: moghamannaṃ vindate apracetāḥ satyaṃ bravīmi vadha itsa tasya | nāryamaṇaṃ puṣyati no sakhāyaṃ kevalāgho bhavati kevalādī ||
translation: The unintelligent one attains (vindate) worthless food, I declare (bravimi) the truth (satyam); his (tasya) slaughter (vadha itsa) is certain; he does not (na) prosper (pusyati) who treats him (aryamanam) as a friend (sakhyam), only harm (kevalagham) arises for him and others (ādi).

sloka: abhyāgato jñātapūrvo hyajñāto'tithirucyate|
translation: The previously known guest is referred to as unknown, (while) the unfamiliar one is proclaimed as a guest.

sloka: apraṇodyo'tithiḥ sāyaṃ sūryoḍho gṛhamedhinā | kāle prāptastvakāle vā nāsyānaśnangṛhe vaset | |
translation: The sun, setting at the designated time, has been swallowed (by the horizon). Whether it is time's arrival or not, one should not stay away from eating food at home.

sloka: sarveṣvevājasrā agnayaḥ syuḥ agnipūjā ca nityā yathā gṛhamedhe āvasathe śrotriyāvarārdhyānatithīnvāsayet teṣāṃ yathāguṇamāvasathāḥ śayyānnapānaṃ ca videyam
translation: Let all fire rituals, performed with the reverence due to them and regularly as in the Gṛhamedha, be carried out by worthy priests using every kind of fire. In accordance with their respective qualities, proper accommodations, bedding, food, and drink should be provided for them.

sloka: abhṛtānāṃ bhavedbhartā bhṛtānāmanvavekṣakaḥ|
translation: Let him become the protector of the dispossessed and one who scrutinizes those who have been given (i.e., their worthiness).

sloka: saṃvibhāgo hi bhūtānāṃ sarveṣāmeva dṛśyate| tathaivāpacamānebhyaḥ pradeyaṃ gṛhamedhinā||
translation: The distribution of all beings is indeed observed, and similarly, what should be given to those who have come to beg is determined by the householder.

sloka: dadasvānnaṃ dadasvānnaṃ dadasvānnaṃ yudhiṣṭhira ||
translation: Engage your forces in the battle, O Yudhishthira, with (the help of) horses, chariots, and elephants.

sloka: yanna prāpyaṃ tadaprāpyaṃ vidyayā pauruṣeṇa vā | satyo lokapravādo'yaṃ nādattamupatiṣṭhati ||
translation: "Without attaining which, and being unable to attain it, even through knowledge and effort, this is the proclaimed truth: it does not establish itself."

sloka: annaṃ dehi sadā rājan sarvakālasukhāvaham || annena caiva dattena kiṃ na dattaṃ mahītale |||| sarveṣāmeva dānānāmannadānaṃ viśiṣyate || annādbhavanti bhūtāni annenaiva ca varddhate ||||
translation: O king, always give food (to others), for what is there that is not given through this act on earth? Of all forms of giving, the gift of food is the most excellent. Through food, beings arise and grow in this world.

sloka: na kañcana vasatau pratyācakṣīta | tadvratam | tasmādyayā kayā ca vidhayā bahvannaṃ prāpnuyāt | arādhyasmā annamityācakṣate | | edadvā antato'nna~rāddham | antato'smā anna~rādhyate || ||
translation: None whatsoever should be shown special treatment in their abodes, such is the rule. Therefore, one does not obtain great wealth by merely wishing for it through any means or actions. This (the food) is declared to be inedible (for the Brahmin) before being offered, and is made edible (offered) only afterwards.

sloka: na tasmātparamaṃ dānaṃ kiñcidastīti me manaḥ| annātprāṇabhṛtastāta pravardhante hi sarvaśaḥ|| tasmādannaṃ paraṃ loke sarvalokeṣu kathyate| annādbalaṃ ca tejaśca prāṇināṃ vardhate sadā||
translation: "From this, there is nothing superior to giving (dānam) in my opinion. Indeed, all things increase from food (annāt). Therefore, food is called the foremost in the world. From it, strength and radiance increase continuously in living beings."

sloka: annena dhāryate sarvaṃ jagadetaccarācaram| annātprabhavati prāṇaḥ pratyakṣaṃ nāsti saṃśayaḥ||
translation: By this , the entire world, moving and non-moving, is sustained; from this arises the vital breath ; without a doubt , it is the visible that is born from it .

sloka: āyurvedo dhanurvedo gāndharvaścaiva te trayaḥ | arthaśāstra caturthantu vidyā hmaṣṭādaśaiva tāḥ || ||
translation: The three are Ayurveda, Dhanurveda, and Gandharva, and the fourth is Artha-shastra; indeed, these eighteen constitute knowledge.

sloka: iha khalvāyurvedaṃ nāmopāṅgamatharvavedasyānutpādyaivaprajāḥ ślokaśata sahasramadhyāyasahasraṃ ca kṛtavān svayambhūḥ tato'lpāyuṣṭvamalpamedha stvaṃ cālokya narāṇāṃ bhūyo'ṣṭadhā praṇītavān vidhātātharvvasarvasvamāyurvedaṃ prakāśayan| svanāmnā saṃhitāṃ cakre lakṣaślokamayīmṛjum” iti bhāvaprakāśokteḥ |
translation: In this world, the self-existent creator, after having created the science of life (Ayurveda) consisting of thousand shloka and thousand chapters, himself studied it completely. Seeing that even those with short lives and few sacrifices are still able to achieve great things through its knowledge, he made it widely available to people. Thus, revealing Ayurveda as the ultimate science of life, he also created a collection of hundred thousand verses named after himself. This is the explanation of the statement of purpose.

sloka: caraṇavyūhamate ṛgvedasyopavedaḥ āyurvedaḥ
translation: The secondary Vedas, Rigveda's explanation and Ayurveda, have been systematically set forth (in written form).

sloka: kimicchantī saramā predamānaḍdūre hyadhvā jaguriḥ parācaiḥ | kāsmehitiḥ kā paritakmyāsītkathaṃ rasāyā ataraḥ payāṃsi ||
translation: What does Sarama desire, standing so near and barking at those over there? Who indeed is she, and who was the one who enclosed her? How did this happen with rasayā? You (sing.) poured water.

sloka: kīdṛṅṅindraḥ sarame kā dṛśīkā yasyedaṃ dūtīrasaraḥ parākāt | ā ca gacchānmitramenā dadhāmāthā gavāṃ gopatirno bhavāti || nāhaṃ taṃ veda dabhyaṃ dabhatsa yasyedaṃ dūtīrasaraṃ parākāt | na taṃ gūhanti sravato gabhīrā hatā indreṇa paṇayaḥ śayadhve ||
translation: Who are these two, Indra, to whom this message comes from afar? And who are the friends that he goes to, embracing them, becoming their protector? I do not know him, the one to whom this message comes, nor does he keep himself hidden from those who have sharp hearing. Those fierce and mighty ones, struck down by Indra, do not hide themselves. "You all become manifest!" - such is the command given to them.

sloka: imā gāvaḥ sarame yā aicchaḥ pari divo antānsubhage patantī | kasta enā ava sṛjādayudhvyutāsmākamāyudhā santi tigmā || asenyā vaḥ paṇayo vacāṃsyaniṣavyāstanvaḥ santu pāpīḥ | adhṛṣṭo va etavā astu panthā bṛhaspatirva ubhayā na mṛl̤āt ||
translation: You, cows, what is this desire for yours that falls toward the sky from

sloka: ayaṃ nidhiḥ sarame adribudhno gobhiraśvebhirvasubhirnyṛṣṭaḥ | rakṣanti taṃ paṇayo ye sugopā reku padamalakamā jagantha || eha gamannṛṣayaḥ somaśitā ayāsyo aṅgiraso navagvāḥ | ta etamūrvaṃ vi bhajanta gonāmathaitadvacaḥ paṇayo vamannit || evā ca tvaṃ sarama ājagantha prabādhitā sahasā daivyena | svasāraṃ tvā kṛṇavai mā punargā apa te gavāṃ subhage bhajāma || nāhaṃ veda bhrātṛtvaṃ no svasṛtvamindro viduraṅgirasaśca ghorāḥ | gokāmā me acchadayanyadāyamapāta ita paṇayo varīyaḥ || dūramita paṇayo varīya udgāvo yantu minatīrṛtena | bṛhaspatiryā avindannigūl̤hāḥ somo grāvāṇa ṛṣayaśca viprāḥ ||
translation:
This treasure, Sarame, protected by the mighty Adribudhna and the divine cows, is guarded by the Paṇayas. Those pure and renowned Paṇayas, sugopā and reku, protect this padala-mā at Jagantha. 

Eha, come now, to this protected place, where Somashita, Aṅgirasa, and other noble Rishis have enjoyed in the past. Let us also partake of this ūrva today. 

And so, you too, Sarama, having been suddenly struck down by a divine force, serve this svasāra well, lest these auspicious cows abandon you again. I do not know if there is any relation between us, whether as brother or sister, but the ghorā rasas of Indra and Angirasa have hidden it away. 

May the worthy Paṇayas stay far away, summoned by this mantra, as Bṛhaspati, Soma, Grāvāna Rishis, and other viprās fail to find the truth.

sloka: asurāḥ paṇayo nāma rasāpāranivāsinaḥ | piveyaṃ tu payastāsāṃ gavāṃ yāstā niguhatha | asurāstāṃ tathetyuktvā tadājahuḥ payastataḥ sā svabhāvācca laulyācca pātvā tat paya āsuram |
translation: The wicked brewers, named Asuras and residing near the liquor, have declared those who partake in their brewed beverage to be of demonic nature, driven by desire and habit. You (pl.) should abandon that contaminated liquid.

sloka: tāṃ jaghāna tadā kruddha udgirantau payastataḥ jagāma sā bhayodvignā punareva paṇān prati
translation: Then, enraged, he struck her and set off, she having been filled with fear, while the pananas (cows) went back in the opposite direction.

sloka: atha ha vai paṇayo nāmāsurā devānāṃ gorakṣā āsuḥ| tābhir ahāpātasthuḥ| tā ha rasāyāṃ nirudhya valenāpidadhuḥ| te devā aliklavam ūcus suparṇemā no gā anviccheti| te saramām abruvan sarama imā nas tvaṃ gā anviccheti|
translation: Once, the panis named asuras were in charge of protecting the cows of the devas. They hid those cows in a secret place and fastened them there. Then, they offered that place to the serpent Vasuki. When the devas realized this, they urged Suparna to help them saying "Please retrieve our cows." Later on, Sarame addressed Sarama saying "You go and search for our cows."

sloka: aitareyabrāhmaṇe'sti kāṇḍamāraṇyakābhidham | araṇya aiva pāṭhyatvādāraṇyakamitīryate || satraprakaraṇe'nuktiraraṇyādhyayanāya hi | mahāvratasya tasyātra hautra karma vivicyate ||
translation: In the Brāhmaṇa of the Aitareya, what is designated as the Āraṇyaka exists. The Āraṇyaka should indeed be studied in the forest, hence it is called Āraṇyaka. In the Satarprakaraṇa, instructions for studying the Āraṇyaka are mentioned. Here, the specific ritual of the great vow (mahāvrata) is detailed.

sloka: araṇyādhyayanādetad āraṇyakamitīryate | araṇaye tadadhīyītetyevaṃ vākyaṃ pracakṣyate ||
translation: This saying is proclaimed: "Derived from forest-study, it is called 'Āraṇyaka.' It should be studied in the forest."

sloka: tasyā bharturabhicāra uktaṃ prāyaścittaṃ rahasyeṣu
translation: The expiation for her husband's transgression was spoken of in secrecy.

sloka: eṣa vai somo rājā devānāmannaṃ yaccandramāḥ|
translation: This is indeed the king Soma of the gods' delight, the nourishment that is the moon.

sloka: yat idaṃ asmin brahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma daharoഽsmin antarākāśaḥ tasmin yadantaḥ tadanveṣṭavyaṃ tad vāva vijijñāsitavym … …
translation: What is in this city of Brahma, the small lotus-like abode? In that (same place), what is the interior space? That should be sought after, that should be thoroughly investigated...

sloka: śataṃ caikā hṛdasya nāḍyaḥ tāsāṃ mūrdhānamabhiniḥsṛtaikā tayordhvamāyannamṛtatvameti viṣvaṅṅanyā utkramaṇe bhavanti
translation: A hundred of the heart's vessels, from them one emerges at the top; with this, rising upwards, becoming immortal, is what the traveling one does. The other separate ones at the departure.

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: The one born as a brāhmaṇa is to be known by janmanā, and is called dvija by saṃskāraiḥ. With vidyayā, he attains vipratvam through tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam, and iti results in the discernment of prāyaḥcitta.

sloka: agnyādheyaṃ pākayajñānagniṣṭomādikānmakhān | yaḥ karoti vṛto yasya sa tasya rtvigihocyate || ||
translation: The one who performs the agnyadheya and pakayajnas, including agniSToma and other sacrifices, is considered the rtvik of that person.

sloka: yathorṇanābhiḥ sṛjate gṛhṇate ca yathā pṛthivyāmoṣadhayaḥ saṃbhavanti | yathā sataḥ puruṣāt keśalomāni tathā'kṣarāt saṃbhavatīha viśvam || ||
translation:
Just as from the navel abscess, [someone] creates and receives [the embryo], and just as plants grow from the earth,
and just as hair grows from the human body, so does this entire universe arise from the imperishable.

sloka: yaḥ sarvajñaḥ sarvavidyasya jñānamayaṃ tāpaḥ | tasmādetadbrahma nāma rūpamannaṃ ca jāyāte || ||
translation: The all-knowing one, who is the very embodiment of knowledge of all sciences, becomes the heat and suffering because of that. Therefore, this Brahman is named as such, taking on the forms of food, knowledge, and female.

sloka: chandāṃsi yajñāḥ kratavo vratāni bhūtaṃ bhavyaṃ yacca vedā vadanti | asmānmāyī sṛjate viśvametattasmiṃścānyo māyayā sanniruddhaḥ || ||
translation: The meters, sacrifices, and rituals, as well as what has been and will be, the Vedas proclaim. From you is brought forth this entire universe, while another is enveloped by illusion in this very place.

sloka: māyāṃ tu prakṛtiṃ vidyānmāyinaṃ ca maheśvaram | tasyavayavabhūtaistu vyāptaṃ sarvamidaṃ jagat || ||
translation: Indeed, understand maya as prakriti and the controller of maya as such. Everything in this world is permeated by the constituents of maya .

sloka: mayā'dhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sacarācaram|
translation: By my supervision, nature, both moving and stationary, is manifested.

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ| nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam||||
translation: The three qualities born of nature—purity , passion , and darkness —restrain the eternal self in the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: mūlaprakṛtiravikṛtirmahadādyā: prakṛtivikṛtaya: sapta | ṣoḍaśakastu vikāro na prakṛtirna vikṛti: puruṣa: || ||
translation: The unmanifest primal nature and the manifest nature, consisting of the great and the subtle, are, respectively, the seven and the sixteen transformations. Yet, there is no transformation in the purusha or the conscious self.

sloka: tasmātprakṛtirutpannā puruṣeṇa samanvitā || tābhyāntapaḥ kṛtaṃ tatra mūlasthe ca jale sudhīḥ || ||
translation: Hence, nature arises, endowed with purusha, from which there, simplicity is accomplished in both the fundamental and the water.

sloka: saṃbhāvya māyayā yuktastatra supto harissa vai || nārāyaṇeti vikhyātaḥ prakṛtirnārāyaṇī matā || ||
translation: Having been endowed with Maya, the one who is known as Narayana is celebrated as having caused (others) to lie asleep there, and as being united with him, while also being himself asleep. That is considered the primal nature of Narayana.

sloka: parātmanastathā śaktestayoraikyaṃ sadaiva hi | abhinnaṃ tadvapurjñātvā mucyate sarvadoṣataḥ || ||
translation: By realizing the non-duality of the supreme self and power, one is constantly freed from all faults, having understood their inseparable oneness.

sloka: tasya cecchāsmyahaṃ daitya sṛjāmi sakalaṃ jagat | sa māṃ paśyati viśvātmā tasyāhaṃ prakṛtiḥ śivā || ||
translation: If I, the creator of the daityas, am currently manifesting the entire world for him, then the cosmic soul sees me as his own auspicious nature.

sloka: rāma māyā dvidhā bhāti vidyā'vidyeti te sadā |
translation: Rama, maya is twofold, as knowledge and ignorance. You should always remember this.

sloka: dvividhā tu khalu tadvidyasaṃbhāṣā bhavati sandhāyasaṃbhāṣā vigṛhyasaṃbhāṣā ca |
translation: Indeed, there are two kinds of speech for the learned: one is conciliatory speech, and the other is harsh speech used in response.

sloka: prāgeva ca jalpājjalpāntaraṃ parāvarāntaraṃ pariṣadviśeṣāṃśca samyak parīkṣet parīkṣamāṇastu khalu parāvarāntaramimān jalpakaguṇān śreyaskarān doṣavataśca parīkṣeta samyak
translation: Even before, one should thoroughly examine the qualities of those who engage in argumentative banter, both within their own group and in other groups. While observing, they should accurately assess such jalpaka qualities in them, determining which are beneficial and which are harmful.

sloka: tadviddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā | upadekṣyanti te jñānaṃ jñāninastattvadarśinaḥ ||
translation: Understand this truth through reverence, questioning, and service. Those who have realized the truth will teach you knowledge.

sloka: jñānagrahaṇābhyāsastadvidyaiśca saha saṃvādaḥ || ||| taṃ śiṣyagurusabrahmacāriviśiṣṭaśreyo'rthibhiranasūyubhirabhyupeyāt || || pratipakṣahīnamapi vā prayojanārthamarthitve || ||
translation: The practice of acquiring knowledge through discussion with experts is a superior means of spiritual progress for the disciple who is free from envy. Similarly, using negative tendencies in a constructive way can also be beneficial. This is the message.

sloka: jñāyate'neneti jñānamātmavidyāśāstram | tasya grahaṇamadhyayanadhāraṇe abhyāsaḥ satatakriyā'dhyayanaśravaṇacintanāni tadvidyaiśca | saha saṃvāda iti prajñāparipākārthe paripākastu saṃśayacchedanamavijñātārthabodho'dhyavasitābhyanujñānamiti | samāpavādaḥ saṃvādaḥ | vābhā |
translation: Knowledge is considered to arise from this (process) – the self-study of atma-vidyaśastra; its acquisition, study, and retention are the continuous practice of adhyayana, listening, and contemplation. For the accomplished ones, discussion with others is also a part of their refinement process, which includes clarifying doubts, understanding the meaning of what is not known, giving consent, and engaging in constructive debates.

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||||
translation: Debate is the presentation, with supporting reasons and evidence, of a thesis that is consistent with established facts, not in conflict with other principles, based on five limbs (exposition of the subject, reason, example, application, and summary), and encompassing both viewpoints.

sloka: yathoktopapannaḥ chalajātinigrahasthānasādhanopālambhaḥ jalpaḥ
translation: Derived from previous compounds, that which is spoken of as having arisen, and is the means of establishing a firm stance against deceitful elements, such is called argumentation.

sloka: sādharmyavaidharmyotkarṣāpakarṣavarṇyāvarṇyavikalpasādhyaprāptyaprāptiprasaṅgapratidṛṣṭāntānutpattisaṃśayaprakaraṇahetvarthāpattyaviśeṣopapattyupalabdhyanupalabdhinityānityakāryasamāḥ || ||
translation: The consideration of similarities, dissimilarities, advantages and disadvantages, their descriptions, comprehension, acquisition or non-acquisition, contradictions, examples, origins, doubts, discussions, means of accomplishment, special characteristics, and the manifestation or non-manifestation of actions - all these are equal.

sloka: pratijñāhāniḥ pratijñāntaraṃ pratijñāvirodhaḥ pratijñāsaṃnyāso hetvantaramarthāntaraṃ nirarthakamavijñātārthamapārthakamaprāptakālaṃ nyūnamadhikaṃ punaruktamananubhāṣaṇamajñānamapratibhā vikṣepo matānujñā paryanuyojyopekṣaṇaṃ niranuyojyānuyogo'pasiddhānto hetvābhāsāśca nigrahasthānāni || ||
translation: Withdrawal of a promise, contradiction of a previous promise, negation of the meaning of a term, designation of something as different from its true meaning, irrelevant or misunderstood meaning, use of words that are redundant, already stated, or unrelated, ignorance or display of knowledge, distraction, making exceptions, ignoring them, accepting established rules or not, illusions, and establishing the grounds for arguments – these are considered.

sloka: aviśeṣābhihite arthe vaktuḥ abhiprāyātarthāntarakalpanā vākchalam ||||
translation: The speaker's intention, different from the expressed meaning in a given context, is what gives rise to the ambiguity of speech.

sloka: sambhavataḥ arthasya atisāmānyayogātasambhūtārthakalpanā sāmānyacchalam ||||
translation: The concept/meaning of this arising object, due to the excessiveness of commonness, remains unchanged.

sloka: dharmavikalpanirdeśe arthasadbhāvapratiṣedhaḥ upacāracchalam ||||
translation: In the exposition of dharma's controversy, (there is) the rejection of wrong interpretations of meaning and (the establishment of) proper understanding; (it is) prone to fluctuation in application.

sloka: yadā vādī parasya sādhanaṃ sādhviti manyate lābhapūjākhyātikāmaśca bhavati tadā jātiṃ prayuṅkte kadācidayaṃ jātyuttareṇākulīkṛto nottaraṃ pratipadyate uttarāpratipattyā ca nigṛhyate | anabhidhāne ca jātirekāntajayaḥ parasyetyaikāntikātparājayādvaramastu saṃdeha iti yukto jāteḥ prayogaḥ || nyāvā ||
translation: When one is considered to regard another's endeavor as proper and seeks fame and worship from it, then they join a different caste. Sometimes, they become polluted by another caste and are held back. In the case of unidentified caste, victory is gained over the other by complete defeat or not. This is the usage in the matter of caste. Thus (it is).

sloka: saḥ pratipakṣasthāpanāhīnaḥ vitaṇḍā ||||
translation: He is the establisher of counter measures, yet not lacking in dignity; and (he is) without argumentativeness.

sloka: svapakṣarāgeṇa caike nyāyamativartante taca | tattvādhyavasāyasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ jalpavitaṇḍe bījaprarohasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ kaṇṭakaśākhāvaraṇavat || ||
translation: Some women, deviating from the principle of partisanship, protect truth and firmness through advocacy and debate to safeguard the establishment of correct knowledge and to preserve the seedling of thought from getting obstructed by thorny branches.

sloka: vidyānirvedādibhiśca pareṇāvajñāyamānasya | tābhyāṃ vigṛhya kathanam || || vigṛhyeti vijigīṣayā na tattvabubhutsayeti | tadetadvidyāpālanārthaṃ na lābhapūjākhyātyarthamiti |
translation: By ignoring the teachings starting from detachment and including other disciplines, and being disdained by someone else, one should engage in a discourse, motivated not by a desire to gain knowledge but to establish it. This is not meant for fame or for the sake of acquiring wealth and prestige, but only for the protection and preservation of knowledge.

sloka: budhajanairvādaḥ parityajyatām || ||
translation: Let the debate be abandoned by the wise.

sloka: pakṣābhyāṃ ca mayā gupto jaṭāyurna pradahyate| pramādāttatra nirdagdhaḥ patanvāyupathādaham||||
translation: Protected by both wings, the jaṭā creature is not to be consumed; through inattention there, it gets burned down; I am the one who's engaged in falling downwards from the path of air.

sloka: purā vṛtravadhe vṛtte parasparajayaiṣiṇau| ādityamupayātau svo jvalantaṃ raśmimālinam||||
translation: In the past, during the battle against Vritra, you (dual) engaged in combat seeking victory over each other; approaching the radiant and shining Aditya, who is adorned with brilliant rays.

sloka: taṃ māmevaṃ gataṃ putrassupārśvonāma nāmataḥ| āhāreṇa yathākālaṃ bibharti patatāṃ varaḥ||||
translation: The excellent son, named Suparsva, sustains me, who has come in this way, with regular nourishment.

sloka: sampātirnāma nāmnā tu cirañjīvī vihaṅgamaḥ| bhrātā jaṭāyuṣaḥ śrīmānvikhyātabalapauruṣaḥ||||
translation: The bird named Sampati, being long-lived, is renowned for his strength and valor, the brother of Jatayus.

sloka: ahaṃ tāta yathākālamāmiṣārthī khamāplutaḥ| mahendrasya girerdvāramāvṛtya susamāsthitaḥ|||| eva muktastato'haṃ taissiddhai: paramaśobhanaiḥ| sa ca me rāvaṇo rājā rakṣasāṃ prativeditaḥ|||| harandāśaratherbhāryāṃ rāmasya janakātmajām| bhraṣṭābharaṇakauśeyāṃ śokavegaparājitām|||| rāmalakṣmaṇayornāma krośantīṃ muktamūrdhajām|
translation: "Father, just as I am now, seeking my purpose, having immersed myself in the nectar of spiritual wisdom, steadily positioned beyond Indra's mountain peak, so I have been released by those most auspicious accomplishments. Among them is Ravana, king of the rakshasas, made known to me. The married daughter of Dasaratha, adorned and defeated by the force of grief, has fallen, losing her ornaments, from Rama and Lakshmana. I hear her calling out, with disheveled hair."

sloka: sā hovāca maitreyī yannu ma iyaṃ bhagoḥ sarvā pṛthivī vittena pūrṇā syātkathaṃ tenāmṛtā syāmiti neti hovāca yājñavalkyo yathaivopakaraṇavatāṃ jīvitaṃ tathaiva te jīvitaṃ syāt amṛtatvasya tu nā''śā'sti vitteneti
translation: Maitreyi, she asked: 'How can this woman, my half, be made full with all the earthly wealth? Can she then attain immortality?' Yajnavalkya replied: 'Just as the life of material objects is, so will her life be. However, immortality cannot be achieved through wealth.'

sloka: yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavati taditara itaraṃ jighrati taditara itaraṃ paśyati taditara itara śṛṇoti taditara itaramabhivadati taditara itaraṃ manute taditara itaraṃ vijānāti | yatra vā asya sarvamātmaivābhūt tatkena kaṃ jighret tatkena kaṃ paśyet tatkena ka śṛṇuyāt tatkena kamabhivadet tatkena kaṃ manvīta tatkena kaṃ vijānīyāt | yeneda sarvaṃ vijānāti taṃ kena vijānīyād vijñātāramare kena vijānīyāditi || ||
translation: Where duality arises, there one 'sees' the other as an object, 'hears' the other, 'speaks to' the other, 'thinks of' and 'understands' the other. But where all aspects of him become his own Self, then what can one 'perceive', 'hear', 'address', 'conceive', or 'know' there? And who is it that one should 'know' as the knower of everything, when even the knower itself is to be 'known'?

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ śraddhāṃ juhoti taseyā āhuteḥ somo rājā saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer their faith; then the king, Soma, arises from the offered oblation.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ somā~ rājānaṃ juhoti tasyā āhutervarṣa saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer oblation to the king Soma; from that offering, rain is produced.

sloka: dhūmaḥ jyotiḥsalilamarutāṃ sannipātaḥ kva meghaḥ
translation: Where in the assembly of winds, lights, and liquids is the cloud?

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ varṣaṃ juhoti tasyā āhuteranna~ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer a rain shower; from that oblation, it (the fire) does not become less.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ annaṃ juhoti tasyā āhuteretaḥ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer oblations; from that (oblation) offered in it, this (wondrous entity) arises.

sloka: tasminnetasminnagnau devāḥ reto juhoti tasyā āhutergarbhaḥ saṃbhavati
translation: In that very fire, the gods offer the seed; from its heat, the fertile germ arises.

sloka: sūrasuryāryamādityadvādaśātmadivākarāḥ | bhāskarāhaskarabradhnaprabhākaradivākarāḥ bhāsvadvisvatsaptāśvaharidaśvoṣṇaraśmayaḥ | vikartanārkamārtaṇḍamihirāruṇapūṣaṇaḥ dyumaṇistaraṇirmitrascitrabhānurvirocanaḥ | vibhāvasurgrahapatistviṣāṃpatiraharpatiḥ bhānurhaṃsaḥ sahasrāṃśustapanaḥ savitā raviḥ | māṭharaḥ piṅlo daṇḍaścaṇḍāṃśoḥ pāripārśvikāḥ
translation: Suryas, gods, and men, twelve-flamed like the sun, o Moon and Fire, Dawn's bringers; o Seven-horse chariot of Day, drawn by fiery steeds; o Creator of the day's light, shining one - you are Indu, Vasu, Agni, Soma, Mitra, Varuna, Dhatri, Graha, Pati, and Aryaman. O Viashvana, you shine with a thousand rays, Savitar, Ravi, you are the sustainer, the nourisher, the supporter, the protector, the prosperity-enhancer, the destroyer of darkness, and the source of all growth. You are Bhaga, Vidhatri, the one who shines in the sky, and the golden-winged Garuda. O Lord of the universe, you hold Vasuki, Ananta, and Airavata as your reins.

sloka: svīryateḥ vā | suvateḥ vā | sūryaḥ sarteḥ vā |
translation: Is it strength's master, or happiness' giver, or the sun that, lacking nothing, (is such a master)?

sloka: sūryasya patnī saṃjñābhūttanayā viśvakarmaṇaḥ | manuryamo yamī caiva tadūpatyāni vai mune || || saṃjñayamityathārkaśva chāyāyāmātmajatrayama | śanaiśvaraṃ manuñcanyaṃ tapatīñcapyajījanat || || tato vivasvānākhyāte tayaivāraṇyasaṃsthitām | samādhidṛṣṭayā dadṛśe tāmaśvāṃ tapasi svitāma || || vājirūpadharaḥ so'tha tasyāṃ devāvathāśvinau | janayāmāsa revantaṃ retaso'nte ca bhāskaraḥ || ||
translation: The wife of the sun, named Sanjna, gave birth to three children sired by Vishvakarman: Manu, Yama, and Yamī. I also was born from her through a subtle form. Just as Arka-shva is the cool shade, she became the shadowy figure established in the forest. The two Asvin gods were born there as well, one from her physical essence and the other from the rays of light. Later, Vivasvan saw his wife there in that state.

sloka: tat sūryasya devatvaṃ tanmahitvaṃ madhyā kartorvitataṃ saṃ jabhāra yadedayukta haritaḥ sadhasthādādrātrī vāsastanute simasmai
translation: You all should revere that as the godhood of the sun and its greatness, which, as the two hands of the maker, holds, supports, and gives away day and night.

sloka: tatsaviturvareṇyaṃ bhargo devasya dhīmahi | dhiyo yo naḥ pracodayāt ||
translation: We meditate on the splendor of the sun's god, the excellent one to be chosen. May he inspire our thoughts.

sloka: oṃ bhūrbhuvaḥ svaḥ | tatsa̭vi॒turvareṇya॒ṃ bhargo̭ de॒vasya̭dhīmahi | dhiyo॒ yo na̭ḥ praco॒dayā̭t ||
translation: Om. The divine light of the three realms, we meditate on its excellent greatness; may it inspire our intellect.

sloka: ṛgbhiḥ pūrvāhṇe divi deva īyate | yajurvede tiṣṭhati | madhye ahnaḥ | sāmavedenāstamaye mahīyate | vedairaśūnyastribhireti sūryaḥ |
translation: With rays, the god rises in the eastern direction of the sky at dawn; he dwells in the Yajurveda during midday; and with the Sama Veda, he becomes dominant in the evening on earth. Unattached to the three Vedas, he shines as the sun.

sloka: suṣumno harikeśaśca viśvakarmā tathaiva ca | viśvaśravāḥ punaścānyaḥ saṃyadvasurataḥ paraḥ || arvāvasuriti khyātaḥ svarakaḥ sapta kīrtitāḥ | suṣumnaḥ sūryaraśmistu puṣṇāti śiśiradyutim ||
translation: Susumna and Harikesha, as well as Visvakarma, are known to be endowed with universal fame. Another one, named Arvasuriti, is also celebrated, along with Svaka and the seven praised ones. Illuminating the rays of the sun, Susumna nourishes the cool splendor.

sloka: saṃsthitenaikacakreṇa paṃcāreṇa trinābhinā || hiraṇmayena bhagavāṃstathaiva haridarvaṇā || ||
translation: With a single, unwavering wheel, O lord, equipped with three parts and five spokes, you indeed exist, resplendent in golden glory.

sloka: ete tapanti varṣanti bhānti vānti sṛjanti ca | bhūtānāmaśubhaṃ karma vyapohantīha kīrttitāḥ || ete sahaiva sūryeṇa bhramanti divi bhānugāḥ | vimāne ca sthito nityaṃ kāmage vātaraṃhasi ||
translation: These (ete, neutral accusative dual) heat, rain, shine, and generate as well. They expel evil deeds from beings. They are called thus that they always move along with the sun in the sky and dwell constantly in the wind on earth.

sloka: saratho'dhiṣṭhito devairādityairmunibhistathā || gaṃdharvairapsarobhiśca grāmaṇīsarparākṣasaiḥ || ||
translation: The chariot is occupied by the gods, Ādityas, sages, as well as by Gandharvas, Apsaras, Grāmaṇī-serpent-rākṣasas.

sloka: sūryeṇa viṣuvaṃ vidyā tkālaṃ somena lakṣayet || samā rātrirahaścaiva yadā tadviṣuvaṃ bhavet || ||
translation: The time is measured by the sun and observed as "viṣuvam" (equinoctial point) with the help of the moon; similarly, day and night become equal.

sloka: devaliṅ‌gapraticchannaḥ svarbhānurdevasaṃsadi | praviṣṭaḥ somamapibat candrārkābhyāṃ ca sūcitaḥ || ||
translation: Concealed by the peak of Devalinga, entered the assembly of gods, having drunk Soma, made known by the light of Chandrarka.

sloka: pramāṇaprameyasaṃśayaprayojanadṛṣṭāntasiddhāntāvayavatarkanirṇayavādajalpavitaṇḍāhetvābhāsacchalajātinigrahasthānānāṃ tatvajñānānniḥśreyasādhigamaḥ || {padārthoddeśasūtram}
translation: Knowledge of the true nature of reality's aspects such as pramana (means of right knowledge), prameya (the knowable), saṃśaya (doubt), prayojana (aim), dṛṣṭānta (example), siddhanta (conclusion), avayava (constituent), tarka (logical reasoning), nirṇaya (ascertainment), vāda (debate), jalpa (wrangling), vitaṇḍā (caviling), ahetu (groundless), ābhāsa (semblance), chala (quibbling), jāti (false generalization), nigraha (refutation) leads to the attainment of niḥśreyasa (supreme good).

sloka: pratyakṣānumānopamānaśabdāḥ pramāṇāni || || {pramāṇauddeśasūtram}
translation: Perception, inference, and comparison are the means of valid knowledge. (Pramāṇauddeśasūtra)

sloka: ātmaśarīrendriyārthabuddhimanaḥpravṛttidoṣapretyabhāvaphaladuḥkhāpavargāḥ tu prameyam|| ||{prameyauddeśasūtram}
translation: The self, body, senses, objects, intellect, and mind, along with the manifestation, flaws, states after death, fruits, suffering, and liberation – all these constitute the object of knowledge.

sloka: samānānekadharmopapatteḥ vipratipatteḥ upalabdhyanupalabdhyavyavasthātaḥ ca viśeṣāpekṣaḥ vimarśaḥ saṃśayaḥ || {saṃśayalakṣaṇam}
translation: Doubt arises, based on the understanding of various equally applicable and opposing attributes, occurrences, non-occurrences, and having a particular focus on special conditions, in the form of consideration or contemplation.

sloka: yaṃ arthaṃ adhikṛtya pravartate tatprayojanam ||{prayojanalakṣaṇam}
translation: Determining the purpose is that activity which is undertaken for a specific end.

sloka: laukikaparīkṣakāṇāṃ yasminarthe buddhisāmyaṃ saḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ || {dṛṣṭāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: For those who judge mundane matters, the one in whom (their) understanding is equalized in that matter, he is the illustrative example.

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {abhyupagamasiddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established doctrine is the acceptance of the locus of rule in the treatise. (Here, 'established' and 'acceptance' are in passive voice, indicating that they have been established and accepted before.)

sloka: pratijñāhetūdāharaṇopanayanigamanāni avayavāḥ || {avayavauddeśasūtram}
translation: The components of an argument are the proposition, reason, example, argument introduction, and conclusion.

sloka: avijñātatatve arthe kāraṇopapattitaḥ tattvajñānārthaṃ uhaḥ tarkaḥ||
translation: Derived from the cause of understanding the true nature, the instrument (tarka) has arisen for gaining knowledge of what remains unrealized.

sloka: vimṛśya pakṣapratipakṣābhyāṃ arthāvadhāraṇaṃ nirṇayaḥ||
translation: After pondering and carefully considering the arguments for and against, one ascertains the true meaning.

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||
translation: Debate, which is based on proofs, arguments, means of valid knowledge, and has assumed the form of five limbs, is non-contradictory and has grasped positions and counter-positions.

sloka: yathoktopapannaḥ chalajātinigrahasthānasādhanopālambhaḥ jalpaḥ ||
translation: Derived from past participle forms, what has been spoken of as the means to establish a firm control over fluctuating tendencies and debates.

sloka: saḥ pratipakṣasthāpanāhīnaḥ vitaṇḍā ||
translation: He is indeed the one who does not establish opposition and is free from harshness.

sloka: savyabhicāraviruddhaprakaraṇasamasādhyasamakālātītāḥ hetvābhāsāḥ ||
translation: Previous actions contrary to the regular course, along with their causes that are no longer applicable, are understood as having been passively brought to a conclusion.

sloka: vacanavighātaḥ arthavikalpopapattyā chalam ||
translation: The obstacle to speech is made unsteady by the arising of indecision regarding meaning.

sloka: sādharmyavaidharmyābhyāṃ pratyavasthānaṃ jātiḥ||
translation: The class establishes its distinct existence through both similarity and difference.

sloka: vipratipattiḥ apratipattiḥ ca nigrahasthānam || tadvikalpātjātinigrahasthānabahutvam ||
translation: The controlled posture (nigraha-sthana) is due to the absence or presence of non-attainment (apratipattiḥ/pratipattiḥ). Its manifoldness (bahutvam) arises from the distinction of those two.

sloka: duḥkhajanmapravṛttidoṣamithyājñānānāṃ uttarottarāpāye tadanantarāpāyātapavargaḥ||
translation: The destruction of the succession of accumulated errors and false knowledge from beginningless birth and activity, and the subsequent attainment of higher and higher states of understanding – this is the means of liberation.

sloka: śvetā raktā ca pītā ca kṛṣṇā kāpotasannibhā | tiktā ca kaṭukā caiva kaṣāyalavaṇāmlakā || madhurā ṣaḍrasopetā sarvasampatkarī dharā |
translation: The white, red, and also the yellow one, the black resembling a crow; pungent, bitter, and also astringent, sour-tasting, and sweet, endowed with all auspicious qualities, and supportive - these are the colors and tastes.

sloka: vakṣye'haṃ grāmavinyāsaṃ śāstre saṃkṣepataḥ kramāt | daṇḍakaṃ sarvatobhadraṃ nandyāvartaṃ tu padmakam || svastikaṃ prastaraṃ caiva kārmukaṃ ca caturmukham | evaṃ cāṣṭavidhaṃ grāmaṃ tattadrūpeṇa saṃjñitam ||
translation: I will explain the arrangement of villages according to the scripture, in a succinct and orderly manner. The straight daṇḍaka is all-auspicious, while nandyāvarta is in the shape of a lotus. Svastika is spread out, and kārmuka is four-faced. Thus, the village is designated by these eight forms.

sloka: alpākṣaramasandigdhaṃ sāravadviśvato mukham| astobhamanavadhyañca sūtraṃ sūtravido viduḥ||
translation: The experts know it as a concise, unambiguous statement with a universal face and destined to be ineffable.

sloka: tac cakṣur devahitaṃ purastāc chukram uc carat | paśyema śaradaḥ śataṃ jīvema śaradaḥ śatam
translation: We should use that divinely inspired insight to see; may we live for a hundred autumns.

sloka: tasmādyajñātsarvahuta ṛca: sāmāni jajñire | chandāṃsi jajñire tasmādyajustasmādajāyata ||
translation: "Therefore, the samans and chants were born from the offered sacrifices; the Vedic hymns were born from them, and hence arose all this."

sloka: yad vai yajñasya sāmnā yajuṣā kriyate śithilaṃ tat | yad ṛcā tad dṛḍham |
translation: When the sacrificial rite is made pliable with sāman and yajus, it becomes firm with ṛc.

sloka: ekaṃ sadviprā bahudhā vadantyagniṃ yamaṃ mātariśvānamāhuḥ ||
translation: The revered ones call the one entity by many names such as Agni, Yama, and Mātariśvan.

sloka: saṃgaṭhana sūktam saṃvanana āṅgirasaḥ| agniḥ saṃjñānam| anuṣṭup triṣṭup| saṃsa॒midyṷvase vṛṣa॒nnagne॒ viśvā̭nya॒rya ā | i॒l̤aspa॒de sami̭dhyase॒ sa no॒ vasū॒nyā bha̭ra || saṃ ga̭cchadhva॒ṃ saṃ va̭dadhva॒ṃ saṃ vo॒ manā̭ṃsi jānatām | de॒vā bhā॒gaṃ yathā॒ pūrvḙ saṃjānā॒nā u॒pāsa̭te || sa॒mā॒no mantra॒: sami̭tiḥ samā॒nī sa̭mā॒naṃ mana̭: sa॒ha ci॒ttamḙṣām | sa॒mā॒naṃ mantra̭ma॒bhi ma̭ntraye vaḥ samā॒nena̭ vo ha॒viṣā̭ juhomi || sa॒mā॒nī va॒ ākṷ̄tiḥ samā॒nā hṛda̭yāni vaḥ | sa॒mā॒nama̭stu vo॒ mano॒ yathā̭ va॒: susa॒hāsa̭ti ||
translation:
Gather together, converse and make my praise known,
As the ancient ones did when kindling the sacred fire.
With this unifying mantra, I offer my oblation to you,
May your minds be one, as is your origin.

May your hearing and hearts be united,
And may your thoughts be harmonious and beneficial.
I invoke this unity in you, as it has always been.

sloka: sāmāni yo vetti sa veda tattvam |
translation: The one who understands the equalities, indeed he knows the truth.

sloka: sāmna udgītho rasaḥ |
translation: The udgeetha (sacrificial hymn) is the essence of sama (harmony or the Sama Veda).

sloka: jagrāha pāṭhyaṃ ṛgvedāt‌ sāmabhyo gītameva ca yajurvedādabhinayān rasamātharvaṇādapi||
translation: He took up the recitation of the Rigveda, savoring the Samahs and skillfully from the Yajurveda, as well as from the Atharvaveda.

sloka: tata utkocakaṃ tīrthaṃ gatvā dhaumyāśramaṃ tu te| taṃ vavruḥ pāṇḍavā dhaumyaṃ paurohityāya bhārata||
translation: After reaching the renowned tīrtha (holy place) named Utkocaka, the Pāṇḍavas approached Dhaumya to serve as their purohitya, O Bharata.

sloka: abhyaṣiñcattato dhaumyo vyāsaśca sumahātapāḥ| nāradaṃ ca puraskṛtya devalaṃ cāsitaṃ munim||
translation: Then Dhaumya and Sumahatapas Vyasa initiated the ritual, having approached Narada and Devala, the sage.

sloka: vyāghrapāda iti khyāto vedavedāṅgapāragaḥ| tasyāhamabhavaṃ putro dhaumyaścāpi mamānujaḥ||
translation: Known as "vyaghrapada," the master of Vedic texts is identified; I am his son, and Dhaumya is my brother.

sloka: kṣīrodanasamāyuktaṃ bhojanaṃ hi prayaccha me||
translation: Please provide me with a meal that is associated with kṣīrauda.

sloka: śakrarūpaṃ sa kṛtvā tu sarvairdevagaṇairvṛtaḥ| sahasrākṣastadā bhūtvā vajrapāṇirmahāyaśāḥ||
translation: Having assumed the form of Indra, he became adorned by all the groups of gods and, becoming a thousand-eyed one, took up the thunderbolt, becoming renowned with great glory.

sloka: etasminnantare kaścidṛṣirdhaumyo nāmāyodastasya śiṣyāstrayo babhūvurupamanyurāruṇirvedaśceti||
translation: In the near past, a certain Rishi named Dhaumya did not have any students. Then, three—Upamanyu, Aruni, and the Veda—became his students.

sloka: sa ekaṃ śiṣyamāruṇiṃ pāñcālaṃ preṣayāmāsa gaccha kedārakhaṇḍaṃ badhāneti|| ta tatra saṃviveśa kedārakhaṇḍe śayāne ca tathā tasmiṃstadudakaṃ tasthau||
translation: He, the selected one, ordered you, Aruṇi from Pāñcāla, "Go to the Kedāra section." You then fully pervaded the Kedāra section and likewise stood in that very water.

sloka: sa evamukta upādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca yasmādbhavānkedārakhaṇḍaṃ vidāryotthitastasmātuddālaka eva nāmnā bhavānbhaviṣyatītyupādhyāyenānugṛhītaḥ||
translation: Having been addressed thus, the teacher replied, "You will be known by the name Uddalaka from now on, because you have split apart the 'kedāra' portion (of the Vedas)."

sloka: sa upādhyāyaṃ pratyuvāca bho bhaikṣyeṇa vṛttiṃ kalpayāmīti||
translation: He said to the teacher, "I will adopt a life of mendicancy."

sloka: tamupādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca mayyanivedya bhaikṣyaṃ nopayoktavyamiti|| sa tathetyuktvā bhaikṣyaṃ caritvopādhyāyāya nyavedayat||
translation: The teacher replied to him, "One should not ask for alms from me." After saying this, he then proceeded to inform the teacher about his having done so.

sloka: tamupādhyāyaḥ pratyuvāca naiṣā nyāyyā guruvṛttiranyeṣāmapi bhaikṣyopajīvināṃ vṛttyuparodhaṃ karoṣi ityevaṃ vartamāno lubdho'sīti ||
translation: The teacher replied, "This is not a proper conduct for mendicants like you. Acting thus greedily, you are obstructing their way of living."

sloka: sa tairarkapatrairbhakṣitaiḥ kṣāratiktakaṭurūkṣaistīkṣṇavipākaiścakṣuṣyupahato'ndho babhūva|| tataḥ so'ndho'pi caṅkramyamāṇaḥ kūpe papāta||
translation: With those bittered, pungent, and astringent remnants of fruits consumed by the sun's rays, he became blind. Then, even he, while moving around, fell into the well.

sloka: tamaśvināvāhatuḥ prītau svastavānayā gurubhaktyā upādhyāyasya te kārṣṇāyasā dantā bhavato'pi hiraṇmayā bhaviṣyanti cakṣuṣmāṃśca bhaviṣyasīti śreyaścāvāpsyasīti||
translation: "May the teacher's instructions, accepted with devotion, cause your shining iron (weapons) to become gold-like in the battle against the Ashvin brothers. You will then see clearly and attain greatness."

sloka: tataḥ śaṅkhāśca bheryaśca paṇavānakagomukhāḥ | sahasaivābhyahanyanta sa śabdastumulo'bhavat || tataḥ śvetairhayairyukte mahati syandane sthitau | mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaścaiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ || pāñcajanyaṃ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṃ dhanañjayaḥ | pauṇḍraṃ dadhmau mahāśaṅkhaṃ bhīmakarmā vṛkodaraḥ ||
translation: Then, conches and drums, along with trumpets, were sounded together, creating a tremendous uproar. There, in a grand chariot drawn by white horses, stood Madhava and the Pandava, who blew their divine conches. Hrishikesha blew Pancajanya, Dhananjaya blew Devadatta, while Bhimakarmavirka, with his powerful chest, sounded the great conch Paundra.

sloka: asthānasnehakārpaṇyadharmādharmadhiyā''kulam | pārthaṃ prapannamuddiśya śāstrāvataraṇaṃ kṛtam || ||
translation: With the purpose of guiding the surrenderering Partha, a treatise expounding on the opposing duties has been composed, relating to the lineage characterized by compassionate hospitality.

sloka: dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ | māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāścaiva kimakurvata saṃjaya ||
translation: Dhrtarastra, having spoken, asked Sanjaya: "What were the cousins who had assembled in the battlefield of Kuruksetra, intent on fighting, doing - both my people and the Pandavas?"

sloka: dharmakṣayāt trāyate iti dharmakṣetram |
translation: The termed 'dharmakṣetra' protects from the destruction (of righteousness).

sloka: sañjaya uvāca dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṃ vyūḍhaṃ duryodhanastadā | ācāryamupasaṃgamya rājā vacanamabravīt || paśyaitāṃ pāṇḍuputrāṇāmācārya mahatīṃ camūm | vyūḍhāṃ drupadaputreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā ||
translation: Sanjaya said, having seen, meanwhile, the Pandava army arranged, King Duryodhana approached his teacher and spoke. "Behold, O instructor, this great host of the sons of Pandu, arranged by your intelligent pupil, the son of Drupada."

sloka: aparyāptaṃ tadasmākaṃ balaṃ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam | paryāptaṃ tvidameteṣāṃ balaṃ bhīmābhirakṣitam || ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathābhāgamavasthitāḥ | bhīṣmamevābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi ||
translation: Our strength, previously unsurpassed and protected by Bhishma, has now been surpassed. But this strength of yours, protected by Bhima, is still sufficient for you both. Being stationed in all respective positions, protect Bhishma alone; you all, being indeed capable, should protect him.

sloka: mahīpate | senayorubhayormadhye rathaṃ sthāpaya me'cyuta || yāvadetānnirikṣe'haṃ yoddhukāmānavasthitān | kairmayā saha yoddhavyamasmin raṇasamudyame || yotsyamānānavekṣe'haṃ ya ete'tra samāgatāḥ | dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddheryuddhe priyacikīrṣavaḥ ||
translation: O king, position my chariot in the middle of both armies. I will observe those eager for battle until they are stationary. With whom should I fight in this encounter? Inform me, O unfailing one. I wish to see those who have gathered here, eager and ready for battle, seeking to please the wicked-minded Dhartarashtra in this battle.

sloka: pārtha paśyaitānsamavetānkurūniti ||
translation: "Partha, behold these Kurus assembled here!"

sloka: dṛṣṭvemaṃ svajanaṃ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṃ samupasthitam || sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṃ ca pariśuṣyati vepathuśca śarīre me romaharṣaśca jāyate || gāṇḍīvaṃ sraṃsate hastāttvakcaiva paridahyate na ca śaknomyavasthātuṃ bhramatīva ca me manaḥ || nimittāni ca paśyāmi viparītāni keśava na ca śreyo'nupaśyāmi hatvā svajanamāhave || na kāṅkṣe vijayaṃ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṃ sukhāni ca kiṃ no rājyena govinda kiṃ bhogairjīvitena vā ||
translation: Having seen this my kin, Krsna, prepared for battle, my limbs sink, my mouth becomes dry, my body shivers, my hair stands on end; the bow, Gāṇḍīva, slips from my hand, my skin feels as if on fire, I am unable to stand steady, my mind whirls; and yet I see adverse omens, Kesava, and I do not see any good in killing my own people in this battle, nor do I desire victory, kingdom, or pleasures; O Govinda, even life does not seem worth living after killing my own kinsmen.

sloka: aho bata mahatpāpaṃ kartuṃ vyavasitā vayam | yadrājyasukhalobhena hantuṃ svajanamudyatāḥ || yadi māmapratīkāramaśastraṃ śastrapāṇayaḥ | dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyustanme kṣemataraṃ bhavet ||
translation: Alas, have we decided to commit such a great sin, that we are ready to kill our own people due to our infatuation with power and happiness? If only those wielding weapons as their power would not attack me unopposed, the sons of Dhritarashtra would be less harmful to me in this battle.

sloka: kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ | dharme naṣṭe kulaṃ kṛtsnamadharmo'bhibhavatyuta || utsannakuladharmāṇāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ janārdana | narake'niyataṃ vāso bhavatītyanuśuśruma ||
translation: "In the destruction of a lineage, its eternal traditions perish. When dharma is lost, adharma prevails throughout the family. Indeed, we have heard that when a family's traditional duties are destroyed, O Janardana, people residing in such families inevitably dwell in hell. Such is the plight of those who violate their family's dharma."

sloka: yadyapyete na paśyanti lobhopahatacetasaḥ | kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ mitradrohe ca pātakam || kathaṃ na jñeyamasmābhiḥ pāpādasmānnivartitum | kulakṣayakṛtaṃ doṣaṃ prapaśyadbhirjanārdana ||
translation: Even if these, their senses blinded by greed, do not see the transgression caused by the destruction of the family and the sin in betraying friends, how should we not recognize that we must turn away from this evil, having seen it, O beholder of people?

sloka: nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrānnaḥ kā prītiḥ syājjanārdana | pāpamevāśrayedasmānhatvaitānātatāyinaḥ || tasmānnārhā vayaṃ hantuṃ dhārtarāṣṭrānsvabāndhavān | svajanaṃ hi kathaṃ hatvā sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava ||
translation: What pleasure, O vanquisher of enemies, could there be for us in killing the Dhartarastras, the sons of our own family? After killing them, how could we be happy? Therefore, it is not befitting us to kill them, these our kinsmen. Indeed, how could we, having killed our own people, ever be at ease, O Mādhava?

sloka: ū॒rdhva ū॒ ṣu ṇo̭ adhvarasya hota॒ragne॒ tiṣṭha̭ de॒vatā̭tā॒ yajī̭yān |
translation: Stand aloft, O hotar, as the leader of the ritual, steadfast among the divine invitees for the sacrificial offerings.

sloka: agnirekākṣareṇa vāca mudajayat
translation: The fire, exhilarated by the single syllable (OM), is winning.

sloka: vākyaṃ syādyogyatākāṅkṣāsattiyuktaḥ padoccayaḥ |
translation: The collection of words, desirous of suitability and readiness for uttering a meaningful statement, will have been combined.

sloka: śabdaḥ anumānaṃ arthasya anupalabdheḥ anumeyatvāt ||
translation: Sound is the means of inferring something's existence when it's not directly perceived.

sloka: āptopadeśaḥ śabdaḥ|
translation: The word, having been indicated by the competent.

sloka: āptaḥ khalu sākṣātkṛtadharmā |
translation: Indeed, the duty has been directly experienced and accomplished by the worthy one.

sloka: āptopadeśasāmarthyātśabdātarthasampratyayaḥ || pūraṇapradāhapāṭanānupalabdheḥ ca sambandhābhāvaḥ ||
translation: Understanding through the power of an appropriate instruction, the connection arises from a word to its intended meaning; absence of the previous context prevents such a relationship, just as in the case of the nonexistence of a connection after falling down or giving away (something).

sloka: yenoccāritena sāsnālāṅgūlakakudakhuraviṣāṇināṃ saṃpratyayo bhavati sa śabdaḥ |
translation: The sound that is made when this (instrument) is caused to be uttered by the nails, tips of fingers, horns, and hooves.

sloka: svapnādipratyaye bāhyaṃ sarvathā na hi neṣyate || ||sarvatrālambanaṃ bāhyaṃ deśakālānyathātmakam | janmanyekatra bhinne vā tathā kālāntare'pi vā || ||taddeśo vānyadeśo vā svapnajñānasya gocaraḥ | alātacakre'lātaṃ syācchīghrabhramaṇasaṃskṛtam || ||gandharvanagare'bhrāṇi pūrvadṛṣṭaṃ gṛhādi ca | pūrvānubhūtatoyaṃ ca raśmitaptoṣaraṃ tathā || ||mṛgatoyasya vijñāne kāraṇatvena kalpyate | dravyāntare viṣāṇaṃ ca śaśasyatmā ca kāraṇam || ||śaśaśṛṅgadhiyo mauṇḍyaṃ niṣedhe śiraso'sya ca | vastvantarairasaṃsṛṣṭaḥ padārthaḥ śūnyatādhiyaḥ || ||kāraṇatvaṃ padārthānāmasadvākyārthakalpane | atyantānanubhūto'pi buddhyā yo'rthaḥ prakalpyate ||
translation:
In the investigation of things external to the waking and dream states, nothing is carried over at all times and in every situation. External objects are dependent on place, time, and other distinct factors. They may appear to one sense organ or another in different locations, even at a different time, or in any other place. The sphere of perception of such knowledge is determined by the locus of that perception, whether it be in the body's extremities or elsewhere. This includes experiences such as flying through the city of the gandharvas (a type of celestial being) and entering a previously seen house, among others.

The awareness of these experiences is considered to be the cause of the objects experienced, like the perception of the mrigatoya (a kind of fluid) is considered to be the cause of that substance. Similarly, the cause of the appearance of the sun is its own brightness and heat. The concept of zero is also said to arise from the absence of any particular object.

Furthermore, the meaning of words such as "existence" or "non-existence," when fully realized, can be understood as a mental construct, even though they may appear to refer to something external. This understanding arises not only from direct experience but also from the power of reason. The objects of perception are considered to exist because of their own intrinsic nature and the causes that give rise to them, rather than being dependent on words or mental constructs alone.

In summary, this passage explores the relationship between external objects, perception, and language, emphasizing that ultimate reality cannot be reduced to mere names or concepts but is rooted in direct experience and causality.

sloka: atyantāsatyapi jñānamarthe śabdaḥ karoti hi|
translation: The word that denotes falsehood, when used in the context of knowledge, indeed brings about such [false] knowledge.

sloka: tasya retaḥ pracaskanda dṛṣṭvāpsarasamurvaśīm| apsūpaspṛśato rājanmṛgī taccāpibattadā|| tasyarṣeḥ śṛṅgaṃ śirasi rājannāsīnmahātmanaḥ| tenarṣyaśṛṅga ityevaṃ tadā sa prathito'bhavat||
translation: Having seen the spilling of his semen into the waters, O king, just like a river flowing towards the sea, and a female deer entering the same water, then on that very spot, the great-souled sage also released (his) seed. Therefore, he became known as Ṛṣyaśṛṅga.

sloka: purohitāpacārācca tasya rājño yadṛcchayā| na vavarṣa sahasrākṣastato'pīḍyanta vai prajāḥ||
translation: Even though the king, according to his whim, had not been serving his priest and was acting improperly toward him, the people were still not oppressed until Indra himself, in the form of a thousand-eyed being, stopped sending rain.

sloka: ihāgato jaṭilo brahmacārī na vai hrasvo nātidīrgho manasvī| suvarṇavarṇaḥ kamalāyatākṣaḥ svataḥ surāṇāmiva śobhamānaḥ||
translation: Here has come, a twice-born, maintaining brahmacarya, not overly short or excessively tall, of wise intellect, with golden hue, lotus-like eyes; he naturally shines, like the suras (gods).

sloka: sa lomapādaḥ paripūrṇakāmaḥ sutāṃ dadāvṛṣyaśṛṅgāya śāntām| krodhapratīkārakaraṃ ca cakre gāścaiva mārgeṣu ca karṣaṇāni||
translation: Lomapada, now contented, gave protection to Risyasringa and made his path safe, having created soothing calmness and the means to counter anger. He also caused the singing of songs and the plowing of roads.

sloka: ṛṣyaśṛṅgastu jāmātā putrāṃstava vidhāsyati sanatkumārakathitametāvadvyāhṛtaṃ mayā
translation: Rishyashringa, the son of my former teacher, will establish (his) sons in your tradition, as I have related and is known.

sloka: brahmacārī gṛhasthaśca vānaprastho yatistathā | ete gṛhasthaprabhavāścatvāraḥ pṛthagāśramāḥ | yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | yathā nadīnadāḥ sarve sāgare yānti saṃsthitim | tathaivāśramiṇaḥ sarve gṛhasthe yānti saṃsthitim |
translation: Just as all beings exist depending on the wind, similarly, they thrive in the householder stage. Just as rivers flow and merge into the ocean, likewise, all ascetics settle down in the householder stage. Indeed, we have seen that all beings originate from the grhasta-asrama (householder stage), which is fourfold and distinct.

sloka: gṛhasthaḥ pravarasteṣāṃ gārhasthyaṃ dharmamāśritaḥ|
translation: The best of householders, established in the conduct called gārhasthya as his religion.

sloka: samyaktapaścarantīha śraddadhānā vanāśrame | gṛhāśramasya te devi kalāṃ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm ||
translation: Those who practice austerities with devotion in the forest, oh goddess, they do not fail to grant you a sixteenth part of themselves.

sloka: yathā mātaramāśritya sarve jīvanti jantavaḥ | tathā gṛhāśramaṃ prāpya sarve jīvanti cāśramāḥ||
translation: Just as all beings live relying on their mothers, so do all inhabitants of the domestic ashram live having attained it.

sloka: vedānadhītya vedau vā vedaṃ vāpi yathākramam | aviplutabrahmacaryo gṛhasthāśramaṃ āvaset |
translation: After properly studying the Vedas, whether one or two (verses/texts), in their given order, let a perpetually celibate grihastha (householder) reside in his stage of life.

sloka: adhītya vedānkṛtasarvakṛtyaḥ saṃtānamutpādya sukhāni bhuktvā| samāhitaḥ pracaredduścaraṃ taṃ gārhasthyadharmaṃ munidharmajuṣṭam||
translation: Having studied the Vedas and fulfilled all duties, after experiencing joyous occasions, having been fully prepared, they should pursue that supreme and difficult household duty, which has been followed by sages and is associated with righteousness.

sloka: sarveṣāṃ api caiteṣāṃ vedasmṛtividhānataḥ | gṛhastha ucyate śreṣṭhaḥ sa trīnetānbibharti hi |
translation: Of all the paths, the one who follows the prescriptions of the Vedas and smritis is considered the best among these; he supports (practices) the three (stages of life) of them.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca ||
translation: Remaining true to his virtuous nature, endowed with moderate food consumption and skilled, possessing faith and having conquered his senses, let him engage in transactions with women and those who have been defeated by women.

sloka: pañcayajñaviśuddhātmā ṛtunityo'nasūyakaḥ| dānto brāhmaṇasatkartā susaṃmṛṣṭaniveśanaḥ|| cakṣuḥśrotramanojihvāsnigdhavarṇapradaḥ sadā| atithyabhyāgatarataḥ śeṣānnakṛtabhojanaḥ|| pādyamarghyaṃ yathānyāyamāsanaṃ śayanaṃ tathā| dīpaṃ pratiśrayaṃ caiva yo dadāti sa dhārmikaḥ||
translation: The self composed of five sacrificial offerings, always pure, and constantly performing righteous actions is one who is free from jealousy and always observant of the ritual duties. Such a person is endowed with a controlled sense of self, performing acts beneficial to Brahmins and is well-established in pleasant habitation. Always having bright eyes, ears, mind, and tongue, they bestow food and are hospitable to guests. They offer water, oblations, seat, bed, and light according to the scriptural rules. One who gives with respect these things to deserving persons is a follower of dharma.

sloka: mṛgoṣṭrakharamarkākhu sarīsṛpkhagamakṣikāḥ | ātmanaḥ putravatpaśyet taireṣāmantaraṃ kiyat ||
translation: Should a being viewing other creatures such as camels, elephants, and small insects like them regard any of them as being like his own child, to any extent?

sloka: svadāratuṣṭastvṛtukālagāmī niyogasevī na śaṭho na jihnaḥ| mitāśano devarataḥ kṛtajñaḥ satyo mṛduścānṛśaṃsaḥ kṣamāvān||
translation: Being content, one who is devoted to duties at the right time, not deceitful or greedy, with moderate eating, firm in religious vows, grateful, and truthful, mild, and forbearing, such a person is worthy.

sloka: śarīramekaṃ daṃpatyorvidhātrā pūrvanirmitam| tasmātsvadāranirato brahmacārī vidhīyate||
translation: The single, previously created physical form of the two spouses is therefore to be strictly observed by one dedicated to celibacy.

sloka: ekenāṃśena dharmārthaḥ kartavyo hitamicchatā| ekenāṃśena kāmārthamekamaṃśaṃ vivardhayet||
translation: With a single aspect, duty and wealth should be accomplished for the benefit of others; with another aspect, stimulate the growth of desire and one portion of it.

sloka: yāvad arthamupāsīno dehe gehe ca paṇḍitaḥ | virakto raktavat tatra nṛloke naratāṃ nyaset || divyaṃ bhaumaṃ cāntarīkṣaṃ vittaṃ acyutanirmitam | tatsarvaṃ upayuñjāna etatkuryāt svato budhaḥ ||
translation: As long as a discerning person is engaged in contemplation of the purpose in this body and in the pair of houses, they should wisely set themselves in the world, unattached and without attachment to sensual pleasures. They should make use of all—the divine, the earthly, and the celestial wealth, which are created by the infallible one—for themselves.

sloka: yāvad bhriyeta jaṭharaṃ tāvat svatvaṃ hi dehinām | adhikaṃ yo'bhimanyeta sa steno daṇḍamarhati ||
translation: As long as one's body is cared for, so long is their individuality present in embodied beings. The one who overestimates himself beyond that deserves to be called a thief and is worthy of punishment.

sloka: dānto vidheyo havyakavyāpramatto hyannasya dātā satataṃ dvijebhyaḥ| amatsarī sarvaliṅgapradātā vaitānanityaśca gṛhāśramī syāt||
translation: The self-controlled one, to be offered as oblation, engaged in scriptural studies, never neglectful, and the constant giver of food should reside in his home; always unenvious, giving all types of marks (or symbols), and steady, he should be.

sloka: atithipriyatā dharmo dharmastretāgnidhāraṇam| iṣṭirvā paśubandhāśca vidhipūrvaṃ paraṃtapa||
translation: Hospitality towards guests and upholding religious duties constitute the true religion. Similarly, the collection of firewood for the sacred Yajna fires is also a religious duty. Additionally, performing ritual offerings (iṣṭi) and taking care of cattle are also important duties to be performed first, O Tapasvi!

sloka: vaivāhike'gnau kurvīta gṛhyaṃ karma yathāvidhi | pañcayajñavidhānaṃ ca paktiṃ cānvāhikīṃ gṛhī |
translation: In the marriage ritual, one should properly perform the gṛhya karma in the fire and also diligently follow the regulations of the five daily yajñas.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan | tāsāṃ krameṇa sarvāsāṃ niṣkṛtyarthaṃ maharṣibhiḥ | pañca klptā mahāyajñāḥ pratyahaṃ gṛhamedhinām |
translation: Of the householder's five oblations, consisting of culli, grains, upaskara, kaṇḍanī, and kumbha, those who are being transported are bound. With regard to all of them, the great sages have ordained five grand sacrifices for the householder to perform every day: the niṣkṛti sacrifice and so on.

sloka: svādhyāyenārcayeta rṣīnhomairdevānyathāvidhi | pitṝñ śrāddhaiśca nṝnannairbhūtāni balikarmaṇā |
translation: With regular study, one should properly honor the sages and gods by prescribed rites; (and) with offerings of food, ancestors and other beings. This is the duty of a strong person, performed through actions referred to as 'bali'.

sloka: pañcaitānyo mahāayajñānna hāpayati śaktitaḥ | sa gṛhe'pi vasannityaṃ sūnādoṣairna lipyate | devatātithibhṛtyānāṃ pitṝṇāṃ ātmanaśca yaḥ | na nirvapati pañcānāṃ ucchvasanna sa jīvati | svādhyāye nityayuktaḥ syāddaive caiveha karmaṇi | daivakarmaṇi yukto hi bibhartīdaṃ carācaram |
translation: Five such great sacrifices, he who is capable and residing at home, never gets tainted by the sins from sons and others. The performer of duties towards deity-installations, guests, servants, parents, and oneself, and who offers oblations to five fires, indeed lives. Always engaged in self-study and occasional performance of Vedic rituals, such a person supports all moving and non-moving entities.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | yatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti gāṃ dattvā vidhivadguroḥ | tatpuṇyaphalaṃ āpnoti bhikṣāṃ dattvā dvijo gṛhī |
translation: Having done this task of a guest's reception, one should invite in this way; and to the mendicant, one should respectfully give alms according to rule. By giving a cow to a teacher according to rule, a brāhmaṇa student obtains the fruit of merit; similarly, by giving alms to a dvija, a householder also obtains the same fruit of merit.

sloka: saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam |
translation: Upon arrival, one should offer (pradadyāt) a seat and water according to their ability, treating the guest with respect following the prescribed rituals (yathā śakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam).

sloka: bhuktavatsvatha vipreṣu sveṣu bhṛtyeṣu caiva hi | bhuñjīyātāṃ tataḥ paścādavaśiṣṭaṃ tu dampatī | devānṛṣīnmanuṣyāṃśca pitṝngṛhyāśca devatāḥ | pūjayitvā tataḥ paścādgṛhasthaḥ śeṣabhugbhavet |
translation: Having partaken in offerings, the priest should afterward enjoy (them) among his own people and servants. Then, he and his wife should consume what remains. Afterward, they should honor gods, sages, humans, ancestors, and family deities. Having worshipped them, the householder may become a consumer of the leftovers.

sloka: śuśrūṣante ye pitaraṃ mātaraṃ ca gṛhāśrame| bhartāraṃ caiva yā nārī agnihotraṃ ca ye dvijāḥ|| teṣuteṣu ca prīṇanti devā indrapurogamāḥ| pitaraḥ pitṛlokasthāḥ svadharmeṇa sa rajyate||
translation: Those who diligently serve their father, mother, and spouse in the household, as well as those who are devoted to performing agnihotra rituals, please the gods, including Indra, in those homes. The ancestors, who reside in pitrloka, are satisfied through the performance of their respective duties.

sloka: maharṣipitṛdevānāṃ gatvānṛṇyaṃ yathāvidhi | putre sarvaṃ samāsajya vasenmādhyasthyaṃ āśritaḥ |
translation: Having paid respects to the ancestors of the great sages, one should approach a person in need according to proper procedure, unite everything for the son, cause him to rule while taking up a mediator's role, having taken up such a position.

sloka: ekākī cintayennityaṃ vivikte hitaṃ ātmanaḥ | ekākī cintayāno hi paraṃ śreyo'dhigacchati |
translation: A solitary person, reflecting continuously in isolation on what is beneficial for himself, indeed attains the highest welfare.

sloka: satsaṅgācchanakaiḥ saṅgaṃ ātmajāyātmajādiṣu | vimuñcen mucyamāneṣu svayaṃ svapnavadutthitaḥ ||
translation: Leaving attachment behind through good company and to those who are like his own children, he should himself become freely moving, as if awakening from a dream, when they are being released.

sloka: siddhairyajñāvaśiṣṭārthaiḥ kalpayed vṛttimātmanaḥ | śeṣe svatvaṃ tyajan prājñaḥ padavīṃ mahatāmiyāt ||
translation: The wise one should fashion a great disposition for himself with the remaining fruits of rituals accomplished through divine grace, abandoning personal ownership when everything is completed.

sloka: eṣu snānaṃ japo homo vrataṃ devadvijārcanam | pitṛdevanṛbhūtebhyo yad dattaṃ taddhyanaśvaram ||
translation: To these (eṣu): ablution (snānam), recitation (japaḥ), fire ritual (homaḥ), vow (vratam), and worship of gods, brahmins, and ancestors (deva-dvija-arcanam) are firmly established (taddhyanaśvaram) that have been given (dattam). As for the things given (yat dattaṃ) to the beings (bhūtebhyaḥ), they are under the control of the givers' intention.

sloka: etāndeśān niṣeveta śreyaskāmo hyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ | dharmo hyatrehitaḥ puṃsāṃ sahasrādhiphalodayaḥ || ||
translation: Let a person devoted to virtue frequently adopt these means, for dharma is that which procures thousands of fruitful ends for humans.

sloka: etāndeśān niṣeveta śreyaskāmo hyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ | dharmo hyatrehitaḥ puṃsāṃ sahasrādhiphalodayaḥ ||
translation: A virtuous person should regularly cultivate these habits/practices; for, righteousness, when adopted, yields a myriad of fruitful outcomes for people.

sloka: ye śāstravidhimutsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ | teṣāṃ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvamāho rajastamaḥ ||
translation: Those who, abandoning the rule of scripture, worship with faith – what is their resolve, Krishna? Are they in goodness, or are they in passion and darkness?

sloka: trividhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṃ sā svabhāvajā | sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṃ śṛṇu ||
translation: Faith in living beings is of three kinds, hear which are these: natural, saattvic, rajasic, and tamasic.

sloka: sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata | śraddhāmayo'yaṃ puruṣo yo yacchraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ ||
translation: In Bhārata, faith of everyone becomes conforming to their sattva. Indeed, this person, composed of faith, is that very faith itself.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: The sattva gets established in happiness, O Bhārata, while rajaḥ does so in activity; knowledge, when covered, becomes tamas, leading to error.

sloka: yaḥ śāstravidhimutsṛjya vartate kāmakārataḥ | na sa siddhimavāpnoti na sukhaṃ na parāṃ gatim || tasmācchāstraṃ pramāṇaṃ te kāryākāryavyavasthitau | jñātvā śāstravidhānoktaṃ karma kartumihārhasi ||
translation: The one who abandons the rule of scripture and acts according to his own desire does not attain success, happiness, or the highest goal. Therefore, scripture is your means for determining what ought and ought not be done. Knowing the rule of scripture as taught, you should endeavor to perform that action here.

sloka: aśāstravihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ | dambhāhaṃkārasaṃyuktāḥ kāmarāgabalānvitāḥ || karṣayantaḥ śarīrasthaṃ bhūtagrāmamacetasaḥ | māṃ caivāntaḥśarīrasthaṃ tānviddhyāsuraniścayān ||
translation: "Those people in this world, who are engaged in austerities that are not prescribed by the scriptures, are terribly afflicted. Driven by arrogance and self-importance, they are consumed by desires and are attached to power. They torment both their physical bodies and, within themselves, the aggregate of beings. Know them to be demonic in their convictions."

sloka: āhārastvapi sarvasya trividho bhavati priyaḥ | yajñastapastathā dānaṃ teṣāṃ bhedamimaṃ śṛṇu ||
translation: Food, too, is of three kinds, pleasing to everyone. Likewise, there are three kinds of sacrificial rituals , austerities , and charity . Now listen to their distinction .

sloka: oṃtatsaditi nirdeśo brahmaṇastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇāstena vedāśca yajñāśca vihitāḥ purā ||
translation: The designation "tat sat" is remembered as having threefold meaning in Brahman. In the past, brahmans and vedic rituals were established through it.

sloka: tasmādomityudāhṛtya yajñadānatapaḥkriyāḥ | pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṃ brahmavādinām || tadityanabhisandhāya phalaṃ yajñatapaḥkriyāḥ | dānakriyāśca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣakāṅkṣibhiḥ || sadbhāve sādhubhāve ca sadityetatprayujyate | praśaste karmaṇi tathā sacchabdaḥ pārtha yujyate || yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ saditi cocyate | karma caiva tadarthīyaṃ sadityevābhidhīyate ||
translation: Therefore, the acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity, as ordained, are continually performed by followers of Brahma's teachings. Understanding the results of such sacrificial rites, charities, and austerities, various kinds are performed by those desiring liberation. The term 'sat' is used in the context of righteousness, both in its presence and absence. The word 'sadhu' is applied to an action that is proper. In sacrifices, austerities, and charities, stability is referred to as 'sat'. The term 'sat' is also used to describe the objective of actions. Hence, Partha, the word 'sat' is employed in various contexts.

sloka: aśraddhayā hutaṃ dattaṃ tapastaptaṃ kṛtaṃ ca yat | asadityucyate pārtha na ca tatpretya no iha ||
translation: Offered without faith, given, austerities performed, and actions done – all that is called Asadita, O Partha, and neither here nor in the next world does it remain.

sloka: sa hovāca pitaraṃ tata kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti
translation: He asked his father, "To whom would you give me as a servant?"

sloka: tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa ||
translation: This fire, named by you, will become many-formed. Take hold of this one.

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū |
translation: The Three-fire oblationist, having completed three karma rituals, transcends the cycle of birth and death.

sloka: yaddurangatha bhavathi yachasyam bhutani gachati
translation: That which moves on its own and that which other things move as directed.

sloka: pasunamehabhavati yathasma deva
translation: O lord, (tell me) how cattle thrive, as you know.

sloka: gavamsuryaha paro guruhu
translation: The supreme teacher of the cows and the sun.

sloka: atrā guru śabdha karanamaci
translation: The sound here indeed refers to the teacher.

sloka: nanavarnakrtini ca
translation: Including those of various colors and kinds.

sloka: lokāḥ samastāḥ sukhino bhavantu |
translation: May all the worlds be prosperous and happy! (Or, Let all the worlds be/become happy!)

sloka: tadyaddūrvā bhavatyoṣadhīnāmevāsmiṃstatkṣatraṃ dadhātyatho pratiṣṭhāmetāni ha vai
translation: I, as the species of grass known as dūrvā, am established in plants and given the designation "kṣatra" in this location. Indeed, these are so.

sloka: ṛgbhyo jātaṃ vaiśyaṃ varṇamāhuḥ | yajurvedaṃ kṣatriyasyāhuryonim | sāmavedo brāhmaṇānāṃ prasūtiḥ |
translation: The caste of the Vaisya is produced from the  Ridge-hymns, while the recitation of the Yajurveda is the birthright of the Kshatriya; the SamaVEDA is the offspring of the Brahmins.

sloka: brahma vā idamagra āsīt| ekameva tadekaṃ sanna vyabhavattacchreyo rūpamatyasṛjata kṣatraṃ yānyetāni devatrā kṣatrāṇīndro varuṇaḥ somo rudraḥ parjanyo yamo mṛtyurīśāna iti |
translation: In the beginning, only Brahman existed. You alone became one, then manifold; you projected this excellent form as supreme power. You cast as gods such as Indra, Varuṇa, Soma, Rudra, Parjanya, Yama, and Death, and also as powers such as sovereignty.

sloka: sa śaudraṃ varṇamasṛjata pūṣaṇamiyaṃ vai pūṣeyaṃ hīdaṃ sarvaṃ puṣyati yadidaṃ kiṃ ca|
translation: You (singular, masculine) of the servant class indeed created this variety and color in the past, even as Pushan does now. All that is here, Pusha, grows because of you. What is this, if not you, that everything consumes?

sloka: udāttaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ vidyānnīcaṃ kṣatriyameva ca| vaiśyaṃ tu svaritaṃ vidyād bhāradvājamudāttakam | nīcaṃ gautamamityāhurgārgyaṃ ca svaritaṃ viduḥ |
translation: Learn the Brahmana with an elevated tone, and the Kshatriya so with a steady one. The Vaishya is to be known in a fluctuating tone, as BhāradvājaMudāttaka. They call Gautama and Mityā "the lowly" with a steady tone. Know Gārgya as "the known" (with the root iti).

sloka: svarāstu brāhmaṇā jñeyā vargāṇāṃ prathamāśca ye dvitīyāśca tṛtīyāśca caturthāścāpi bhūmipāḥ
translation: The sounds, indeed, are to be understood by the brahmans as the foremost among the groups, namely the second, the third, and the fourth, as well as the bhūmipas.

sloka: vargāṇāṃ pañcamā vaiśyā antasthāśca tathaiva ca ūṣmāṇaśca hakāraśca śūdrā eva prakīrtitāḥ
translation: The fifth of the social classes, the Vaishyas, and those who reside within the group, as well as those known as Hakara, are all collectively identified as Shudras.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ| tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam||
translation: The four-class system created by me, based on qualities and actions , even its creator, recognize that as me, the imperishable one , who is also not an agent in this.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The mouth belongs to the Brahmana, his arms to the king, his thighs to the Vaisya, and from his feet the Shudra was born.

sloka: brahma vai svaṃ mahimānaṃ brāhmaṇeṣvadadhād adhyayanaadhyāpanayajanayājanadānapratigrahasaṃyuktaṃ vedānāṃ guptyai ||
translation: I, the Brahman, indeed make my own greatness (powers) manifest among the brāhmaṇas through study, teaching, procreation, and acceptance of gifts, for the protection of the Vedas.

sloka: kṣatre balam adhyayanayajanadānaśastrakośabhūtarakṣaṇasaṃyuktaṃ kṣatrasya vṛddhyai ||
translation: The strength, including that of study, ritual donations, weapons and treasury, associated with protecting living beings, is for the enhancement of the kshatriya's power.

sloka: viṭsv adhyayanayajanadānakṛṣivāṇijyapaśupālanasaṃyuktaṃ karmaṇāṃ vṛddhyai ||
translation: To promote the growth of activities such as studying, performing sacrifices, giving gifts, farming, trading, and tending to animals.

sloka: śūdreṣu pūrveṣāṃ paricaryām ||
